questions.text: 1. Which of the following Electron Transport Chain complexes is inhibited by malonate?
questions.solution:
Malonate inhibits succinate dehydrogenase (Complex II).

Malonate is a structural analogue of succinate and acts as a competitive inhibitor of succinate dehydrogenase, also known as Complex II of the Electron Transport Chain (ETC). This enzyme plays a dual role — it’s part of both the TCA cycle, where it catalyses the oxidation of succinate to fumarate, and the ETC, where it helps transfer electrons from FADH₂ to coenzyme Q (ubiquinone).

This complex bypasses Complex I and transfers electrons from FADH₂ to Q. When malonate binds to the active site, it blocks succinate from interacting with the enzyme, halting both TCA, ETC progression at this step. 

Other options: 

Option A: NADH-Q oxidoreductase (Complex I) – Inhibited by rotenone and amobarbital. It transfers electrons from NADH to ubiquinone.

Option B: Q-Cyt c oxidoreductase (Complex III) – Inhibited by British Anti-Lewisite. It transfers electrons from reduced coenzyme Q (ubiquinol, QH₂) to cytochrome c.

Option D: Cyt c oxidase (Complex IV) – Inhibited by cyanide and carbon monoxide. It transfers electrons from cytochrome c to oxygen.

questions.text: 2. Which of the following nerves and arteries pass beneath the extensor retinaculum of the foot?

choices.text: Deep peroneal nerve, Posterior tibial artery
Superficial peroneal nerve, Posterior tibial artery
Deep peroneal nerve, Anterior tibial artery
Superficial peroneal nerve, Anterior tibial artery

questions.solution:
Deep peroneal nerve and anterior tibial artery pass beneath the extensor retinaculum of the foot.

The following are the structures passing deep to the superior and inferior extensor retinacula:

* Tibialis anterior tendon

* Extensor hallucis longus tendon

* Deep peroneal nerve

* Extensor digitorum longus tendon

* Peroneus tertius tendon

The anterior tibial vessels pass deep to the superior extensor retinaculum, while the dorsalis pedis vessels pass deep to the inferior extensor retinaculum.

Note: The tendon of tibialis posterior passes deep to the flexor retinaculum of the foot

questions.text: 3. A healthy child is brought to the pediatrician for a routine check-up. The child comes in with a toy in her hand and readily shares it with the doctor. She knows her full name and gender. Her mother says that she is able to ride a tricycle. If she is given paper and pen, which of the following will she be able to do?
questions.solution:
This child who knows her name and gender, shares toys, and rides a tricycle is around three years of age and she will be able to copy a circle.

Developmental milestones at the age of three:

Fine motor and adaptive: Copy a circle, Makes a tower of 9 blocks

Gross motor: Rides tricycle, and walk upstairs with one foot on each step

Social and adaptive milestones: Shares toys, plays simple games, helps in dressing, and washes hands

Language milestones: Knows full name and gender, ask questions

Other options:

Options B and C- A child copies square and cross at age of 4 years. 

Option D-  A child copy a triangle at age of 5 years.

questions.text: 4. Tirzepatide, a newly approved drug, is the analogue of which gastrointestinal hormones?
questions.solution:
Tirzepatide is a dual GLP and GIP agonist.

Tirzepatide is given subcutaneously. It can be used for long-term weight management in adults who have obesity (BMI ≥ 30 kg/m²) or who are overweight (BMI ≥ 27 kg/m²) with at least one weight-related comorbidity (e.g., hypertension, type 2 diabetes, or dyslipidemia), as an adjunct to calorie restriction and increased physical activity.

questions.text: 5. A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a high-speed collision of his car with a stationary object. He is hypotensive and tachycardic. On examination, chest bruising and decreased breath sounds were noted on the left. A chest X-ray reveals a widened mediastinum and multiple rib fractures. What is the most likely life-threatening injury in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents after a high-speed collision with a widened mediastinum, hypotension, and chest trauma, which are signs pointing toward traumatic aortic rupture due to sudden deceleration.

Traumatic aortic injury often results from sudden deceleration, which causes shearing forces at fixed points of the aorta, most commonly the aortic isthmus, just distal to the left subclavian artery. A widened mediastinum on chest X-ray is a hallmark.

Aortic rupture may initially present with subtle signs like chest pain or shortness of breath, but many patients experience rapid decompensation due to hemorrhagic shock. CT angiography is used for confirmation. Immediate surgical or endovascular repair is required after stabilising blood pressure.

Other options:

Option A: Pulmonary contusion causes alveolar haemorrhage and respiratory distress but does not lead to a widened mediastinum or profound hypotension.

Option B: Tension pneumothorax causes unilateral breath sounds and tracheal deviation, not a widened mediastinum, and is treated with immediate decompression.

Option D: Rupture of the diaphragm is usually large with herniation of the abdominal contents into the chest. Diagnosis of diaphragmatic rupture can be missed in the acute phase, and may only be discovered at operation or through the presentation of complications.

questions.text: 6. A 32-year-old male patient came with complaints of pain, photophobia, and watery discharge for a few days. The inspection findings are as shown in the image below. On examination, preauricular lymph nodes are found to be enlarged. No history of pharyngitis or fever was present. Which of the following can be a causative agent for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of pain, redness, photophobia, lacrimation of both eyes with preauricular lymphadenopathy, and an image showing conjunctival congestion, chemosis, multiple hemorrhages in bulbar conjunctiva along with lid edema are suggestive of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. It is caused by enterovirus 70.  

Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis is caused by picornavirus namely enterovirus 70 and coxsackievirus. It is also known as Apollo conjunctivitis. 

Patients present with pain, watering, mild photophobia, transient blurring of vision, and lid swelling.

On examination, conjunctival congestion, chemosis, multiple haemorrhages in the bulbar conjunctiva, follicular hyperplasia, lid oedema, and preauricular lymphadenopathy.

It has a rapid onset and is usually self-limiting, running a course of 1-2 weeks. Broad-spectrum antibiotic eye drops can be used to prevent secondary bacterial infections. 

Other options:

Option A- Herpes simplex causes herpetic conjunctivitis. It presents as acute unilateral follicular conjunctivitis and is often associated with skin vesicles.

Option B- Adenovirus 3, 4 and 7 causes pharyngoconjunctival fever. It is characterized by acute follicular conjunctivitis in association with pharyngitis, fever, and occasionally preauricular lymphadenopathy. It is commonly seen in children. 

Option D- Molluscum contagiosum is a skin infection caused by a human-specific double-stranded DNA pox virus. The skin lesions shed virus particles and can cause chronic follicular conjunctivitis associated with mild watery, mucoid discharge. A pale, waxy, umbilicated nodule on the lid margin can be seen. It is commonly seen in children between the ages of 2-4 years.

questions.text: 7. Which organism shows the below-depicted phenomenon when incubated with staphylococcus aureus on blood agar?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the phenomenon of satellitism which is exhibited by Haemophilus influenzae when incubated on blood agar along with Staphylococcus aureus.

H. influenzae requires growth factors V and X that are present in the blood.

* Factor V  is a nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD), a coenzyme, and is heat labile.

* Factor X is hemin. It is required for cytochrome synthesis and the function of enzymes like catalase and peroxidase. It is heat stable.

Satellitism is seen when S. aureus is streaked across a plate of blood agar on which H. influenzae has been inoculated. After overnight incubation, the colonies of H. influenzae will be large and well-developed alongside the streak of Staphylococcus and smaller when they are farther away from the streak. This is due to the release of factor V by lysis of RBCs mediated by S. aureus. Thus factor V is present in high concentrations near the streak. The Hemophilus colonies become progressively smaller further away from the streak because the factor V concentration becomes less. 

The given image shows satellitism on blood agar.

questions.text: 8. According to the Weigert–Meyer rule, which ureter is more prone to obstruction?

choices.text: Ureters of the right kidney are more prone as compared to left kidney, irrespective of the pole

questions.solution:
The ureter marked as 2 will be more prone to obstruction.

The Weigert–Meyer rule describes the insertion pattern of duplicated ureters in a duplex collecting system. In this condition, a single kidney has two ureters — one draining the upper pole and the other draining the lower pole of the kidney. According to this rule, the ureter from the upper renal segment inserts into the bladder in an inferior and medial position compared to the ureter from the lower segment, which inserts in a more superior and lateral position.

The upper ureter is considered ectopic and the lower ureter is considered orthotopic. Ectopic ureters are more prone to obstruction. Orthotopic ureters are more prone to reflux due to perpendicular entry into bladder musculature rather than oblique entry.

According to Weigert Meyer's rule of congenital complete duplication of the ureter:

* The ureter that inserts inferiorly and medially (typically draining the upper pole) is more prone to obstruction. This is because it often ends in an ectopic location (such as the urethra, vagina, or even below the sphincter in females) and lacks a normal, oblique tunnel through the bladder wall, making it more vulnerable to functional obstruction. 

* In contrast, the superior and lateral ureter (draining the lower pole) is more commonly associated with vesicoureteral reflux (VUR). This happens because its insertion is usually anatomically higher and more lateral, leading to a shorter submucosal tunnel in the bladder wall, which reduces the anti-reflux mechanism. 

(EASY TO REMEMBER - LOWER pole LATERAL upper)

questions.text: 9. A 65-year old male with a hypertensive emergency is started on IV Sodium nitroprusside. After 48 hours of therapy, he develops confusion, tachycardia, metabolic acidosis and a progressive decline in serum bicarbonate levels. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Continue sodium nitroprusside infusion at the current dose and monitor blood pressure closely.
Stop nitroprusside immediately and administer sodium thiosulfate infusion.
Decrease the nitroprusside dose and add IV nicardipine to maintain BP control.
Cover the IV bag and tubing with an opaque material, continue nitroprusside infusion, and reassess.

questions.solution:
Immediate discontinuation of nitroprusside and administration of sodium thiosulfate is the best course of action. This patient with symptoms of confusion, tachycardia, metabolic acidosis and declining bicarbonate level is suffering from cyanide toxicity. Sodium thiosulfate acts as a sulfur donor to convert cyanide into thiocyanate, which is less toxic and renally excreted. The infusion has been continued for a longer period of time and hence it has resulted into cyanide toxicity.

Cyanide toxicity is a life-threatening complication of sodium nitroprusside, especially when:

* High doses (>2 mcg/kg/min) are used.

* Prolonged infusions (>24–48 hours) occur.

* Renal impairment is present (reduced cyanide clearance)

Other options:

Option A: Continuing sodium nitroprusside infusion at the current dose and monitoring blood pressure closely is an incorrect statement since it would worsen toxicity and could lead to fatal metabolic disturbances.

Option C: Reducing the dose alone does not reverse cyanide toxicity. Primary management should focus on cyanide detoxification first before considering BP control. Alternative antihypertensive agents (e.g., Nicardipine, Labetalol) are often needed after stopping Nitroprusside. Hence this is an incorrect statement.

Option D: Covering the IV bag and tubing is necessary to prevent decomposing of the drug, but in this case, since the patient already has signs of cyanide toxicity, the priority is treating it, which requires stopping the drug and administering sodium thiosulfate.

questions.text:
10. A 32-year-old woman came with complaints of a frontal headache, nasal congestion and pain near the gums. A diagnosis of allergic fungal sinusitis was made. Which of the following are included in the major criteria for diagnosis of this condition ?

1. Nasal polyposis

2. Positive fungal culture

3. Positive fungal stain

4. Serum eosinophilia

5. Double density sign on CT scan
questions.solution:
The major criteria that are used for the positive diagnosis of allergic fungal sinusitis are nasal polyposis, positive fungal stain and characteristic CT findings like double density sign.

Bent and Kuhn’s diagnostic criteria are used as diagnostic criteria for Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis (AFRS). It includes : Major Criteria | Minor criteria 1. Type I hypersensitivity  2. Nasal polyposis 3. Characteristic CT findings 4. Eosinophilic mucin without invasion 5. Positive fungal stain | 1. Asthma 2. Unilateral disease 3. Bone erosion 4. Fungal cultures 5. Charcot-Leyden crystals 6. Serum eosinophilia

All the major criteria must be met by the patient, while the minor criteria serve to support the diagnosis and describe individual patients.

Characteristic CT findings in AFRS include heterogeneous signal intensities within the paranasal sinuses filled with allergic mucin (double density sign or rail track sign), expansion of the paranasal sinuses/nasal cavity, unilateral or asymmetric disease load, and bony erosion.

Treatment of allergic fungal sinusitis includes avoidance of allergen exposure, antihistamines, corticosteroid nasal sprays, aggressive surgical intervention for mucin removal which improves sinus drainage, post-surgery oral corticosteroids, and immunotherapy against fungal and non-fungal allergens.

questions.text: 11. An iodinated anti-arrhythmic drug belonging to Class 3 caused the ocular finding seen in the image below. What is the most likely type of cataract caused by this drug?
questions.solution:
Anterior subcapsular cataract is the most likely type of cataract seen in Amiodarone toxicity.

The given clinical scenario involves a patient taking an iodinated Class 3 anti-arrhythmic drug, and developing Corneal verticillata/ Vortex keratopathy which is highly suggestive of amiodarone toxicity. Anterior sub-capsular cataract is seen in amiodarone toxicity.

Amiodarone is a structural analog of the thyroid hormone, a highly lipophilic Class 3 antiarrythmic drug that contains iodine in its molecular structure. It is used for ventricular rate control in atrial fibrillation, and in ventricular tachycardia and fibrillation. It is a potassium and sodium channel blocker.

The most important side effects of amiodarone are pulmonary fibrosis which can result in death, and thyroid dysfunction, with the potential for both hypothyroidism and less commonly hyperthyroidism. Corneal microdeposits known as corneal verticillata/ vortex keratopathy are a common finding and are usually asymptomatic. Other ocular adverse effects include cataracts and optic neuropathy. questions.text: 12. A patient on an antipsychotic pharmacotherapy started complaining of browning of vision. This is due to _________
questions.solution:
Thioridazine is associated with the browning of vision.

Pigmentary retinopathy is an adverse effect of thioridazine. In advanced cases, the deposits may resemble retinitis pigmentosa, and the deposits are associated with "Browning of Vision".

questions.text: 13. Which of the following statements is correct for mixed connective tissue disorder?

choices.text: Raynaud’s phenomenon is the characteristic initial presentation
The long-term prognosis is poor than that of systemic sclerosis

questions.solution:
Raynaud’s phenomenon is the characteristic initial presentation of mixed connective tissue disorder.

Mixed connective tissue disorder is a type of overlap syndrome and has features of localised systemic sclerosis, systemic lupus erythematosus, polymyositis, and rheumatoid arthritis. Raynaud’s phenomenon is a common presentation and is associated with puffy fingers and myalgia. Over time, sclerodactyly, soft-tissue calcinosis, and cutaneous telangiectasia can appear.

Other clinical features that can be associated are :

* Malar erythema, photosensitivity suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus

* Dermatomyositis (heliotrope rash on the eyelids, erythematous rash on knuckles)

* Arthralgia

* Erosive polyarthritis

* Pulmonary fibrosis and isolated or secondary Pulmonary artery hypertension

* Oesophageal dysmotility

* Pericarditis

* Sjögren’s syndrome

* Renal disease

* Membranous glomerulonephritis

These clinical features can appear at any time throughout the course of the disease. Nail-fold capillaroscopy reveals dilated capillary loops, capillary dropout, and vascular malformations similar to those seen in Systemic Sclerosis. Laboratory evaluation shows elevated ESR and hypergammaglobulinemia. Anti-U1RNP (ribonucleoprotein) antibodies are detected in high titers, and systemic sclerosis-specific autoantibodies are absent.

Mixed connective tissue disorder can lead to interstitial lung disease and Pulmonary arterial hypertension, which is the leading cause of mortality in such patients. Central and peripheral nervous system involvement is relatively uncommon. Mixed connective tissue disorder responds to glucocorticoids, and the long-term prognosis is better than that of systemic sclerosis.

questions.text: 14. A patient presented with anemia, decreased haptoglobin and elevated serum LDH levels. Peripheral smear of the patient is shown. Which of the following is not a differential diagnosis for this condition?
questions.solution:
Fanconi anemia is not a likely differential diagnosis for a microangiopathic hemolytic anemic (MAHA) picture, as given in the scenario. Stem-cell depletion resulting in anemia is seen in Fanconi anemia, not hemolysis-induced anemia.

The given vignette describes a patient with anemia with low haptoglobin levels and elevated LDH levels. Low haptoglobin is seen in hemolytic anemias due to the complexing of the haptoglobin with extracorpuscular hemoglobin, which is increased in MAHA. LDH levels are elevated further suggestive of RBC hemolysis. The peripheral smear has two significant findings, schistocytes and helmet cells, as shown below:



Schistocytes are fragmented red cells that are smaller than the red cell itself and have sharp angles and spurs. They are typically seen in cases of red cell fragmentation such as microangiopathic hemolytic anemia(MAHA), cardiac hemolytic anemia due to valve shearing, etc. Helmet cells and triangle cells are specific shapes of fragmented RBCs seen in MAHA.

MAHA is observed as the clinical picture in conditions where intravascular hemolysis of RBCs occurs usually due to a mechanical disturbance in the flow of blood, causing shearing and fragmentation of RBCs. MAHA picture is seen in:

* Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)( Option C)

* Hemolytic uremic syndrome

* Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)

* HELLP syndrome (Option B)

* Malignant Hypertension (Option A)

In all these conditions, the primary mechanical factor responsible for RBC lysis is usually microthrombi in the vessel walls that cause shear stress on RBCs. In malignant hypertension, an additional contribution is from the elevated blood pressure.

In TTP, there is a deficiency of vWF metalloproteinase ADAMTS13 causing aggregation of large vWF multimers that activate platelets, create thrombi, occlude vessels, and cause MAHA. Clinical pentad of fever, MAHA, thrombocytopenia, and neurological and renal manifestations are seen.

In DIC, specific triggers cause mass activation of tissue factors leading to numerous microvascular thrombi, and occlusion of the vessels causing MAHA. A consumptive coagulopathy also occurs with concomitant excess fibrinolysis.

HELLP syndrome is seen in pre-eclampsia and includes hemolysis, low platelet count, and elevated liver enzymes and is basically a hypertensive emergency in pregnancy inducing an MAHA picture. In malignant hypertension, there is a diffuse endothelial injury that causes thrombus formation, microvascular occlusion and MAHA. 

Fanconi anemia (Option D) is an autosomal recessive defect in the gene responsible for homologous DNA repair. It is characterized by developmental abnormalities like short stature and skeletal anomalies, hypoplasia of the spleen and kidney with increased risk of marrow failure and leukemia. It causes stem cell depletion and non-hemolytic anemia with reduced RBC production. Biallelic BRCA2 gene mutations are a known cause.

questions.text: 15. A couple is unable to conceive after a year of unprotected intercourse. The husband’s semen analysis is normal. The wife has a history of dysmenorrhea, irregular menstrual cycles, and chronic abdominal pain. Identify the following investigation done for her:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of infertility due to endometriosis and the investigation shown in the image is laparoscopic chromopertubation. 

Laparoscopy is the gold standard method for the evaluation of tubal factors of infertility. Chromopertubation may be performed, in which a dilute dye is injected through a Leech-Wilkinson cannula placed against the cervix or through a balloon catheter positioned within the uterine cavity. Tubal spill is evaluated through the laparoscope. 

Indigo carmine dye, if available, is preferable to methylene blue, as methylene blue may rarely induce acute methemoglobinemia, particularly in patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency. It is commonly done in the proliferative phase.

Drawbacks: Laparoscopy is more invasive than hysterosalpingography (HSG). It cannot detect abnormalities in the uterine cavity or tubal lumen.

Other options:

Option A: Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is an imaging modality in which radiopaque contrast is injected through the cervical canal to assess the endometrial cavity, the fallopian tubes, and the endocervical canal.

HSG can be used for the following:

* To assess tubal patency in infertility 

* To detect uterine anomalies, synechiae, and polyps

* To detect incompetence of the cervical os. 

Given below is an HSG image:



Option B: Falloposcopy is the study of the entire length of the tubal lumen with the help of a fine and flexible fiberoptic device. It is performed through the uterine cavity, using a hysteroscope. It helps direct visualization of tubal ostia, mucosal pattern, intratubal polyps, or debris.

Option D: Salpingoscopy is the study of the tubal lumen by introducing a rigid endoscope through the fimbrial end of the tube. It is performed through the operating channel of a laparoscope.

questions.text: 16. An infant seems normal at birth but develops breathing difficulties shortly after birth with feeding problems, vomiting, and hypotonia. His urine was found to have a characteristic smell of tomcat urine. Which of the following is used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Tomcat urine odor is seen in Multiple carboxylase deficiency. Affected infants should be treated with Biotin.

Multiple carboxylase deficiency refers to inherited defects of metabolism of biotin

* Neonatal/infantile type: deficiency of holocarboxylase synthetase. Manifests in 1st week with:

* lethargy

* poor muscle tone

* vomiting.

* Juvenile/late type: deficiency of biotinidase. Slow and progressive with loss in urine, causing organic aciduria. It is characterized by:

* alopecia, dermatitis,

* ketoacidosis, 

* ataxia,

* seizures, myoclonus and nystagmus.

Both can be effectively managed through the administration of vitamin B7

It is called multiple carboxylase deficiency because biotin is a water-soluble vitamin that is a cofactor for all 4 carboxylase enzymes in humans:

* Pyruvate carboxylase

* Acetyl CoA carboxylase

* Propionyl CoA carboxylase

* 3-methylcrotonyl CoA carboxylase

questions.text:
17. A 68-year-old male undergoes a transrectal ultrasound (TRUS) guided biopsy for elevated PSA levels. The biopsy results confirmed prostate adenocarcinoma. The Gleason score is reported as 4+3=7. According to the 2014 WHO grading system, this corresponds to which Gleason Grade Group?

PSA: Prostate-Specific Antigen
questions.solution:
In this case, Gleason score of 4+3=7 falls under Gleason Grade Group 3.

Prostate cancers are classified using the Gleason Grading system. Here, the histopathologist looks at the biopsy sample and, depending on the findings, assigns one Gleason score to the most predominant pattern in the biopsy and a second Gleason score to the second most predominant pattern.

The Gleason system is a method used to evaluate the aggressiveness (grade) of prostate cancer based on how the cancer cells are arranged in the tumor tissue. A pathologist examines tissue samples from a biopsy and assigns a grade from 3 to 5 to the most common pattern of cancer cells (primary grade) and another grade from 3 to 5 to the second most common pattern (secondary grade). These two grades are then added together to obtain the Gleason score.

The Gleason Score is always a sum of two numbers. If only one Gleason grade is present, then this is doubled. In 2014, the International Society of Urological Pathology (ISUP) released a revised prostate cancer grading system, called the Grade Groups. It is a simpler classification with only five grades (1 to 5).

Highlights of 2014 WHO/ISUP modified Gleason score:

1) Gleason Pattern:

* Pattern 3- Well formed glands

* Pattern 4- Poorly formed/Fused/Cribriform glands/Glomeruloid glands

* Pattern 5- Sheets of the tumor, individual cells, cords and solid nests of cells, Comedo necrosis

* Pattern 1 and 2 are no longer defined

2) Gleason Score: The current Gleason score ranges from 6–10. 

3) Grade group (first score represents the most predominant pattern and the second represents the second most predominant pattern in the biopsy):

* Grade group 1: 3 + 3 = 6

* Grade group 2: 3 + 4  = 7

* Grade group 3: 4 + 3 = 7

* Grade group 4: 4 + 4; 3 + 5; or 5 + 3 = 8

* Grade group 5: 4 + 5; 5 + 4; or 5 + 5 = 9-10

In this case, the patient's Gleason score is reported as 4+3=7, indicating that the predominant pattern of cancer cells was assigned a grade of 4, and the second most common pattern was assigned a grade of 3, which belongs to Gleason Grade Group 3.

Pearl PM0161: Important tumor classifications

Important tumor classifications: Bloom Richardson grading | Carcinoma breast Butchart staging | Mesothelioma Chang staging | Medulloblastoma Duke staging | Colorectal carcinoma Gleason | Prostate Jackson | Carcinoma penis Masaoka staging | Thymoma Noguchi | Adenocarcinoma lung Nevin's staging | Carcinoma gall bladder Robson staging | Renal cell carcinoma Reiss and Ellsworth classification

Esson prognostic index | Retinoblastoma Shimada index | Neuroblastoma Sullivan modification of Macfarlane system | Adrenocortical carcinoma

questions.text: 18. A patient with proteinuria is being evaluated. A CT scan shows a thrombus in the inferior vena cava. What is the likely mechanism of proteinuria?
questions.solution:
This patient with a finding of proteinuria is found to have a thrombus in the inferior vena cava. This leads to an increased capillary hydrostatic pressure downstream from the renal vein, which leads to hyperfiltration and thus proteinuria. 

Starling's forces are what determine the rate of filtration along a capillary. These forces are represented as:

Fluid movement = k [(Pc− Pi) − (πc− πi)]

where, k = capillary filtration coefficient

Pc = capillary hydrostatic pressure

Pi = interstitial hydrostatic pressure

πc = capillary colloid osmotic pressure

πi = interstitial colloid osmotic pressure

Thrombosis of the inferior vena cava (IVC) impairs renal venous outflow, causing renal venous hypertension that is transmitted back to the glomerular capillaries. This elevation of glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure increases the net filtration pressure across the glomerular basement membrane, forcing protein into the ultrafiltrate and manifesting as proteinuria.  Similar findings are seen in a patient with hypertension who will also have hyperfiltration injury leading to proteinuria.

questions.text: 19. All of the following enzymes are a part of the CAD enzyme complex involved in pyrimidine biosynthesis except:
questions.solution:
All of the following enzymes are a part of the CAD enzyme complex involved in pyrimidine biosynthesis except carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I. It initiates the biosynthesis of urea.

The CAD multi-protein complex comprises the first three letters of enzymes involved in the first three reactions of pyrimidine biosynthesis. These enzymes are:

* Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II is a cytosolic enzyme responsible for the synthesis of carbamoyl phosphate in the presence of glutamine, CO2, and ATP. It is activated by phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate and inhibited by uridine triphosphate.

* Aspartate transcarbamoylase catalyzes the synthesis of carbamoyl aspartate from carbamoyl phosphate and aspartate. This is the rate-limiting step.

* Dihydroorotase is involved in the synthesis of dihydro-orotic acid from carbamoyl aspartate.

Whereas, carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I is a mitochondrial enzyme that uses ammonia as a nitrogen donor. It is involved in the synthesis of citrulline from ornithine in the urea cycle. It is not a part of the CAD complex. 

The pyrimidine synthesis pathway is shown in the image below.



A defect in the enzymes of pyrimidine synthesis can give rise to the following conditions: Enzyme deficiency | Disorder | Features Uridine-5-monophosphate synthase | Hereditary orotic aciduria | Megaloblastic anaemia, growth retardation, neurologic abnormalities, crystalluria, obstructive uropathy Pyrimidine-5-nucleotidase | Hemolytic anemia | Basophilic stippling of erythrocytes, high levels of cytidine and uridine ribonucleotides Dihydroprimidine dehydrogenase | Convulsive disorders, motor retardation, and mental retardation | increased urinary excretion of uracil, thymine

questions.text: 20. A patient is undergoing a diagnostic nasal endoscopy, and the physician observes a structure, labeled as A in the image below. The uncinate process and bulla ethmoidalis are visible between structure A and the lateral wall of the nose. Identify 'A'.
questions.solution:
The structure shown in the image is the middle turbinate.

The given image taken during a diagnostic nasal endoscopy has a structure marked as A. The bulla ethmoidalis and uncinate process are remarked to be between A and the lateral wall of the nose. Based on the given options, the most likely answer is the middle turbinate.



The middle turbinate is an ethmoturbinal, which implies that it is part of the ethmoid bone. It has an S-shaped attachment to the lateral wall termed the ground lamella. In the anterior third, it runs sagitally, in the middle third, it runs in the frontal plane, and in the posterior third, it runs horizontally.

The basal/ground lamella of the middle turbinate bone is the demarcating line between the anterior and posterior groups of sinuses. The middle turbinate forms the lateral boundary of the middle meatus. The middle meatus is an important location in the nasal cavity as multiple structures open into it.

An image of the structures visualised on removing the middle turbinate to view the middle meatus is shown along with a CT image of regional anatomy:





The structures seen in the middle meatus are the uncinate process, a bony projection inferiorly stemming from the inferior turbinate, superiorly varying in attachment, and has an anterosuperior to posteroinferior curve mirroring the bulla ethmoidalis located above and lateral to it.

The bulla ethmoidalis is a large ethmoidal air cell that projects into the middle meatus. The semilunar space between the bulla and uncinate is called hiatus semilunaris.

The area limited medially by the uncinate process and laterally by the lamina papyracea is the infundibulum, in the inferior aspect of which the maxillary sinus ostium drains. The frontal sinus opening is usually near the anterosuperior attachment of the uncinate process(which is variable) while the middle ethmoidal air cells open at the bulla ethmoidalis.

The osteomeatal complex is the name given to the area containing the openings of these various sinuses in the middle meatus. Hypertrophy, pneumatization of the middle turbinate (concha bullosa), cancerous masses on the middle turbinate, etc can cause the osteomeatal complex area to narrow considerably and result in sinusitis of the frontal, ethmoidal, and maxillary sinuses.

Pearl PM1424: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

* Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner

* Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.

* Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus

* Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: 21. On 2nd March 2025, AQI was recorded as 150 in Delhi. According to the Central Pollution Control Board of India, an air quality index of 150 is classified as?
questions.solution:
An air quality index of 150 is classified as Moderate.

An air quality index is an overall scheme that transforms the weighted values of individual air pollution-related parameters (for example, pollutant concentrations) into a single number or set of numbers.

AQI categories and the range as per the Central Pollution Control Board of India are as follows : AQI Category | AQI Range Good | 0 - 50 Satisfactory | 51 - 100 Moderate | 101 - 200 Poor | 201 - 300 Very poor | 301 - 400 Severe | 401 - 500

Eight pollutants are taken into consideration to calculate the AQI - 

* PM10 (Airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 10 microns or less)

* PM2.5 (Airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 2.5 microns or less)

* NO2 (Nitrogen dioxide)

* SO2 (Sulfur dioxide)

* CO (Carbon monoxide)

* O3 (Ozone/Trioxygen)

* NH3 (Ammonia)

* Pb (Lead)

Pearl PM1623: Air Pollution

The vertical diffusion of pollutants depends upon the temperature gradient. When there is rapid cooling of the lower atmospheric layers – which is called temperature inversion - due to little vertical diffusion, pollutants and water vapor get trapped in the lower levels of the atmosphere.

Air pollutants: Pollutant | Comments Carbon monoxide | Incomplete combustion of carbon-containing materials like fuel combustion, vehicles, industries, etc. Sulfur dioxide | Colorless gas Sharp odor Combustion of sulfur-containing fossil fuels, smelting of ores, etc Main components of acid rain. Lead | Usually occupational and environmental sources Carbon dioxide | Increase in a global concentration above natural levels can increase temperature and affect climate adversely. Hydrocarbons | Cause photochemical smog Cadmium | From volcanic action, waste incineration, zinc production, smoking, etc Hydrogen sulfide | Waste-water treatment plants, wood pulp production, coke production, etc Ozone | Ground-level ozone is one of the main constituents of photochemical smog. Oxides of nitrogen | Most common form is nitric oxide From coal burning, road traffic, and electricity generation Affects the lungs adversely Polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAH) | Incomplete burning of wood or coal, vehicle exhausts, smoking, etc Carcinogenic and mutagenic Particulate matter | Mixture of solid and liquid, organic and inorganic matter Major components are sulfates, nitrates, sodium chloride, mineral dust, black carbon, and water. Common indoor air pollutants | From coal or fuel combustion

Include CO, PAHs, nitrogen and sulfur oxides, pesticides, and other biological pollutants

Radon, lead, asbestos are formed from construction materials, paints, and demolition

Effects of indoor air pollution:

* Lung infections including pneumonia, tuberculosis, ALRI

* Stroke

* Ischemic heart disease

* COPD

* Lung, laryngeal, nasopharyngeal cancers

* Pregnancy problems like low birth weight

Indicators of air pollution:

* Sulfur dioxide - one of the best indicator of air pollution

* Smoke or soiling index: A known volume of air is filtered through a white filter paper under specified conditions and the stain is measured by a photoelectric meter

* Grit and dust measurement 

* The co-efficient of haze - assessment of the amount of smoke or other aerosols in the air

* Air pollution index - measure of pollution severity

* Suspended particle matter (SPM) 

In India, National Air Quality Programme sponsored by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) is the main mode of monitoring air pollution.

questions.text: 22. A patient with benign intracranial hypertension presented with right abducent nerve palsy. Which of the following statements about this condition are true?

choices.text: Right eye moves inwards on cover test
Deviation is constant in all directions of gaze

questions.solution:
In right abducent palsy, there will be a paralytic squint of the right eye, and the forced duction test will be negative.

The abducens nerve is the most commonly involved nerve in benign intracranial hypertension caused by increased intracranial pressure. On examination of the patient, the following will be noted:

When the patient tries to look to the right, the left eye's medial rectus functions normally, so it turns inward as expected. However, the right eye’s lateral rectus is paralyzed due to abducent nerve palsy, so it cannot turn outward. As a result, the right eye fails to follow the movement and remains near the primary position, but because of the unopposed action of the medial rectus, it is slightly turned inward, causing esotropia in the primary gaze.

During the cover test, when the normal (left) eye is covered, the brain shifts fixation to the affected (right) eye. Since the right eye was already deviated inward at rest, it must now move outward to look directly at the target. This shows that the direction of deviation is opposite to the direction of movement - a classic finding in esotropia. (Option C)

As discussed above, the right eye will be in esotropia due to loss of function of the right lateral rectus muscle. As the patient has esotropia, there will be uncrossed diplopia, not crossed. (Option A) Crossed diplopia is seen in exotropia. The head will turn towards the right to compensate for the loss of function of the right lateral rectus.

The given image demonstrates a schematic illustration of Right abducens palsy:



The deviation is not the same in all directions of gaze. (Option D) Paralytic squint is a type of incomitant squint, where the magnitude of the squint varies with eye position.

The forced duction test is negative. (Option B) A forced duction test is used to differentiate between the two main etiological conditions causing incomitant squint- paralytic and restrictive squint. In this test, the eyeball is passively rotated using forceps in the direction in which the movement of the eye is hampered.

The inability to do this implies restrictive squint (due to restriction of muscle movement) and the test is said to be positive. In paralytic squint, the eyeball can be passively moved in the paralyzed muscle's direction of action and the test is said to be negative.

Benign intracranial hypertension/pseudotumor cerebri/idiopathic intracranial hypertension(IIH) is an idiopathic elevation of the intracranial pressure with no identifiable obstructive cause. It is famously recognized as a complication of Hypervitaminosis A. Other suspected causes of secondary IIH include tetracycline toxicity, dural sinus thrombosis, etc

Ocular findings include papilledema, abducens nerve palsy, neuroimaging showing flattening of the posterior aspect of the globe, tortuous optic nerve, etc.

Pearl PM1016: Cover tests in ophthalmology

Cover–uncover test:

* To detect the presence of heterophoria: Latent squint

* One eye is covered with the occluder, and the other eye is made to fix an object.

* In the presence of heterophoria, the eye under the cover will deviate.

* When the cover is removed, the eye under the cover will return back to its normal.

* This movement is observed.

* The direction of movement determines the type of heterophoria.



Direct Cover test:

* Confirms the presence of manifest squint.

* Differentiates apparent squint from a manifest squint.

* The patient is asked to fixate on the point light.

* The normal-looking eye is covered.

* In manifest squint, the uncovered eye will move in the opposite direction to take fixation.

* In apparent squint, there will be no movement of the uncovered eye.



Alternate cover test:

* In the below image, the patient has right exotropia with left eye fixating.

* Both eyes move each time the cover alternates from one eye to the other.

* It reveals if the squint is unilateral or alternate.

* It differentiates between concomitant and paralytic squint.



Pearl PM1015: Classification of Strabismus

* Pseudostrabismus—Apparent squint

* Pseudo esotropia

* Pseduo exotropia

* Heterophoria—Latent squint

* Esophoria: Convergent

* Exophoria: Divergent

* Hyperphoria: Deviation upwards

* Hypophoria: Deviation downwards

* Cyclophoria: Rotation around AP axis

* Heterotropia—Manifest squint

* Concomitant

* Amount of deviation remains constant in all directions of gaze.

* Esotropia: Convergent

* Infantile

* Accommodative

* Sensory

* Consecutive

* Exotropia: Divergent

* Congenital

* Primary

* Secondary: Sensory deprived

* Consecutive

* Hypertropia: Vertical squint

* Incomitant

* Amount of deviation varies in different directions of gaze

* Paralytic squint

* Restrictive squint

* A and V pattern heterotropia

questions.text: 23. An athlete slipped off the pavement while running and twisted his right ankle. He could not walk properly and developed swelling in the right ankle region. What is the most probable ligament injured?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests an ankle sprain. The most probable ligament injured is the anterior talofibular ligament (marked as 1).

Ankle sprains are common in pedestrians and country walkers who stumble on stairways, pavements, and potholes. In the majority of the cases, it is the lateral ligament complex that is injured, in particular the anterior talofibular followed by the calcaneofibular ligaments(marked as 2). Medial ligament injuries are usually associated with a fracture or joint injury.

The anterior talo-fibular ligament (ATFL) during plantarflexion, changes its orientation from horizontal to vertical with respect to the floor. Thus the ligament gets stretched and vulnerable to injury. On slipping off a pavement or into a pothole the foot gets plantar-flexed and inverted predisposing the ATFL to injury.

The lateral collateral ligaments consist of the anterior talofibular, the posterior talofibular, and (between them) the calcaneofibular ligaments. The calcaneofibular ligament runs from the tip of the lateral malleolus to the posterolateral part of the calcaneum and, therefore helps to stabilize the subtalar joint. The posterior talofibular ligament runs from the posterior border of the lateral malleolus to the posterior part of the talus.

The medial collateral (deltoid) ligament consists of superficial and deep portions. The superficial fibers spread like a fan from the medial malleolus anteriorly to the navicular and inferiorly to the calcaneum and talus. Its chief function is to resist the eversion of the hindfoot. 

The deep portion is intra-articular, running directly from the medial malleolus to the medial surface of the talus. Its principal effect is to prevent external rotation of the talus. The deltoid ligament is the major stabilizer of the ankle joint.



Management of ankle sprains includes protection (crutches, splints, or braces), rest, ice, compression, elevation, and rehabilitation (summarized as PRICER). Analgesics such as NSAIDs can be used topically as a gel or in oral formulations for pain relief.

Markings 3 and 4 are anterior inferior tibiofibular and posterior inferior tibiofibular ligaments respectively.

questions.text: 24. A 62-year-old man with a long-standing history of COPD presents with increasing shortness of breath. On examination, paradoxical inward movement of the lower lateral chest during inspiration is noted. Which of the following signs does this finding represent?
questions.solution:
The paradoxical inward movement of the lower lateral rib cage during inspiration is known as Hoover’s sign. This physical sign is often observed in patients with severe COPD. and reflects the severity of airflow obstruction.

Patients with COPD may show signs of active smoking, like nicotine-stained fingers or a smoky odour. Lung examination often reveals a prolonged expiratory phase and expiratory wheezing.

Patients with severe airflow obstruction may also exhibit sitting in the characteristic tripod position due to the use of accessory muscles of respiration, to facilitate the actions of the sternocleidomastoid, scalene, and intercostal muscles. Patients may develop cyanosis, visible in the lips and nail beds.  In advanced stages, patients can also present with cachexia, significant weight loss and diffuse loss of subcutaneous adipose tissue.

Other options:

Option A: Hamman’s sign is a crunching, rasping sound synchronous with the heartbeat, heard in cases of mediastinal emphysema.

Option C: Carvallo’s sign refers to a murmur heard in tricuspid regurgitation which increases in intensity with inspiration.

Option D: Tripod sign is a posture adopted by patients in respiratory distress, where they lean forward and support themselves with their hands on their knees to optimise breathing.

questions.text: 25. A 65-year-old male with a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is diagnosed with chronic urinary retention. After catheterisation, the patient develops postobstructive diuresis, producing more than 200 ml of urine per hour for three consecutive hours. The patient has intact cognition. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Remove the catheter and initiate intravenous fluid resuscitation
Monitor the patient’s fluid balance, postural blood pressure, and electrolytes
Administer desmopressin to reduce urinary losses
Reduce oral fluid intake to prevent fluid overload

questions.solution:
The given scenario points towards postobstructive diuresis and the most appropriate management is to monitor the patient’s fluid balance, postural blood pressure, and electrolytes.

Postobstructive diuresis is a condition where patients excrete more than 200 mL of urine per hour for three consecutive hours after the relief of chronic urinary retention. This occurs due to the elimination of accumulated solutes and excess fluid after obstruction is relieved.

The management of postobstructive diuresis includes strict fluid balance monitoring, postural blood pressure checks to detect postural hypotension and daily serum electrolyte monitoring. Intravenous fluid replacement may be needed if the patient is unable to take enough fluids orally.

Other options:

Option A: Administering intravenous fluids indiscriminately, especially in patients with normal mental status, may prolong the postobstructive diuresis and is not recommended.

Option C: Desmopressin is used to treat conditions like diabetes insipidus or nocturnal enuresis by reducing urine output. It is not indicated for postobstructive diuresis. 

Option D: The patient should be given free access to oral fluids if there are no signs of fluid overload or impaired renal function. Fluid overload should be prevented but this is managed by careful monitoring rather than reducing oral intake unnecessarily.

questions.text: 26. A 17-year-old girl with a history of anorexia nervosa is admitted for severe malnutrition. Her BMI is 15 kg/m². On day 2 of nutritional rehabilitation, she develops confusion, muscle weakness, and tachycardia. What could have prevented the development of her symptoms?

choices.text: Starting nutritional support at 20 kcal/kg per day
Ensuring maximum caloric repletion in the first two days
Replenishing vitamins and electrolytes before starting feeds

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests refeeding syndrome. Replenishing vitamins, especially vitamin B1 and electrolytes, before nutritional rehabilitation would have prevented her symptoms.

Thiamine is essential for glucose metabolism (it prevents Wernicke's encephalopathy), and correcting low phosphate, potassium, and magnesium is key before proceeding with nutritional rehabilitation. The key is to always correct deficiencies before increasing calories.

In starvation, the body adapts to low insulin, uses fat for energy, and conserves electrolytes. When feeding is restarted, especially with carbohydrates, there is a spike in insulin level, which drives phosphate, potassium, and magnesium into cells. Due to long-term decreased oral intake, there will also be vitamin deficiencies that need to be addressed. 

Other options:

Option A: Nutritional support is to be started at a maximum of 10 kcal/kg per day, and gradually increased. 

Option B: Caloric repletion is to be done slowly, and levels are increased slowly to meet full body needs by 4–7 days.

Option C: Starting total parenteral nutrition would worsen refeeding syndrome, as it is very high in carbohydrates.

questions.text: 27. An autopsy is being conducted on a person who was diagnosed with normal pressure hydrocephalus. An axial dissection of the brain reveals enlargement of the lateral ventricles. The enlarged anterior horn of the lateral ventricle causes compression of which of the following structures laterally?
questions.solution:
The lateral relation of the anterior horn of the lateral ventricle is the caudate nucleus. Enlargement of the anterior horn of the lateral ventricle causes compression of the caudate nucleus laterally.

The clinical symptoms of normal-pressure hydrocephalus are characteristic of the classic triad of cognitive dysfunction, urinary symptoms, and a wide-based gait (wet, wacky, and wobbly). Additionally, depressed affect and UMN signs in lower limbs may be seen.

The diagnosis is established by a CT that shows a marked enlargement of ventricles and the Miller Fisher test that shows improvement in gait following a lumbar tap. Treatment generally involves ventriculoperitoneal shunting.

The lateral ventricle can be divided into the body and 3 horns—anterior, posterior, and inferior.

The locations of the parts: 

* Body: Frontal and parietal lobe

* Anterior horn: Frontal lobe

* Posterior horn: Occipital lobe

* Inferior horn: Temporal lobe



Anterior horn:

Extent: from the genu of the corpus callosum till the interventricular foramen

Relations: 

* Anteriorly: Genu and rostrum of the corpus callosum

* Roof: Anterior part of the body of the corpus callosum 

* Floor and lateral wall: Caudate nucleus

* Medial wall: Septum pellucidum and anterior column of fornix

Body or Central part:

Extent: from the interventricular foramen till the splenium of the corpus callosum

Relations:

* Roof: Body of the corpus callosum

* Medial wall: Septum pellucidum 

* Floor (from lateral to medial): Caudate nucleus, stria terminalis, thalamostriate vein, thalamus, choroid plexus, and body of the fornix

Posterior horn: 

Extent: from the splenium till the occipital pole

Relations:

* Roof and lateral wall: tapetum of corpus callosum

* Medial wall: Forceps major and calcar avis (calcarine sulcus)

Inferior horn: the largest compartment

Extent: till 2.5 cm from the temporal pole

Relations:

* Roof: tapetum of corpus callosum and tail of caudate nucleus

* Floor (lateral to medial): Collateral eminence (produced by collateral fissure, hippocampus)



Note: There is no lateral wall for the lateral ventricle.

questions.text: 28. A patient from a remote rural village presented with a sudden onset of high-grade fever followed by altered mental status and seizures, and was diagnosed with acute encephalitis. This was followed by multiple similar cases from the same area, which prompted a thorough epidemiological investigation of the outbreak. The medical officers identified sandflies as one of the prominent vectors transmitting the disease. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a patient from a rural household presenting with high-grade fever of sudden onset, followed by localising signs in the CNS, and diagnosed with acute encephalitis. The vector for this outbreak is found to be a sandfly, confirming the diagnosis as the new, emerging viral illness named Chandipura encephalitis.

Chandipura encephalitis is caused by Chandipura virus, a Rhabdovirus that causes encephalitis and is an emerging viral pathogen in tropical countries like India. The last major outbreak was in 2024, the largest in 20 years, with over 240 cases concentrated in and around western, central, and southern parts of India. 

It is an arbovirus with multiple known vectors transmitting the virus, most notably among them being:

* Sandflies of the genus Phlebotomus and Sergentomyia.

* Mosquitoes of the genus Aedes species aegypti

The major non-human host for Chandipura virus is the Hedgehog, which is a type of mammal belonging to the same family as shrews and moles. Outbreaks typically occur in the monsoon.

In humans, the disease commences as an influenza-like illness with nausea, vomiting, headache, myalgia, high fever, and abdominal pain. The influenza phase is followed by a plethora of neurological manifestations such as altered sensorium and seizures, culminating in infection-associated or autoimmune-mediated encephalitis, which has a high mortality rate in children. 

Diagnosis is confirmed by ELISA or RT-PCR, and treatment is symptomatic management of the encephalitis until it abates. There is no vaccine. The disease is an emerging pathogen of great interest due to frequent outbreaks in India which are of acute onset with high case fatality among children. It forms an important differential diagnosis of acute encephalitis syndrome.

Below is an image of Phlebotomus papatasii, the vector for Chandipura virus, after completing a blood meal.



Other Options:

Option A: Nipah virus encephalitis is caused by Nipah virus, which is a zoonotic illness. The reservoir is fruit bats and is transmitted to humans via pigs, which serve as an intermediate host, or from contaminated fruit. The clinical picture is similar to Chandipura encephalitis, presenting with influenza-like illness, which progresses to encephalitis with a high mortality rate. Zoonotic transmission of Nipah virus is shown below:



Option C: Lymphocytic choriomeningitis (LCM) is caused by lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus, an Arenavirus, and is a zoonotic disease transmitted to humans via contact with aerosols of excreta or secretions of common house mice( Mus musculus). It can occur in immunology laboratories as it is frequently used for testing T-cell function.

In patients with aseptic meningitis, LCM is suspected when there is a well-marked febrile prodromal phase in adults, occurrence in autumn, hypoglycorrhachia, and most importantly, CSF mononuclear counts >1000 per microliter.

Option D: Kyasanur forest disease is an arboviral hemorrhagic fever caused by a Flavivirus and first identified in the forests of Karnataka. It is believed to be transmitted by the hard tick Haemaphysalis. Monkeys are amplifier hosts. The disease presents as a viral hemorrhagic fever. An inactivated vaccine has been developed against the disease.



Pearl PM1731: Arthropod- borne diseases

Arthropod | Disease transmitted Anopheles mosquito | Malaria, Filariasis Culex mosquito | Bancroftian filariasis, Japenese encephalitis, West nile fever, Viral arthritis Aedes mosquito | Yellow fever, Dengue, Chikungunya, filariasis, zika Mansoni Mosquito | Filariasis, Chikungunya Housefly | Typhoid and paratyphoid fever, diarrhea, dysentery, cholera, gastroenteritis, amoebiasis, helminthic infestations, poliomyelitis, conjunctivitis, trachoma, anthrax, yaws, etc. Sandfly (Phlebotomus) | Kala-azar(Visceral Leishmaniasis), oriental sore, Oroya fever, Sandfly fever Tsetse fly | Sleeping sickness(African Trypanosomiasis) Louse | Epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, pediculosis Rat flea | Bubonic plague, endemic typhus(Murine Typhus), hymenolepis diminuta Black fly(Simulium) | Onchocerciasis Reduviid bug(Kissing bug/triatominae) | Chagas disease(American Trypanosomiasis) Hard tick (Ixodes species) | Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, viral hemorrhagic fever,(e.g. Kyasanur forest disease), tularemia, tick paralysis, human babesiosis, lyme disease Soft Tick (Argas species) | Q fever, relapsing fever, Kyasanur forest disease (KFD) (can be casued by hard tick as well) Trombiculid mite | Scrub typhus, Rickettsial pox Itch mites | Scabies Cyclops | Guinea-worm disease, fish tapeworm (D. latum) Cockroaches | Enteric pathogens Sand flea (Tunga penetrance, Jiggar, Chigoe flea) | Tungiasis, Ulcer in the feetnails

Pearl PM1676: Sandfly

* They are also referred to as Phlebotomus.

* They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), Oriental sore, sandfly fever, and Oroya fever.

* They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.

* They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during the night (nocturnal pests).

* They do not fly for more than 50 yards.

* They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

questions.text: 29. A 20-year-old obese male is brought to the emergency department with diabetic ketoacidosis. He reports no history of taking oral hypoglycemic medications or insulin. He has no personal history or family history of autoimmune disease. Genetic studies are normal for the HNF-1β and GCK genes. He tests negative for the antibodies. What is the most probable diagnosis?

choices.text: Maturity-onset diabetes of the young type 5
Maturity-onset diabetes of the young type 2

questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis of the given patient with diabetic ketoacidosis, with an absence of autoimmunity, suggests Ketosis-prone type 2 diabetes mellitus, also known as Flatbush syndrome.

Individuals with Ketosis-prone type 2 diabetes mellitus present with diabetic ketoacidosis but lack autoimmune markers. It is commonly seen in African, African American, and Hispanic populations. 

Some patients with type 2 diabetes present acutely with marked osmotic symptoms and weight loss. These patients usually present late after developing β-cell failure or minimal functioning of β-cells. Patients often crave sugar and consume large volumes of sugary drinks to try to quench their thirst as hyperglycaemia worsens. 

Illness, like infections, increases the production of stress hormones such as cortisol, growth hormone and catecholamines that oppose insulin action. This can also precipitate an acute exacerbation of insulin resistance and insulin deficiency, resulting in more severe hyperglycaemia and dehydration.

This worsening hyperglycaemia leads to increased lipolysis, high circulating glucose and free fatty acids that are toxic to the β cell, resulting in ‘glucolipotoxicity’ and reduced β-cell function, leading to diabetic ketoacidosis. Insulin treatment is required initially, but the β cells recover as the glucose and lipids are controlled. They respond well to oral hypoglycemic agents like metformin, which can be started after 3 months of insulin treatment.

Other options:

Option B: Type 1 diabetes mellitus presents at younger ages and is characterised by the presence of antibodies.

Option C: Maturity-onset diabetes of the young type 5 is an autosomal dominant monogenic form of diabetes that usually presents within 25 years and sometimes in the neonatal period with renal cysts and genital anomalies due to a mutation in HNF-1β.

Option D: Maturity-onset diabetes of the young type 2 is an autosomal dominant monogenic form of diabetes that usually presents within 25 years and sometimes in the neonatal period due to a mutation of GCK gene.

questions.text: 30. A G2P1L1 woman with a previous history of preterm delivery presents at 32 weeks with intermittent uterine contractions. To allow for fetal lung maturity, what is the dose of betamethasone to be given?
questions.solution:
To allow for fetal lung maturity, the dose of betamethasone to be given is 12mg IM 24 hourly 2 doses.

Antenatal corticosteroids are recommended in a pregnancy less than 34 weeks to allow fetal lung maturation and to reduce the incidence of respiratory distress syndrome(RDS), intraventricular hemorrhage(IVH), and necrotizing enterocolitis(NEC). 

Betamethasone is the steroid of choice and it becomes useful if the delivery is delayed beyond 48 hours of the first dose with the effect lasting for about 18 days. Dexamethasone is another steroid that can be given in a dose of 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses IM.  

Short-term therapy with tocolytics is given in conjunction with steroids for 1-3 days to delay labour for at least 48 hours or to transfer the patient to a tertiary centre (with NICU). The drugs include terbutaline, indomethacin, nifedipine, and atosiban. Contraindications to tocolysis include chorioamnionitis, preeclampsia/eclampsia, fetal distress, pregnancy >34 weeks, active labor, and placental abruption.

Preterm labour is the onset of labour before 37 completed weeks of pregnancy (less than 259 days of gestation). It can occur in patients with a history of prior preterm birth, multiple pregnancies and genital tract infection. Evaluation of cervical anatomy is the most important step in women with a history of preterm labour to look for cervical incompetence. 

Features of preterm labour include regular uterine contractions at least once every 10 minutes, with/without pain, cervical dilatation >2 cm and effacement >80% and length of cervix <2.5 cm and funnelling of the internal os >1 cm.

The best predictors of preterm labor in a woman with a previous history of preterm birth are fetal fibronectin >50ng/ml and cervical length <2.5cm on transvaginal ultrasound.

Pearl PM2438: Tocolytic agents

Drugs | Examples Calcium channel blockers | Nifedipine Nicardipine Verapamil Competitive inhibition to calcium ion | Magnesium sulfate Cyclo-oxygenase inhibitors | Indomethacin Sulindac Beta mimetics | Terbutaline Ritodrine Isoxsuprine Oxytocin Antagonists | Atosiban Nitric oxide (NO) Donors | Glyceryl trinitrate (GTN)

questions.text: 31. An unbooked woman at term in labor underwent an obstetric examination. The first Leopold maneuver revealed a smooth, hard, globular, independently ballotable structure and the fourth Leopold maneuver revealed a broad, soft, irregular mass. Bedside USG revealed that the fetal neck was in a hyperextended position. What is the ideal management of this condition?

choices.text: Allow labour to progress and deliver vaginally
Administer tocolytics and plan for elective LSCS
Take to OT and attempt internal podalic version

questions.solution:
When a case of hyperextended neck in breech position is identified in labor, the patient must be taken up for emergency LSCS.

The given clinical scenario describes a woman at term arriving in labor and undergoing an obstetrical examination. The first Leopold maneuver or fundal grip identified a smooth, hard, globular, independently ballotable structure which is synonymous with the cephalic end/head. The fourth Leopold maneuver revealed a broad, soft, irregular mass consistent with the breech. Hence, the breech was the presenting part. 

Next, an antenatal bedside USG was performed, which additionally identified a key finding: the neck was in a hyperextended position. A breech baby presenting with a hyperextended neck is called a star-gazer breech baby. If such a pregnancy is allowed to progress to normal vaginal delivery, the hyperextended neck will undergo cervical spinal injuries during parturition and thus, normal delivery is avoided.

If a stargazer breech presents in labor, the ideal management is to urgently prepare the patient for surgery and take up the patient for emergency LSCS which ensures the best outcome for the fetus. Normally, breech presentation presenting in labor or otherwise must be evaluated before allowing or planning for normal delivery. The following are indications for a cesarean section in a breech presentation:

* Big baby/Postterm

* Small baby/Preterm 

* Hyperextension of neck(Star-gazer breech)

* Footling presentation due to high risk of cord prolapse

* Suspected contracted pelvis or protracted active phase/CPD

* Knee presentation

* Previous C-section

* Twin pregnancy with the first twin in breech

* Any medical complications in the mother (PIH, GDM, etc)

* Breech score less than or equal to 3

* Any fetal congenital anomalies

Even in a normal delivery, no induction or augmentation of malpresented babies in labour is indicated; rather, a natural progression of labor is encouraged and any complication is managed by converting to LSCS. Below are various maneuvers to facilitate normal delivery in breech summarised in a pearl.

Other options:

Option C: Since the woman is already in labour, there is no role for tocolytics and to plan for elective LSCS. Rather, it is converted to emergency LSCS. 

Option D: Internal podalic version followed by breech extraction under GA or breech delivery is done when the second twin is found to be in transverse lie.

Given below are images of various breech positions and the Leopold maneuvers:





Pearl PM1839: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

* Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa

* Catch hold of the ankle

* Pull down along with abduction



Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

* Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.

* Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.

* Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 



Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

* Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.

* Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.



Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

* Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.

* When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.

* Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.



Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

* Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.

* Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.

* Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.

* Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.

* Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.



Mnemonic:

* Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)

* Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: 32. You are a part of a water purification program, where you are explaining chlorine as a disinfectant. Which among the following is the most effective form of chlorine for water disinfection?
questions.solution:
Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine for water disinfection.

Action of chlorine:

When chlorine is added to water, there is the formation of hydrochloric acid (HCl) and hypochlorous acids (HOCl), as follows.

H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl

The hydrochloric acid is neutralized by the alkalinity of the water.

The hypochlorous acid (HOCl) ionizes to form hydrogen ions (H+) and hypochlorite ions (OCl-), as follows:

HOCl → H+ + OCl-

The disinfecting action of chlorine is mainly due to hypochlorous acid, which is 70-80 times more effective than the hypochlorite ions.

The formation of hypochlorous acid is predominant, when the pH of the water is around 7. If the pH exceeds 8.5, chlorine is unreliable as a disinfectant, as about 90% of the hypochlorous acid that is formed gets ionized to hypochlorite ions.

Most waters have a pH between 6 to 7.5.

Pearl PM1598: Chlorination of Water

* Chlorination is widely used for the large-scale purification of drinking water.

* It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.

* It oxidizes iron, manganese, and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odour producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.

* The action of chlorine:

* Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.

* H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl HOCl → H + OCl

* The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.

* Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.

* Principles of chlorination:

* The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.

* The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.

* The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.

* Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.

*  Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.

* The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.

* Methods of chlorination:

* Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action, and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for the application of chlorine gas.

* Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.

* Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.

* Break point chlorination:

* The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.

* Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.

* In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines would have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.

* This corresponding dosage to achieve the appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.

* It is also called controlled superchlorination

* Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.

* Orthotolidine (OT) test:

* It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.

* The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in a 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.

* When added to water that contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorine.

* Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:

* This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.

* It determines free and combined chlorine separately.

Pearl PM1610: Horrock’s Apparatus

* Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.

* This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.

* Contents of this water-testing apparatus:

* 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark

* 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)

* 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette

* Two droppers

* Starch-iodide indicator solution

* Procedure:

* Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.

* The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested

* Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.

* Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.

* Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup

* Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 

* The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.

* Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.text: 33. A 60-year-old man comes to the outpatient department with a complaint of worsening pain in his right buttock and right thigh, especially at night. X-ray reveal central lytic bone lesions with popcorn calcification. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with worsening pain in the hip and thigh and osteolytic lesions with popcorn calcification is likely to have chondrosarcoma.

Chondrosarcoma is the second most common malignant matrix-producing bone tumour after osteosarcoma. It typically affects the pelvis, proximal femur, or humerus of individuals aged 40-70 years. It is an aggressive, slow-growing, malignant cartilaginous tumour, and men are affected more commonly than women. The patient presents with progressively worsening pain and tenderness.

X-ray reveals osteolytic lesions and popcorn calcification or ring and arc calcification. Biopsy typically reveals cartilaginous growth with a lobulated appearance. It has the best prognosis among malignant bone tumours. It is radio- and chemo-resistant. Treatment is surgery.



Other options:

Option A: Ewing sarcoma has an onion-peel appearance on X-ray due to an aggressive periosteal reaction. It typically occurs before the age of 30 years and affects diaphyses of long bones more commonly.



Option B: Osteoclastoma has a soap bubble appearance on X-ray and typically affects individuals 20-40 years of age. Axial skeleton involvement is not common.



Option C: Osteochondroma appears as a small bony protrusion at metaphysis on X-ray. They are benign and rarely transform into chondrosarcomas.
