questions.text: 34. A middle-aged woman presents with right wrist pain. She says that the pain aggravates while working and improves with rest. On examination, there is local tenderness in the area of the dorsal radial styloid. There is no limitation of motion, but the ulnar deviation is very painful. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of De Quervain's disease.

De Quervain's disease is a stenosing tenosynovitis of the extensor tendons of the first dorsal compartment, namely extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) and abductor pollicis longus (APL). It is the non-inflammatory thickening of the tendons and the sheath through which they traverse. This condition is prominent among females, especially women of childbearing age.

Key diagnostic factors:

* History of joint overuse at home or at work.

* Pain and tenderness at the tip of radial styloid.

* Positive Finkelstein test

Finkelstein's test - The examiner grasps the thumb of the patient and turns the hand towards the ulnar side. This causes severe pain over the tip of the styloid process. It is positive in the following conditions:

* De Quervain's disease (tenosynovitis)

* Arthritis in the intercarpal and radiocarpal joints

* Superficial radial nerve entrapment 

* Intersection syndrome i.e. tenosynovitis occurs due to friction between the obliquely placed extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis tendons and the longitudinally placed extensor tendons.



Treatment of De Quervain's disease includes conservative management in the majority of the patients with steroid injection. Only a few require surgical release of the 1st dorsal compartment (housing the APL and EPB tendons).

Other options:

The site of pain and tenderness can be diagnostic Condition | Site of pain Kienböck’s disease | Over the lunate Scaphoid fracture | Anatomical snuffbox Carpometacarpal osteoarthritis | The base of the first metacarpal

Note: Kienböck’s disease is the traumatic softening of the lunate bone. This condition is characterized by ischemic necrosis which may be due to chronic stress or injury.

questions.text: 35. A 30-year-old woman presents with a right-sided blurring of vision for 3 months. The blurring is more for near vision and is not progressive. The right pupil is larger than the left and doesn’t react to light. On applying 0.1% pilocarpine, the right pupil becomes smaller than the left. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features suggest a diagnosis of Adie’s tonic pupil.

This condition is usually unilateral and is caused by damage to the postganglionic parasympathetic neurons supplying the pupillary sphincter. The following findings are seen in the affected eye:

* The affected pupil is larger and doesn’t react to light.

* On applying a weak solution of pilocarpine (0.1%), the affected pupil becomes smaller than the other pupil due to denervation supersensitivity.

* The affected pupil constricts very slowly on testing the near reflex due to aberrant innervation of the pupillary sphincter by ciliary muscle nerve fibres.

It is more common in young women, and its aetiology is uncertain. It may follow a viral illness. Absent knee jerk on the same side may be associated with this condition, in which case it is known as Holmes-Adie Syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Argyll Robertson pupil occurs due to a dorsal midbrain lesion that interrupts the pupillary light reflex pathway but spares the more ventral pupillary near reflex pathway, leading to light–near dissociation. In dim light, both pupils are small and may be irregular. In bright light, neither pupil constricts, but on accommodation (near object), both constrict. After instillation of pilocarpine 0.1% into both eyes, pupils do not constrict.

Option B: Marcus Gunn pupil is a relative pupillary defect caused by an incomplete optic nerve lesion or severe retinal disease. The relative pupillary defect can be seen on the swinging flashlight test.

Option D: The Hutchinson pupil is characterised by initial ipsilateral miosis followed by dilatation with no light reflex. It occurs due to raised intracranial pressure.

questions.text: 37. Which of the following immunoglobulin levels are decreased in Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome?
questions.solution:
Serum IgM levels are decreased in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. However, IgG is usually normal and paradoxically IgA and IgE are often elevated.

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS) is an X-linked recessive immunodeficiency disorder. It is caused by mutations in the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASp) that primarily affects the T lymphocytes. Normally, WASp regulates the actin cytoskeleton and thus helps in cell adhesion, migration, and the formation of synapses between antigen-presenting and target cells. In WAS, there is a progressive loss of T lymphocytes in the peripheral blood resulting in defects in cellular immunity. 

The clinical features of WAS are recurrent bacterial infections, eczema, and bleeding due to thrombocytopenia. Diagnosis is based on intracellular immunofluorescence analysis of WAS protein (WASp) expression in blood cells. IgM levels in the serum are low, but levels of IgG are usually normal. Ig A and Ig E levels are high. Reduced-sized platelet is a typical feature of WAS. 

The image given below shows eczema seen in WAS.

questions.text: 38. A middle-aged chronic smoker has recently been discharged from the hospital after being admitted for an acute exacerbation of chronic bronchitis. He is now motivated to quit smoking and wants to know about medications that will help him with quitting. All of the following can be used in him, except ______.
questions.solution:
Mirtazapine is not used in smoking cessation.

Mirtazapine is a serotonin receptor antagonist, used in the treatment of major depression.

Pharmacological methods to quit smoking:

1. Nicotine replacement therapy - is highly effective, because it reduces withdrawal symptoms. It is available as - 

* Nicotine gum - available over the counter and releases nicotine via buccal absorption. One to two pieces of gum per hour up to a maximum of 24 pieces per day can be used

* Nicotine lozenges - useful for patients who smoke a cigarette immediately on awakening

* Nicotine patches - administered every morning and produce blood concentrations of nicotine about half those of smoking

* Nicotine nasal spray - available only by prescription, produces nicotine concentrations in the blood comparable to smoking a cigarette and is helpful for heavily dependent smokers However, adverse effects like rhinitis, watering eyes, and coughing are experienced by most patients

* Nicotine inhalers deliver 4 mg per cartridge and resultant nicotine levels are low

2. Non-nicotine medications:

1st line:

* Bupropion - both dopaminergic and adrenergic actions. 

* Varenicline - a partial agonist for nicotinic Ach receptor. Side effects include sleep disturbances, depression, and increased suicidal tendencies.

2nd line:

* Nortriptyline - tricyclic antidepressant which appears to be effective for smoking cessation.

* Clonidine - alpha-agonist which decreases sympathetic activity and thus decreases withdrawal symptoms.

It is recommended to offer nicotine patches or varenicline along with counselling and behavior therapy as a part of the cessation attempt. Acute exacerbations of chronic bronchitis are valuable "teachable moments" for the patient and can help reaffirm the smoking cessation message serving as a springboard for a cessation attempt.

questions.text: 39. A patient with ARDS in the ICU is on a ventilator with volume-controlled settings. According to current management guidelines for ARDS, which should not be done in the management?

choices.text: Keep the lowest FiO₂ targeting SpO₂ 88–95%
Keep the goal tidal volume at 6mL/kg predicted body weight
Keep the goal plateau pressure > 30 cm H2O
Keep the PEEP at 5 cm H2O

questions.solution:
A plateau pressure ≤ 30 cm H2O is recommended for lung-protective ventilation in ARDS. Low plateau pressure helps to prevent barotrauma. So, the incorrect step in management is to keep the goal plateau pressure > 30 cm H2O. 

Components of the lung protective ventilation in ARDS are:

* Low tidal volumes (6 ml/kg) to initiate volume-limited ventilation

* FiO₂ ≤0.6 and SpO2 88–95% to prevent oxygen toxicity

* PEEP at 5 cm H2O  to improve arterial oxygenation

* Plateau pressure ≤ 30 cm H2O to prevent barotrauma

All these measures reduce mortality.

questions.text: 40. A patient on ATT presented with a focal neurological deficit of the upper limb, which resolved after a few hours. He said his symptoms began with flashes of light and profuse sweating. This was followed by sudden, involuntary movements starting from his fingers and spreading to his entire upper limb, lasting a few seconds. This episode was followed by paresis of the upper limb. What is the most likely condition experienced by the patient?
questions.solution:
Todd's paresis is the most likely condition experienced by the patient based on the clinical features given.

The scenario given refers to a patient taking ATT and presenting with flashes of light and profuse sweating followed by sudden involuntary movements starting from the fingers and progressing to involve the rest of the upper limb. This is followed by a paresis that resolves in a few hours. This picture is consistent with a focal seizure which spreads in the form of jacksonian march and followed by Todd's paresis.

Focal seizure is a type of seizure limited to one area of the brain. It may undergo secondary generalization but begins from one focus in the brain. It can be divided into focal seizures with impaired awareness and intact awareness. Focal seizures show up as epileptiform spikes in a background of normal activity. 

In the beginning, changes in somatic sensations such as paraesthesias, visual symptoms like hallucinations and flashes of light, dysequilibrium, and autonomic symptoms like flushing, sweating, and piloerection may herald the start of a focal seizure. Lesions in the temporal and frontal lobes can manifest with olfactory and auditory phenomena and bizarre sensations termed auras.

In focal seizures with intact awareness, as in this case, show motor symptoms, often in a sequential fashion known as Jacksonian march where the motor symptoms are initially restricted to a small area, say fingers, and then spread to include more muscle groups. This indicates the spread of seizure activity to adjacent brain areas.

Another distinguishing feature is Todd's paresis, which is a transient, localized paresis for minutes to hours following the seizure episode which usually spontaneously resolves with no residual deficit. It is an important stroke-mimic. The seizure is also known to continue for days and is often refractory to medical treatment, a condition known as epilepsia partialis continua. 

Treatment involves the identification of the focus responsible for the seizure activity and its specific management along with antiepileptic drugs. In this case, the patient is taking ATT, hence he may have a tuberculoma in the brain and requires imaging to rule it out. Other common intracranial space-occupying lesions causing focal seizures are neurocysticercosis, malignancies etc

First line drugs for focal seizure include carbamazepine, lamotrigine,oxcarbazepine, eslicarbazepine,phenytoin and levitiracetam.

Other Options:

Option A: Hemiplegic migraine is also a stroke mimic causing temporary paresis but typical Jacksonian muscle march is not seen there. This condition is often familial.

Option B: Cataplectic attacks are seen in narcolepsy where any sudden emotional outbursts such as laughing or crying result in sudden loss of muscle tone resulting in the patient collapsing to the ground. Consciousness is retained and the patient recovers in seconds to a few minutes.

Option C: Clumsy hand type of lacunar stroke is a lacunar stroke syndrome, properly termed " Clumsy hand-dysarthria" syndrome where a lacunar infarct results in dysarthria and clumsiness of the hand or arm. The lesion is believed to be in the genu or ventral pons. It does not present with flashes of light or Jacksonian march and is not reversible in hours.

questions.text: 41. A 10-year-old child was brought to the OPD with complaints of multiple motor and vocal tics for the past 18 months. His mother informed that sometimes the child would also utter socially unacceptable words suddenly during a conversation. The tics increased and decreased in frequency during this period. The child has normal social and academic skills. How do you manage?

choices.text: Psychoeducation with wait and watch strategy
Botulinum toxin injection to decrease tic severity

questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of Tourette's syndrome. In mild cases, which do not affect the academic or social life, the first-line of management, is to provide psychoeducation and follow a watch and wait strategy.

Tourette's syndrome is a neurobehavioral disorder named after the French neurologist Georges Gilles de la Tourette. The condition is characterized by sudden, rapid, recurrent, non-rhythmic motor movements and vocalizations, called tics. Coprolalia may be seen, which is a complex vocal tic that is characterized by expression/use of obscene words or phrases.

The DSM-V criteria for the diagnosis of Tourette syndrome include:

* Presence of both multiple motor and one or more vocal tics, at the same time during the illness. Although both need not occur simultaneously.

* The tics may wax and wane in frequency but have persisted for more than 1 year since the onset of the first tic.

* Onset is before age 18 years.

* The disorder is not attributable to the physiological effects of substance abuse (e.g. cocaine) or underlying medical condition (e.g., Huntington’s disease, postviral encephalitis).

The management of Tourette's syndrome depends on the severity of the disease.

Mild cases:

* In mild cases, where the disorder does not affect academic performance or social life, the first line of management is to provide psychoeducation, followed by a watch and wait strategy. A large proportion of patients the severity of tics wane in adult life becoming less of a medical problem.

Moderate to severe cases:

* In moderate to severe cases, where the disorder significantly affects the child's academic performance and social life, the first line of management includes behavioral and psychological treatment.

* Some commonly used methods for behavioral treatment include habit reversal, and exposure & response training.

* In severe cases, both behavioral and pharmacological treatment may be provided.

* Drugs commonly used include typical and atypical antipsychotics, nor-adrenergic agents.

questions.text: 42. A 20-year-old male presents to you with sleep deprivation, elation, and talkativeness for the last 4 days, but his social and occupational functioning is intact. He also complains of irritability and distractibility and gives a history of three episodes of major depression in the past year. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical features of decreased sleep, irritability, distractibility, elation, and talkativeness for 4 days with intact social and occupational functioning suggest an episode of hypomania. Since the patient has had episodes of major depression in the past, the diagnosis is bipolar disorder II.

Types of Bipolar disorder:

* Bipolar I: Episodes of mania with or without episodes of major depressive disorder. At least one-lifetime episode of mania is required for diagnosis. 

* Bipolar II: Episodes of hypomania with episodes of major depressive disorder. Major depressive episodes lasting at least 2 weeks and hypomanic episodes lasting for at least 4 days are required for diagnosis. A negative history of a manic episodes is needed for making a diagnosis of bipolar II disorder.

Mania presents with features similar to hypomania but for a duration of at least one week. There is a marked impairment in social and occupational functioning.

The age of onset for bipolar type I disorder ranges from, children of ages 5-6 years to adults aged 50 or above. The mean age of onset is 30 years. The lifetime prevalence of bipolar type 1 disorder is 0 to 2.4%, whereas bipolar type 2 disorder is 0.3-4.8%. Bipolar type 1 disorder is seen with an equal prevalence among men and women. Suicide attempt is seen in approximately 15% of patients affected by bipolar disorder. 

Lithium is used in the pharmacological management of bipolar disorder. Along with it, antidepressants, antipsychotics, and benzodiazepines are also used.

Other options:

Option B: Dysthymia refers to a persistent depressive mood lasting for more than two years in adults (1 year in children and adolescents). It is not severe enough to be diagnosed as major depression and has an insidious onset. The low mood persists for most of the day.

Option C: Euphoria is an emotional condition marked by intense feelings of well-being, elation, happiness, and joy.

Pearl PM0499: Bipolar disorder

Bipolar & related disorders Manic episode

* Symptoms more severe

* 1 week unless hospitalized

* Marked impairment in social or occupational functioning or hospitalization necessary

* May have psychotic features; makes episode manic by definition Hypomanic episode  

* Symptoms less severe

* 4 days to less than 7 days

* Unequivocal, observable change in functioning from patient's baseline

* Symptoms not severe enough to cause marked impairment or necessitate hospitalization

* No psychotic features Bipolar I

* Manic episode(s)

* Depressive episodes common (but not required for diagnosis) Bipolar II

* Hypomanic episode(s)

* Major depressive episodes (required for diagnosis) Cyclothymic disorder

* At least 2 years of fluctuating, mild hypomanic & depressive symptoms that do not meet criteria for hypomanic episodes or major depressive episodes

Pearl PM1904: Mania Vs Hypomania

Mania | Hypomania Symptoms for at least 1 week | Symptoms for at least 4 days Marked impairment in social or occupational functioning | No impairment in social or occupational functioning May need hospitalization | Doesn't need hospitalization

Pearl PM0502: Lithium in bipolar disorder

Guidelines for Lithium therapy Indications:

Mania, hypomania, bipolar disorder, etc. Blood levels of lithium:

For therapeutic purpose (treatment of acute mania) : 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

For prophylaxis (to prevent relapse of bipolar disorder): 0.5-0.8 mEq/L

Toxic levels of lithium: >/= 1.5 mEq/L Contraindications:

* Heart disease

* Thyroid function test

* ECG in patients with coronary risk factors Acute adverse effects:

* Tremor, ataxia, weakness

questions.text: 43. A 26-year-old who has 2 children through normal delivery presents with a dull aching pain over the abdomen with irregular menses. Per vaginal examination revealed a mass felt through the posterior fornix. A USG showed a clear ovarian cyst of 3x2 cm. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
A clear ovarian cyst with minimal symptoms and of size less than 5 cm in a woman of reproductive age group is most likely to be a functional ovarian cyst. The next best step in the management of this case is to wait and watch as most of the functional cysts regress within 6 months of identification.

Features of a functional cyst:

* Related to temporary hormonal variation

* Benign and rarely become complicated

* Should be at least 3 cm but not more than 7 cm

* Usually asymptomatic

* Unilocular

* Contains clear fluid, unless hemorrhage occurs

questions.text: 44. An elderly man presented with a painful and swollen right knee, and difficulty in walking. After examining the knee joint, aspiration is done. The following image is seen on the examination of synovial fluid using compensated polarized microscopy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image of weakly positive birefringent, rhomboid-shaped crystals are suggestive of pseudogout.

Pseudogout is a condition that occurs due to the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals (CPPD). It presents with features similar to acute gout and predominantly affects the elderly. This is attributable to the increased levels of inorganic pyrophosphate in diseased or aging cartilage which promotes CPP crystal nucleation and their deposition.

Acute attacks of CPPD presents with joint swelling and pain, affecting the knee (most common), wrist, shoulders, elbows, and hands. It also has systemic features of inflammation including fever, chills, and elevated CRP. Chronic CPPD commonly presents as polyarticular arthritis resembling osteoarthritis (pseudo-osteoarthritis). It affects atypical joints such as metacarpophalangeal, wrist, elbow, and ankle joints causing severe damage.

X-ray or ultrasonography of the joint shows chondrocalcinosis, which is punctate or linear radiodense deposits in the joint menisci or articular cartilage. Detection of rod-like or rhomboid crystals in synovial fluid or articular cartilage is diagnostic of pseudogout.

Other options :

Option A: Osteoarthritis also affects the elderly. Commonly involved joints are the hip, knee, and first metatarsal phalangeal joint (MTP). The synovial fluid in osteoarthritis is non-inflammatory. If the synovial fluid white blood cell count is >1000/μL, it is likely to be due to inflammatory arthritis, gout, or pseudogout.

Option C: Gouty arthritis is caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals (MSU) crystals which are needle-shaped and negatively birefringent. They appear yellowish when observed under polarized light. Below image shows needle-shaped, monosodium urate crystal in gout.



Option D: Psoriatic arthritis usually occurs after the development of skin lesions in a patient with psoriasis. It usually presents with dactylitis (involving the distal interphalangeal joint) and enthesitis. It is diagnosed by X-ray features of pencil-in-cup deformity, marginal erosions with adjacent bony proliferation (whiskering) and telescoping of digits.

Pearl PM1080: Difference between Gout and Pseudo-gout

Finding | Gout | Pseudogout Crystal composition | Monosodium urate | Calcium pyrophosphate Shape | Needle like | Rhomboid Birefringence pattern | Negative | Weak positive Most commonly affected joint | 1st MTP | Knee X-ray findings | Periarticular erosions with overhanging margins | Chondrocalcinosis

questions.text: 45. An obstetrician performed fetal scalp pH monitoring after obtaining an abnormal cardiotocograph of a primigravida in labour. The pH of the fetal scalp blood came out to be 7.22. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Repeat the fetal scalp blood pH within 30 minutes
Repeat the fetal scalp blood pH every 2 hours

questions.solution:
The most appropriate next step in the management of this patient will be to repeat the fetal scalp blood pH within 30 minutes.

Fetal scalp pH blood monitoring from the capillaries of the fetal scalp helps to identify the fetus in serious distress and corroborates the significance of fetal cardiotocograph abnormality due to hypoxia. The fetal scalp blood pH testing was aimed at reducing cesarean deliveries for fetal distress.

Inferences:

* Fetal scalp blood pH between 7.21 and 7.25 is borderline and needs to be repeated within 30 minutes

* Fetal scalp blood pH>7.25 is reassuring, and labour progress is monitored

* Fetal scalp blood pH <7.20 indicates fetal acidosis, and urgent delivery is required

Procedure: Mother lies in the left lateral position, and an illuminated plastic cone is inserted through the dilated cervix (4–5 cm) against the fetal head. Blood is collected (35 µl may be adequate for analysis with most pH monitors) with a long capillary tube for pH and base excess estimation through an incision of 2 mm depth made with a lancet.

Indications: 

* Abnormal cardiotocograph in labour

* Biochemical assessment of fetal hypoxia

Contraindications:

* Delivery is urgently indicated, or spontaneous delivery is certain 

* Fetal coagulation disorders

* Prematurity (< 34 weeks)

* Maternal infection (HIV, hepatitis or herpes simplex virus)

questions.text: 46. Which of the following is a symptom of the substance derived from the plant shown below?
questions.solution:
The plant shown in the image is Erythroxylum coca, the source of cocaine. Cocaine abuse is associated with formication.

Cocaine is a potent stimulant that affects the central nervous system. The symptoms of acute stimulant intoxication include agitation, irritability, aggression, and an increase in psychomotor activity. On examination, tachycardia, hypertension, and mydriasis may be seen. Paranoid delusions and hallucinations are hallmarks of stimulant-induced psychosis. 

Formication or Magnan syndrome is the false sensation of insects crawling on or under the skin or sand grains emanating from the skin. This tactile hallucination is commonly reported in chronic users of cocaine and often leads to compulsive scratching and skin picking. The sensation of bugs crawling is so distinctive in cocaine users that it is referred to as "cocaine bugs."

Other options:

Option B:  Dipsomania refers to a compulsive urge to drink alcoholic beverages. Patients suffering from alcohol-use disorders feel a need for daily use of large amounts of alcohol for adequate functioning throughout the day.

Option C: Saturnism is a term given for chronic lead poisoning, where the symptoms include anemia with basophilic stippling, Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums), constipation and colic, wrist and foot drop, and encephalopathy.

Option D: Carphologia refers to the action of trying to pick imaginary objects. The patient will usually be trying to pick lint from his clothes or the bedsheet. This is often seen in delirium. Datura intake can lead to a delirious state and may show carphologia.

questions.text: 47. A 50-year-old hypertensive woman presents with sudden, violent, uncontrollable flailing movements of her left proximal upper limb for the past one week. A lesion in which of the following structure is most commonly found in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given movement disorder describes hemiballismus and the lesion in subthalamus is most commonly found in this condition. 

Hemiballismus is a violent form of choreiform movement where wild, flinging, large-amplitude movements are seen affecting one side of the body. It mainly affects the proximal muscles and can be confined to one limb or both upper and lower limbs.



It is commonly seen in partial lesions, i.e, infarct or haemorrhage in the subthalamic nucleus. The thalamus, putamen, and parietal cortex are less commonly involved.

This movement disorder is usually self-limiting and tends to resolve spontaneously after weeks or months. Dopamine antagonistic agents can be given to manage it as well. 

Other options:

Option B: A lesion in the putamen can give rise to chorea. This is described as flicking movements of the hands, face, or any other part of the body. The movements are rapid, semipurposeful, graceful, dancelike, nonpatterned involuntary movements involving distal or proximal muscle groups.

Option C: A lesion in the globus pallidus can give rise to athetosis. This involves spontaneous and continuous writhing movements of the hand, arm, neck, or face.

Option D: A lesion in the caudate nucleus would hamper cognitive control of motor activity, that is, voluntary movements generated due to the thoughts in a person's mind.

Pearl PM1687: Site of Lesion of Movement Disorders

Movement disorder | Site of Lesion Athetosis | Globus pallidus Chorea | Putamen, Caudate Hemiballismus | Subthalamic Nucleus Parkinsonism | Substantia Nigra

questions.text: 48. What is the preferred contraceptive pill in a lactating woman and when is it ideally started in a fully breastfeeding woman?
questions.solution:
The preferred contraceptive pill in a lactating woman is the progesterone-only pill and it is ideally started at 3 months in a fully breastfeeding woman.

Progesterone-only pill does not suppress lactation and hence it is the preferred contraceptive in lactating women.

Regular breastfeeding is effective in preventing pregnancy with a failure rate of 0.5%-1.5%.  This occurs due to prolactin preventing LH surge and ovulation. It depends on the frequency of the feed rather than the duration of the feed. Hence when the woman is fully breastfeeding, a contraceptive method should be used from the 3rd postpartum month and with partial or no breastfeeding, it should be used from the 3rd postpartum week.

Oral contraceptive pill(OCP) is contraindicated in a lactating woman because

* They reduce the quality and quantity of milk.

* The hormone secreted in the milk may harm the infant

* Increased risk of thromboembolism

Note: Progesterone-only pills are safe to use anytime after birth. However, the ideal time to start contraceptives in a fully breastfeeding woman is 3 months postpartum. Hence, option B is the best answer for the given scenario.

questions.text: 49. A 28-year-old woman came to the doctor with a fever and joint pain for a month. She gives a history of some insect bites during her visit to Africa, followed by the development of a painless chancre at the site. Blood examination shows the following findings. PCR tests confirmed the presence of Trypanosoma rhodesiense. CSF shows WBC ≤5 cells/microL, and no trypanosomes are present in the CSF. What is the treatment for the causative organism?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient is diagnosed with East African trypanosomiasis, caused by Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense, without central nervous system (CNS) involvement. The most appropriate treatment for patients without CNS involvement is Suramin.

Melarsoprol is the drug of choice for treating T. brucei rhodesiense when the CNS is affected, and the patient presents with altered mental status and abnormal CSF findings. Its ability to cross the blood-brain barrier is critical in managing this severe and potentially fatal disease.

T. brucei rhodesiense is predominantly transmitted by the tsetse fly and is associated with a more acute form of disease compared to its West African counterpart. Patients typically experience a rapid progression of symptoms, including fever, headaches, and altered mental status, reflecting CNS infection. The presence of abnormal CSF findings indicates that the trypanosomes have infiltrated the CNS. Causative organism | Clinical stage | | I (Normal CSF) | II (Abnormal CSF) T. brucei gambiense

(West African) | Pentamidine | Eflornithine T. brucei rhodesiense

(East African) | Suramin | Melarsoprol

questions.text: 50. A 30-year-old male presented with 2 hypopigmented patches over the left hand. There was no nerve involvement. The physician suspects it to be leprosy. As per the updated WHO guidelines, what will be the duration of treatment and the drug regimen given to the patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of the patient with 2 hypopigmented patches and no nerve involvement is suggestive of Paucibacillary leprosy. The recommended treatment for this patient is a 3-drug regimen containing Rifampicin, Dapsone and Clofazimine, and the duration of treatment is 6 months.

According to the WHO guidelines: | Paucibacillary leprosy | Multibacillary leprosy Number of skin lesions | Upto 5 | 6 or more Nerve involvement | No nerve involvement | 1 or more Slit skin smear | Negative at all sites | Positive at any site Duration of treatment | 6 months | 12 months Drugs | Rifampicin, Dapsone and Clofazimine | Rifampicin, Dapsone and Clofazimine

The image given below shows the Multidrug therapy kit for paucibacillary and multibacillary leprosy.



Chemoprophylaxis for leprosy should be given to those:

* Age more than 2 years

* Close contact for more than 20 hours per week for more than 3 weeks

A single dose of rifampicin is recommended for the close contact of a patient with leprosy, provided they do not develop any signs or symptoms pertaining to leprosy.

The image given below shows a hypopigmented satellite skin lesion seen in leprosy.

questions.text: 51. A patient came to the OPD with a swelling shown in the image below. What examination findings are seen in this type of swelling?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a swelling with punctum suggestive of a sebaceous cyst. They are usually transillumination negative and Paget’s test positive.  

Paget's test determines whether the swelling is fluctuant. The transillumination test determines if a swelling contains clear fluid by transmitting light through it. Positive results indicate the presence of water, serum, lymph, or plasma. 

Sebaceous cysts, also known as epidermoid cysts, are painless retention cysts that arise from a blocked infundibulum of the sebaceous gland. They are encapsulated, adherent to the skin, filled with keratin, yellowish-white cheesy material, and lined by true stratified squamous epithelium. A punctum (denuded keratin) is a common identifying feature, and it can occur anywhere on the body except for the palms and soles. They are most commonly found in the postauricular sulcus or below and behind the ear lobule.

The complications include sebaceous horn, cock’s peculiar tumor, and abscess formation. The treatment involves the excision of the cyst along with normal skin using an elliptical incision.

Pearl PM2120: Brilliantly Transilluminating Swellings

* Vaginal hydrocele

* Epididymal cyst

* Cystic hygroma

* Ranula

* Meningocele

questions.text: 52. A 56-year-old woman presents with progressive dyspnea, fatigue, and occasional hemoptysis. She reports a history of rheumatic fever in childhood. On examination, she has a diastolic murmur best heard at the apex with the patient in the left lateral decubitus position, and there is evidence of left atrial enlargement on echocardiography. Which of the following pressure-volume loops corresponds to this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation suggests mitral stenosis. The pressure-volume curve in image 2 is an accurate representation of the same.

The pressure-volume curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.



The PV loop is shifted to the right when there is volume overload (increased EDV). The PV loop is shifted to the left in case of increased contractility or decreased compliance (decreased EDV).

Pressure-Volume Changes in Mitral Stenosis (MS):

* Decreased LV end-diastolic volume (EDV) (rules out option A): MS limits blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle during diastole. This leads to reduced LV preload, resulting in a smaller PV loop width (narrow loop on the X-axis, indicating lower volume).

* Reduced stroke volume because of lower preload. (rules out option C and D)

* Normal LV systolic pressure as contractility remains preserved



Other options:

Option A: This PV loop shows increased LV pressure during systole due to the high afterload imposed by aortic stenosis. However, the stroke volume is reduced, evident from the narrowed width of the loop. End-systolic pressure is much higher, and the ventricle must generate significantly more pressure to eject blood through the narrowed valve.

Option C: The loop is widened, and LV end-diastolic volume is markedly increased due to volume overload from backflow of blood in aortic regurgitation. There is no true isovolumetric contraction or relaxation, as blood is constantly flowing back into the ventricle during diastole. Stroke volume increases, but the LV has to deal with both the forward and regurgitant volume, increasing myocardial workload.

Option D: In this loop, end-diastolic volume increases slightly, and there's no isovolumetric contraction, as blood leaks back into the atrium in mitral regurgitation. The loop has a blunted, more rounded shape. The afterload is reduced because blood is ejected both into the aorta and back into the left atrium. Although total stroke volume is increased, effective forward stroke volume is reduced, and this leads to volume overload over time.

questions.text: 53. A 26-year-old male presents with complaints of anal discharge for the past 3 days. He reports engaging in unprotected anal intercourse. On examination, mucopurulent discharge from anus was seen without ulceration. Which of the following drugs will be used for syndromic management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of anorectal discharge. The syndromic management of anorectal discharges is done with Kit-8 (Brown kit), which includes Cefixime and Doxycycline.

NACO color-coded kits for syndromic management of sexually transmitted infections: Kit | Syndrome | Drugs Kit 1 (Grey) | Urethral discharge

Cervical discharge | Azithromycin and Cefixime Kit 2 (Green) | Vaginal discharge | Secnidazole and Fluconazole Kit 3 (White) | Non-herpetic genital ulcers | Inj Benzathine Penicillin G and Tab Azithromycin Kit 4 (Blue) | Non-herpetic genital ulcers, if allergic to penicillin | Doxycycline and Azithromycin Kit 5 (Red) | Herpetic genital ulcers | Acyclovir Kit 6 (Yellow) | Lower abdominal pain | Cefixime, Metronidazole and Doxycycline Kit 7 (Black) | Inguinal bubo | Doxycycline Kit 8 (Brown) | Anorectal discharge | Cefixime and Doxycycline

Partner treatment is not required for asymptomatic partners in cases of Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: 54. A 57-year-old man comes with complaints of severe headaches for 3 weeks that are unresponsive to analgesia. His MRI Brain is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis and the cell involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history suggests the presence of an intracranial space occupying the lesion. The MRI shows a growth that is crossing the corpus callosum with areas of necrosis. This is most likely Glioblastoma multiforme, which is an aggressive tumor of astrocytes. 

Glioblastoma falls under WHO grade IV brain tumors

According to the WHO Classification of CNS Diseases 2016, glioblastomas are classified as follows:

Glioblastoma, IDH-wildtype:

* About 90% of cases

* Primary or de novo glioblastoma

* Over 55 years of age

* Mutations: EGFR, PTEN

* Carries poor prognosis

Glioblastoma, IDH-mutant:

* About 10% of cases

* Secondary glioblastoma, with a history of prior lower-grade diffuse glioma

* Arises in younger patients

* Mutations:p53

* Better prognosis

Glioblastoma, NOS, where full IDH evaluation cannot be performed.

Temozolomide is used as a first-line agent for the management of glioblastoma multiforme. It is used for newly diagnosed cases along with radiotherapy and also used for maintenance therapy.

The histological image shows foci of necrosis with pseudopalisading of malignant nuclei and endothelial cell proliferation, which is characteristic of glioblastoma (previously called glioblastoma multiforme).



MRI of a glioblastoma shows a necrotic hemorrhagic mass that usually crosses the corpus callosum. 

Other Options: 

Meningiomas are primary extra-axial neoplasms arising from the meningothelial arachnoidal cells. It is seen as a well-defined, hyperdense mass close to the midline, situated extra-axially.

questions.text: 55. Which of the following is true regarding the toxin produced by the most common organism implicated in traveler’s diarrhea?

choices.text: Heat stable-A (ST-A) toxin is insoluble in methanol
Heat stable-B (ST-B) toxin is soluble in methanol

questions.solution:
Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC) is the most common organism implicated in the causation of traveller’s diarrhoea, and Heat stable-A (ST-A) toxin acts by ↑cGMP.

Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli is toxigenic, but not invasive. Toxins produced include: 

* LT (heat-labile toxin): acts by ↑cAMP

* ST (heat-stable toxin): Two types of ST are known, ST-A (or ST I, which is soluble in methanol) and ST-B (or ST-II, insoluble in methanol).

* ST-A acts by ↑cGMP  in the intestine

* ST-B: Its mode of action is not known though it is not through cAMP or cGMP.

Pearl PM2032: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

* Bordetella pertusis

* Bacillus anthracis

* Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin

* Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

* Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

* Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)

* Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)

* Clostridium difficile

* Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S

* Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: 56. A 26-year-old pregnant woman has the following flow pattern of umbilical arteries on a doppler. What does this pattern indicate?
questions.solution:
The given flow pattern of umbilical arteries represents an absence of end-diastolic flow (AEDF) in the umbilical arteries.

In case of absent end-diastolic flow (AEDF), the waves just touch the baseline, but do not appear below it. This is associated with intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR). 

Pregnant women having intrauterine growth restriction with AEDF in the umbilical artery are managed expectantly until delivery at 34 weeks. 

Umbilical artery vessels usually have forward flow throughout the cardiac cycle.  As gestation increases, there is a gradual fall in all the placental resistance indices, so the amount of the forward diastolic flow increases and the S/D ratio (systole to diastole ratio) decreases as the period of gestation increases.

Note: Reverse end-diastolic flow has seen an insignificant increase in resistance to blood flow within the placenta. They are managed expectantly until delivery at 32 weeks.

The below image shows various patterns of end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery on Doppler.

questions.text:
57. Which of the following is incorrect about the use of eFAST?

eFAST - Extended focused assessment with sonography for trauma

1. It can detect >100 ml of free blood

2. It is used for the assessment of blood in the paracolic gutters, subdiaphragmatic spaces and pelvis

3. Solid organ injury is difficult to diagnose

4. Hollow viscus injury can easily be identified
questions.solution:
Statement 4, that is, Hollow viscus injury can easily be identified, is the incorrect statement.

Extended focused assessment with sonography for trauma (eFAST) is a rapid, non-invasive bedside test for detecting free fluid using sonography to assess patients for potential thoracoabdominal injuries. It helps to view the left and right thoracic regions to assess for pneumothorax and haemothorax, in addition to the assessment of blood in the paracolic gutters, subdiaphragmatic spaces and pelvis. It can detect >100 ml of free blood.

Limitations of eFAST are:

* It is operator-dependent

* Hollow viscus injury and solid organ injury are difficult to diagnose

* Bowel gas and subcutaneous air distort images.

* Unreliable for assessment of the retroperitoneum

* Cannot reliably exclude injury in penetrating trauma

* May need repeating or supplementing with other investigations

questions.text: 58. A 42-year-old woman presents with a gradual onset of weight gain, central obesity, and thinning skin. Laboratory tests reveal increased cortisol levels and elevated ACTH. Which of the following cells in the pituitary gland secretes the hormone implicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario indicates Cushing's disease characterized by increased levels of cortisol and ACTH, . It typically occurs due to a pituitary adenoma that hypersecretes ACTH. The pituitary hormone ACTH is secreted by basophils (cells with a strong affinity for basic dyes).

Exogenous causes (iatrogenic)

* Prolonged administration of glucocorticoids (most common cause of Cushing's)

Endogenous causes

* Adrenocortical adenoma 

* Adrenocortical carcinoma 

* Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia

* ACTH dependent (secondary hypercortisolism)

* Cushing’s disease: ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma (most common cause of endogenous Cushing's)

* Paraneoplastic causes: Ectopic ACTH secreting tumors

* Small-cell lung carcinoma

* Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors

* Medullary thyroid carcinoma

* Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia

Pearl PM1550: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

* Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol

* 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value

* Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)

* Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

* Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

questions.text: 59. Which of the following is not a criteria for discharging a patient recovering from dengue?

choices.text: Minimum of 2-3 days after recovery from shock
No respiratory distress from pleural effusion or ascites

questions.solution:
The absence of fever for 12 hours is not a criterion for the discharge of a patient recovering from dengue. Fever should be absent for at least 24 hours without the use of antipyretic drugs in order to discharge a patient recovering from dengue.

Criteria for discharge of patients recovering from dengue:

* Absence of fever for at least 24 hours without the use of antipyretic drugs

* Platelet count >50,000/mm3

* Return of appetite

* Adequate urine output

* Visible clinical improvement

* Minimum of 2-3 days after recovery from shock

* No respiratory distress from pleural effusion or ascites

questions.text: 60. Identify the anomaly seen in this fetus on the antenatal ultrasound.
questions.solution:
The fetal anomaly seen in this antenatal ultrasound is gastroschisis.

Gastroschisis is a congenital anomaly whereby there is a full-thickness ventral abdominal wall defect usually to the right side of the umbilical insertion associated with herniation of the bowel loops through the defect into the amniotic cavity. It is seen in 1:2000 births and is associated with younger maternal age, the average age being 20 years. 

Associated anomalies like jejunal atresia are sometimes seen. There is usually no aneuploidy and survival rates when surgically managed are very good. Gastroschisis on an antenatal ultrasound is evidenced by the cauliflower-shaped protrusion from the fetus's abdomen, which is the herniated bowel loops without an omental covering freely floating in the amniotic fluid, as shown below:

This condition can be diagnosed in an ultrasound as early as the late first trimester. It may be complicated by fetal growth restriction. At birth, the neonate presents as shown in the image below:





The intestines are matted and covered by a thick peel. Longer exposure in utero to amniotic fluid can cause trauma to the intestines. The intestines are also not fully rotated and these factors increase the risk of intestinal volvulus, postnatal intestinal dysfunction with delayed mobility, and prolonged need for hospitalization and enteral feeding.

Gastroschisis also increases the risk of intestinal transplant and short bowel syndrome in children. Treatment involves surgically placing the herniated viscera back in the abdominal cavity followed by repair of the wall defect. Silastic spring-loaded silo or staged repair may be done where immediate surgery cannot be undertaken.

An important differential diagnosis is Omphalocele in which there is usually persistence of physiological herniation of the gut. On AN USG, a smooth mass is seen to protrude from the abdomen. Post delivery, the neonate is seen to have a mass covered by the peritoneum and amnion containing the viscera. AN USG and postnatal image is shown below:





Other Options:

Option B: Ectopia cordis- Due to defective development of the chest wall, the heart lies exposed, on the front of the chest, and can be seen from the outside. A fetal MRI is seen below seen in the picture below, showing the heart in an ectopic position (indicated by *). Eventration of a part of the liver at the midline (indicated by the arrow) is also seen with a small thoracic cavity (t).



Option C: Posterior urethral valve is the presence of abnormal folds of mucosa between the wall of the urethra and the verumontanum, and causes distal obstruction of the urinary tract. It may be diagnosed as early as the first trimester, presenting with urinary ascites, oligohydramnios, enlarged bladders and renal dilatation. The dilation of the proximal urethra, with a markedly dilated bladder, is termed the keyhole sign (as shown in the image below).



Option D: Encephalocele is a defect in the skull through which the meninges and brain tissues herniate.

Characteristic | Gastroschisis | Omphalocele Defect size (diameter) | 2-3 cm | 2-15 cm Sac | Never | Always, may be ruptured Gestational age | Prematurity | Term Umbilical cord | Adjacent to the defect (defect is seen usually on its right side) | Attached to sac Herniated viscera | Small bowel, stomach, colon | Small bowel, stomach, colon, liver Malrotation | Yes | Yes Bowel character | Inflammatory, edematous | Normal Enternal nutrition | Delayed | Normal Associated abnormalities | Uncommon (10% atresia) | Common (50%)

Pearl PM2262: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.



Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.



T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.



Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.



Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.



Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 



Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.



Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 



Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.



Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.



Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.



Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: 61. A 1-year-old child is brought to the clinic with complaints of delayed development and an abnormally shaped head. The hands of the child are as shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image given in the question shows syndactyly which is characterized by fusion of fingers or toes, and it is the hallmark for Apert syndrome.

The child’s delayed development, abnormally shaped head (craniofacial abnormalities), and syndactyly (fusion of fingers or toes) are characteristic of Apert syndrome, which is a genetic disorder caused by a mutation in the FGFR2 gene. This syndrome is known for its craniosynostosis (premature fusion of skull bones), syndactyly, and intellectual disability. Children with Apert syndrome often have distinctive facial features, including a high, prominent forehead, shallow eye sockets, and wide-set eyes.

Other options:

Option A: Crouzon syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the FGFR2 gene (same as Apert syndrome) but does not typically involve syndactyly. The hallmark features of Crouzon syndrome include craniofacial abnormalities such as craniosynostosis, midface hypoplasia (underdeveloped midface), and exophthalmos (bulging eyes), but syndactyly is not present.



Option C: Treacher Collins syndrome is characterized by craniofacial abnormalities, including underdeveloped cheekbones, downward-slanting eyes, and microtia (small or absent ears). While developmental delay can occur in some cases, syndactyly and craniosynostosis are not characteristic features of Treacher Collins syndrome.



Option D:  Waardenburg syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by sensorineural hearing loss, pigmentary abnormalities (such as two different colored eyes or early graying of hair), and dystopia canthorum (widely spaced eyes). It does not involve craniosynostosis or syndactyly.

questions.text:
62. Which of the following is not included in Step 3 under the WHO STEP wise approach for NCD surveillance?

NCD: Non-communicable Diseases
questions.solution:
Blood Pressure is not included in Step 3 under the WHO STEP wise approach for NCD surveillance. 

The STEPS Non-communicable Disease Risk Factor Survey was developed by the WHO to help countries establish NCD surveillance system. The methodology prescribes three steps: 

* Step 1: Questionnaire: In this step, behavioral risk factors are assessed, including smoking, alcohol consumption, physical activity, diet, and medical history of hypertension and diabetes.

* Step 2: Physical measurements are taken, such as weight, height, waist circumference, blood pressure measurement.

* Step 3: Biochemical measurements are collected such as fasting blood glucose, total cholesterol levels and urinary sodium and creatinine levels. (Option B, C, D)

Surveys are conducted at both national and subnational levels, focusing on demographic, health status, and health behaviors. They collect data on socio-economic, metabolic, nutritional, and lifestyle risk factors.

questions.text: 63. A 44-year-old man diagnosed with primary sclerosing cholangitis presents with progressive worsening of jaundice and pruritus for one month. MRCP done showed a dominant stricture at the hilum with a hepatic mass adjacent to the stricture. What is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this patient?

choices.text: ERCP with brushings of the bile duct for cytology
Ultrasound-guided percutaneous biopsy of the mass

questions.solution:
In the above scenario, a patient with primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) presents with pruritis, jaundice, and ascites that are suggestive of obstructive jaundice. Cholangiocarcinoma should be ruled out in case of a suspected mass in the biliary tract that is causing the obstruction. Hence the next best step would be to perform an endoscopic inspection with biliary brush cytology. 

Primary sclerosing cholangitis is an autoimmune condition characterized by inflammatory strictures involving the intra and extra-hepatic biliary tree. It is a progressive condition that leads to secondary biliary cirrhosis.

The common age group of primary sclerosing cholangitis is 30-45 years. Men are affected twice as commonly as women. 2/3rd of these cases are associated with ulcerative colitis. It is also associated with Riedel’s thyroiditis and retroperitoneal fibrosis. There is also a strong predisposition to cholangiocarcinoma, gall bladder carcinoma, and colorectal carcinoma. Thus, annual screening for these cancers is mandatory. 

Clinical features of a patient with PSC include:

* Intermittent jaundice

* Fatigue

* Weight loss

* Pruritus

* Abdominal pain

Liver function tests show a cholestatic pattern with an elevation of ALP and GGT and smaller rises in the aminotransferases. Bilirubin values may be variable.

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiography (ERCP) is a gold standard in diagnosis and shows multiple dilatations and strictures (beading) of both intra- and extra-hepatic biliary tree.

Currently, there is no known effective medical therapy. Surgical management involving resection of extrahepatic biliary tree and hepaticojejunostomy has shown reasonable effects. For patients with advanced liver disease, liver transplantation is the only available option.

The below image shows a cholangiogram of primary sclerosing cholangitis. There are diffuse strictures of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts with dilatation of the areas in between:



Option A: Imaging studies to differentiate the biliary strictures from either inflammation or malignancy is not reliable. They are also not sensitive to detecting the mass and hence, are not indicated to diagnose cholangiocarcinoma. 

Option B: Percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage is done as a part of palliative treatment in unresectable cholangiocarcinoma. This is done to relieve obstructive features like jaundice and pruritis. 

Option D: Ultrasound-guided percutaneous biopsy of the mass is not done as it increases the risk of bile duct injuries and biliary leak.

questions.text: 64. A 45-year-old woman presented with menorrhagia. A hysterectomy was performed, and the resected specimen is shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a woman with menorrhagia and hysterectomy gross specimen showing a well-circumscribed tumour, well demarcated with a whorled appearance within the uterine cavity suggests a Submucous fibroid.

Interstitial fibroid grows inwards towards the uterine cavity, leading to the formation of submucous fibroid. The patient can be asymptomatic or present with menorrhagia. Other menstrual disturbances that can be seen with fibroids are polymenorrhoea, metrorrhagia, or postmenopausal bleeding. The patient can also present with infertility, recurrent abortions, pain, pressure symptoms, abdominal lump, or vaginal discharge.  

Classification of fibroids based on anatomical location:

* Body (corporeal) fibroids-

* Interstitial/intramural fibroids: They are the most common 

* Subserosal fibroids: They are the least common (10%). Interstitial fibroids grow outwards to form subserous fibroids and are covered by the peritoneum. These include wandering or parasitic fibroids and broad ligament fibroids.

* Submucous fibroids

* Cervical fibroids



Other options:

Option A: Uterine sarcoma- The cut surface of the tumour is haemorrhagic and irregular, without the whorled appearance of a myoma as shown in the image below. The consistency is friable and soft.



Option C: Subserosal fibroid is present towards the peritoneal surface of the uterus as shown in the image below.



Option D: Endometrioma is an ovarian cyst filled with endometrial tissue. It would not be found within the uterus but rather on the ovaries as shown in the image below.

questions.text: 65. A young girl presented with an inability to abduct her right thumb following a supracondylar fracture of her right humerus. The following test was done on her and found to be positive. What is the nerve likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a pen test. A positive pen test is seen in injury of the median nerve due to the weakness of the abductor pollicis brevis muscle. 

To perform the pen test, the hand is held flat with the palm facing upwards. A pen is held above the palm and the patient is asked to touch the pen with his thumb. If the patient is unable to touch the pen, it signifies a positive pen test.

Median nerve lesions can be high lesions or low lesions depending on the site of injury.

Low lesions occur due to injuries at the distal 1/3rd of the forearm such as carpal dislocation or cut wound of the wrist. There will be paralysis of the hand muscles and the patient will be unable to abduct the thumb. There is also a loss of sensation over the radial 3½ digits. The forearm muscles supplied by the median nerve are spared in these lesions. Wasting of thenar eminence is seen in long-standing cases.

High lesions occur due to injuries such as forearm fractures or elbow dislocation. There is paralysis of the forearm muscles along with all the features of low lesions.

Muscles supplied by the median nerve are given in the table: In the arm | No muscles Proximal 1/3rd of the forearm | All the flexor muscles of the proximal forearm, except the flexor carpi ulnaris and the medial half of the flexor digitorum profundus Distal 1/3rd of the forearm | No muscles In the hand | Abductor pollicis brevis Opponens pollicis Flexor pollicis brevis First two lumbricals

Other tests for median nerve: 

Pointing index sign or Oschner’s clasp test - the patient is asked to clasp both hands together. When this is done the index and the middle finger fail to flex due to the loss of action of long finger flexors which are supplied by the median nerve. 

Benediction test - due to loss of activity of the long finger flexors the patient is unable to flex the index and middle finger on lifting the hand. As this is the position a clergyman uses to bless the couple during the marriage, it is called the benediction test.

questions.text: 66. A female patient with ovarian cancer is started with paclitaxel. Which of the following is false about this class of drugs?

choices.text: Also used in chemotherapy regimen of breast cancer
Glove-stocking sensory neuropathy is an adverse effect.

questions.solution:
Paclitaxel belongs to the class of taxanes. Taxanes promote the polymerization of tubulin protein, stabilize the microtubules and result in mitotic arrest.

Taxanes are cell-cycle-specific cytotoxic drugs. Taxanes bind to the β-tubulin subunit of the microtubules, promote polymerization, and prevent the disassembly of these microtubules that result in M-phase arrest of the cell cycle. Examples of taxanes are paclitaxel, docetaxel, and cabazitaxel.

Resistance to taxanes occurs due to increased expression of efflux proteins. They are used in chemotherapy regimens of metastatic ovarian tumor, breast, lung, gastrointestinal, genitourinary, and head and neck cancers. Paclitaxel is used in the first-generation drug-eluting stent for primary coronary intervention and used as an antiproliferative agent. 

The adverse effects include bone marrow suppression, peripheral glove-stocking sensory neuropathy, hypersensitivity reactions, myalgia, mucositis and fluid retention.

questions.text: 67. A farmer from sub-Himalayan belt had a thorn prick injury and developed a warty, verrucous growth at the site of the prick. Histology of the lesion is given in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is likely a case of chromoblastomycosis with sclerotic bodies seen on histopathology examination

It is a subcutaneous infection caused by fungi belonging to the genus Fonsecaea. It enters the skin by traumatic inoculation. Hence, seen in woodcutters and farmers. It appears as sclerotic bodies on histopathology examination and copper penny bodies on KOH mount. Treatment with antifungals are given.

Points in favor:

* Sub-Himalayan belt farmer with thorn prick injury

* Verrucous growth

* Histology showing "Medlar bodies"(sclerotic bodies)

| Chromoblastomycosis | Sporotrichosis Cause | Pigmented fungi-Phialophora and Fonsecaea species | Dimorphic fungi-Sporothrix schenckii Presentation | Warty, cauliflower-like growth at the site of the prick | A linear chain of ulcerating nodules and sinuses along the lymphatics Histology | Medlar bodies/sclerotic bodies | Asteroid bodies

The image given below shows a patient's foot affected with chromoblastomycosis.



Other options:

Mycetoma:

* It is caused by various types of fungi (Eumycetoma) or filamentous bacteria (Actinomycetes).

* It presents with a painless nodule but with time, papules and pustules may form, which break down to form draining sinuses, with the discharge of granules.

Image: Mycetoma of foot



Sporotrichosis: Nodules generally develop along the draining lymphatics



Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that causes cryptococcosis. It is an oval, budding yeast with a prominent polysaccharide capsule, which is very apparent in India ink staining. It forms smooth, mucoid, cream-colored colonies on Sabouraud agar.

Pearl PM1761: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

* Yeast

* Yeast-like

* Molds

* Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

* Unicellular fungi

* Reproduces by budding

* Oval to round forms

* Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.



Yeast like:

* Unicellular fungi

* Reproduces by budding or binary fission

* Spherical or oval forms

* Pseudohyphae may be seen.

* Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.



Molds/filamentous fungi:

* Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate

* Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.

* Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.



Dimorphic fungi

* Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.

* Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.

* Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: 68. In a 50-year-old patient undergoing a Bassini repair of a direct inguinal hernia, which suture material will provide infinite tensile strength and low tissue reaction?
questions.solution:
Prolene is the best suture material used for the repair to have infinite tensile strength and low tissue reaction.

Prolene, also known as Polypropylene, is a non-absorbable suture material with low tissue reaction. It is made up of a polymer of propylene, which is a monofilament, dyed or undyed. The tensile strength is for infinite (> 1 year), and remains encapsulated in the body tissues.

In case of herniorrhaphy, non-absorbable suture material with low tissue reaction is used to maintain the strength of the hernia repair and minimise the tissue inflammation reaction. Prolene is the best option for the repair. Another suture that can be used is Ethilon.



Option B: Vicryl is an absorbable suture material with mild tissue reaction, which is a braided multifilament.



Option C: Silk is a non-absorbable suture material with moderate to high tissue reaction, which is a braided multifilament. The raw material is silk from the silkworm.



Option D: Chromic catgut is an absorbable suture material with moderate tissue reaction.

questions.text: 69. A 30-year-old female patient came with complaints of fever, cough, multiple joint pain, and painful rashes on the leg as shown below. Chest x-ray showed bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and a pulmonary biopsy showed non-caseating granuloma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A female patient with fever, arthritis, lesions suggestive of erythema nodosum, and chest x-ray of bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy with biopsy showing non-caseating granuloma are suggestive of Lofgren's syndrome.

Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous inflammatory condition with multisystem involvement. The most common organs affected are the lungs, liver, eyes, and skin. It is more often seen in women. 

There are two syndromes that are associated with sarcoidosis are: 

* Lofgren's syndrome is characterized by erythema nodosum and hilar adenopathy. Periarticular arthritis may also be seen.

* Mikulicz syndrome is the bilateral involvement of parotid, submaxillary, and sublingual glands. 

The most common presenting features are cough, dyspnea, fever, night sweats, and weight loss. Other manifestations of sarcoidosis include: 

* Ophthalmologic - anterior uveitis, photophobia, dry eyes, and blurred vision

* Neurological - myelopathy, basilar meningitis, and facial nerve paralysis

* Dermatological - maculopapular lesions, keloid formation, and subcutaneous nodules. Lupus pernio refers to the skin involvement of the bridge of the nose, periocular region, and cheeks and points to a chronic state.

The investigations used in the diagnosis of sarcoidosis include:

* Serum ACE (angiotensin-converting enzyme) levels - elevated

* BAL- lymphocytosis and increased CD4/CD8 ratio. A ratio of >3.5 in BAL is strongly supportive of sarcoidosis.

* Gallium scan shows the following signs:

* Panda sign- due to bilateral involvement of parotid and lacrimal glands 

* Lambda sign- due to bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph nodes 

* Biopsy showing non-caseating granulomas along with features of sarcoidosis is confirmatory.

* PET-CT scan - to identify areas of granulomatous disease

Other options:

Option A: Heerfordt–Waldenstrom syndrome also known as uveoparotid fever is a rare presentation of sarcoidosis characterized by fever, parotid enlargement, facial palsy, and anterior uveitis.

Option C: Loeffler's syndrome is transient pulmonary eosinophilia which occurs in response to the passage of helminthic larvae through the lungs. Most commonly, it is seen in roundworm (Ascaris species) infection.

Option D: Sweet syndrome is also known as febrile neutrophilic dermatosis. It is characterized by the presence of WBCs in the lower dermis. It is mostly seen in neutropenic patients with malignancies such as acute myeloid leukemia.

Pearl PM0009: Named lung diseases

Bagassosis | Pneumoconiosis due to sugarcane Byssinosis (brown lung disease/ Monday fever) | Pneumoconiosis due to cotton fiber Farmer’s lung | Pneumoconiosis due to Thermophilic actinomycetes Bird Fancier’s lung | Hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by bird droppings Chalicosis (flint disease) | In stonecutters, due to inhalation of fine particles of stone Caplan’s syndrome | RA + pneumoconiosis Lofgren's syndrome | An acute presentation of sarcoidosis, consisting of arthritis, erythema nodosum, and bilateral hilar adenopathy Bornholm’s disease (epidemic pleurodynia) | associated with Coxsackie B virus

questions.text: 70. A patient with acute intestinal obstruction and bowel distension is posted for immediate laparotomy. Which of the following anesthetic agent is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Nitrous oxide is contraindicated in a patient with intestinal obstruction and bowel distension. This is due to its tendency of rapid diffusion into air-containing cavities than nitrogen in the blood, thus increasing the pressure.

Nitrous oxide is the least potent inhalational anesthetic agent. It has a very high diffusion capacity than nitrogen (air) itself, which causes the cavity to expand. Thus it is avoided in cases like pneumothorax, air embolism, acute intestinal obstruction with bowel distention, intracranial air, pulmonary air cysts, intraocular air bubbles, and tympanic membrane grafting.

It can even diffuse into tracheal tube cuffs, thus increasing its pressure and hampering mucosal blood circulation. It is also avoided in patients at high risk of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV).

Other side effects include bone marrow depression, megaloblastic anemia, teratogenicity and peripheral neuropathy.

Other options:

Option B - Desflurane is avoided in patients with severe hypovolemia, malignant hyperthermia, and intracranial hypertension.

Option C - Halothane is avoided in patients with unexplained liver dysfunction, intracranial space-occupying lesions and reduced left ventricular function.

Option D - Isoflurane has no unique contraindications but has to be avoided in patients with the risk of developing malignant hyperthermia as it can be a triggering agent.

Pearl PM2301: Unique features of Nitrous oxide

Concentration-effect

* The blood gas partition coefficient of N2O is 35 times higher than O2 and N2, hence its rapid uptake diminishes its volume and concentrates the remaining anesthetics in the alveolus.

Second-gas effect

* Concentration-effect of one gas over another is known as the second gas effect

* Increase in the partial pressure of the 2nd gas (Oxygen and volatile agents) due to the rapid uptake of N2O during induction.

Diffusion hypoxia (Finks effect)

* Rapid elimination of N2O during recovery causes a reduction in the partial pressure of oxygen leading to hypoxia

* Avoided by using 100% oxygen for 10 minutes during recovery from anesthesia.

Nitrous oxide in gas-filled spaces

* It diffuses into air-containing cavities more rapidly than air (principally nitrogen) can be absorbed by the bloodstream

* If the walls surrounding the cavity are rigid, pressure rises instead of volume.

Hence N2O is contraindicated in:

* Venous or arterial air embolism

* Acute intestinal obstruction

* Pneumocephalus, pneumothorax

* Pulmonary air cysts

* Intraocular air bubbles

* Tympanic membrane grafting.

Pearl PM2298: Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)

Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is the minimum concentration of an inhaled anesthetic at 1 atm of pressure that prevents skeletal muscle movement in response to a surgical incision in 50% of patients. 

MAC of inhaled anesthetics Anesthetic Agents | MAC (Potency) | Blood-gas coefficient (Solubility) Halothane | 0.75 | 2.4 Isoflurane | 1.2 | 1.4 Enflurane | 1.7 | 1.9 Sevoflurane | 2 | 0.65 Desflurane | 6 | 0.42 Nitrous oxide | 104 | 0.47

MAC is an indicator of potency. The lower the MAC, the higher is the potency.
