questions.text: 71. Which of the following will result if there is a transection at the level marked as 2 in the given image along with vagotomy?
questions.solution:
A mid-pontine lesion, as shown by the level marked 2 in the given image, along with vagotomy, will lead to the stopping of the breath in inspiration, known as apneusis.

The pacemakers of normal breathing, neurons of the pre-Botzinger complex are located in the medulla. Dorsal and ventral groups of respiratory neurons are also present in the medulla. The dorsal group generates the inspiratory impulses independent of any other input into the brainstem. The ventral group is inactive during normal quiet breathing, but provides expiratory signals to abdominal muscles during forceful expiration.

The impulses generated by the dorsal group are initially irregular. They are made regular by the input from the apneustic center located in the lower pons. The apneustic center itself is under inhibitory control of the pneumotaxic center, located in the upper part of the pons.

A transection below the medulla stops all spontaneous breathing because the inspiratory signals from the dorsal group are not able to act.

A transection between the medulla and the pons makes the breathing irregular, because the influence of the apneustic center on the dorsal group of neurons is gone. 

A transection at the mid-pontine level removes the influence of the pneumotaxic center on the apneustic center. If the vagi are intact, this results in regular, deep breathing. If the vagi are also cut, it leads to prolonged inspiratory effort, known as apneusis.

A transection above the level of the pons have no effect on breathing. If the vagi are also cut, the breathing becomes deeper.

Pearl PM0998: Effects of Various Lesions and Brainstem Transections

Label | Level of transection | Vagi intact | Vagi cut A | Complete transection above pons | Regular breathing continues | Regular breathing continues but depth of inspiration increases B | Mid-pontine level section | Regular breathing continues | Apneusis develops C | Transection midway between pons and medulla | Irregular but rhythmic respiration | Irregular but rhythmic respiration D | Complete transection below medulla | Spontaneous respiration ceases | Spontaneous respiration ceases



CP - middle cerebellar peduncle

DRG - Dorsal group of respiratory neurons

IC - inferior colliculus

NPBL - nucleus parabrachialis (pneumotaxic center)

VRG - ventral group of respiratory neurons

4th vent - fourth ventricle.

Pearl PM0997: Respiratory Centres

Respiratory center component | Primary function Pre-Bőtzinger complex | Pacemaker cells of spontaneous or automatic breathing Dorsal Respiratory Group (DRG) | Respiratory rhythm generator (inspiratory ramp signal) Ventral Respiratory Group (VRG) | Overdrive mechanism Pneumotaxic centre | Controls the “switch off” point of inspiratory ramp signal Apneustic centre | Delays switch off signal- promotes inspiration Vagi | Inhibits inspiratory discharge

questions.text: 72. A 40-year-old man is undergoing a 45-minute procedure on his forearm under Bier’s block. Which of the following local anesthetics is most appropriate for this setting?
questions.solution:
Intravenous regional anaesthesia (IVRA), or Bier’s block, is most commonly performed using Lidocaine.

Lidocaine or Prilocaine are ideal due to their rapid onset, short duration of action, and relatively safer systemic profiles. Lidocaine, in particular, is the most widely used agent for IVRA, especially for procedures lasting less than an hour, like the 45-minute forearm procedure in this case. It is typically administered in a preservative-free 0.5% solution without epinephrine, with a dose of around 3 mg/kg for upper limb surgeries. This makes it both effective and relatively safe for short procedures in extremities.

Other options:

Option B, C and D: Bupivacaine, Ropivacaine, and Etidocaine are not recommended for IVRA due to their higher cardiotoxic potential. They cause severe cardiac arrhythmias and even cardiovascular collapse if inadvertently released into the systemic circulation, as can happen if the tourniquet fails or is deflated prematurely.

questions.text: 73. A 45-year-old woman came with complaints of massive painless vaginal bleeding. She also reported amenorrhea for 2 months. The histopathological examination of the endometrium showed a characteristic Swiss cheese pattern. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario history of painless vaginal bleeding preceded by amenorrhea with histopathological examination of the endometrium revealing a characteristic Swiss cheese pattern is suggestive of metropathia hemorrhagica.

Metropathia hemorrhagica is a specialized form of anovulatory DUB, seen in women aged 40 to 45 years. The typical symptoms are continuous painless vaginal bleeding at the onset of menses or preceded by a 6-8 week period of amenorrhoea. Occasionally the woman gives a history of menorrhagia prior to this.

On examination, the uterus is bulky and uniformly enlarged. Histopathological findings are:

* Myohyperplasia of the uterine wall - up to 2.5cm

* Thick endometrium with cystic glandular hyperplasia appearing as Swiss cheese pattern

* Absence of secretory endometrium i.e. absence of corkscrew glands 

* Thin, slender endometrial polyps project into the uterine cavity

* Corpus luteum is absent

* One or both ovaries may contain a cyst

Other options

Option A: Endometriosis usually presents in the reproductive age group, with symptoms of dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, menorrhagia, and infertility.

Option B: Halban's disease is irregular shedding and is due to persistent corpus luteum. Regular cycles with prolonged bleeding and normal flow are present. 

Option D: Endometrial carcinoma usually presents as postmenopausal bleeding. There may be a history of PCOS or HRT indicating chronic estrogen exposure. There will be no Swiss cheese appearance on histopathological examination.

questions.text: 74. What is the engaging diameter in a face presentation with complete extension of the head?
questions.solution:
The engaging diameter in face presentation with a fully extended head is submento-bregmatic diameter which measures 9.5 cm.

questions.text:
75. A patient presented with a slow-growing, painless, pulsatile mass in the lateral aspect of the neck with an audible bruit. Carotid angiogram shows an enhancing lesion in the neck at the common carotid artery bifurcation, splaying and displacing the ICA and ECA. What is the diagnosis?

ICA: Internal Carotid Artery

ECA: External Carotid Artery
questions.solution:
The answer is carotid body tumor, also called a chemodectoma.

The given clinical scenario involves a patient presenting with a painless, slow-growing pulsatile mass in the lateral aspect of the neck, with an audible bruit. Pulsatile masses with a bruit are highly likely to be of vascular origin.

Further, on the carotid angiogram, an enhancing lesion that splays and displaces the internal and external carotid and is located at the common carotid bifurcation. These two features are highly suggestive of a carotid body tumor. The splaying of ECA-ICA is called Lyre's sign, as shown below:



Carotid body tumors are mostly benign, neurogenic tumors or paragangliomas arising from the chemoreceptor cells of the carotid bulb. They are related to catecholamine-secreting neuroendocrine tumors like pheochromocytomas and occasionally occur concurrently with them.

Familial cases are caused by mutations in the SDH gene. The pathophysiology is believed to be chronic hypoxia in high-altitude states stimulating tumorigenesis, which is why the tumor is commonly seen in individuals from hilly areas.

Clinical features are a painless, slow-growing, pulsatile lateral neck mass in the 5th decade, firm in consistency moves from side to side but not up to down. The tonsil may be displaced medially. A bruit may be associated with the tumor and sometimes the mass can be emptied and slow refilling occurs.

Investigation of choice is a CECT as explained above. FNAC is absolutely contraindicated. The Shamblin classification is utilized to assess the resectability of these tumors. being benign tumors, the need for operative management must be properly established, in some unresectable cases, a bypass may be established.

Other Options:

Option A: Glomus jugulare arises from the dome of the jugular bulb and invades the hypotympanum and jugular foramen, presenting as a blanching mass in the middle ear causing pulsatile tinnitus. It can cause X, XI, XII, and IX cranial nerve palsies. It is also a paraganglioma just like carotid body tumors. 

Option C: Cavernous hemangiomas are usually benign tumors consisting of large dilated blood vessels filled with blood. They are often infiltrative and are found in the liver. CNS cavernous hemangiomas are associated with VHL gene mutations. They are not found in the carotid body.

Option D: Hemangioendothelioma is a borderline vascular neoplasm occurring in adults around medium to large-sized veins. Clinical presentation is very variable and even after excision, recurrence rates are high. Plump cuboidal neoplastic cells are seen to line vascular channels on histopathology.

questions.text: 76. Identify the true statement regarding kidney transplantation from a live donor.

choices.text: Donor's renal artery is end-to-end anastomosed  with internal iliac artery
Donor's renal vein is end-to-end anastomosed  with internal iliac vein
It is a type of orthotopic organ transplantation
The external iliac artery is used more commonly for live donor kidneys

questions.solution:
In a live donor kidney transplantation, the donor's renal artery is end-to-end anastomosed with the internal iliac artery.

In the kidney transplant,

* The renal vein is anastomosed end-to-side to the common or external iliac vein.

* In the case of a cadaveric donor, the renal artery is anastomosed end-to-side to the common or external iliac artery.

* In the case of a living donor, as the renal artery lacks an aortic patch, it may be preferable to anastomose the donor artery end-to-end to the recipient's internal iliac artery.

The below image shows the different types of anastomosis in kidney transplantation from live and deceased donors.



The iliac fossa, in the retroperitoneal position, is the usual site for kidney transplantation, making it a heterotopic type of transplantation. The diseased kidney is left in situ.

In orthotopic graft/transplantation, the graft is placed in its normal anatomical site. However, in heterotopic graft/transplantation, the graft is placed at a site different from its normal anatomical site.

questions.text:
77. A 48-year-old man presented with complaints of diarrhea for the past 3 days. On examination, he is tachypneic. His laboratory investigations are given below. What is the acid-base disorder in this patient?

pH | 7.2 pCO2 | 20 mmHg HCO3- | 7 mEq/L Cl- | 120 mEq/L Na+ | 135 mEq/L

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with increased anion gap

questions.solution:
The acid-base disorder in this patient is metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap.

Diagnosis can be arrived at by the following steps:

Step 1: A pH of 7.20 indicates acidosis. The normal pH is 7.35-7.45. 

Step 2: Bicarbonate level of 7 mEq/L (normal = 22-28) together with low pH indicates that acidosis is due to loss of bicarbonate (i.e. base). Hence this is metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: PCO2 levels of 20 mmHg indicate respiratory alkalosis. The decrease in PCO2 with a decrease in pH indicates that it is a compensatory mechanism. Hence the patient has metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation.

Assessing the anion gap:

AG=( Na+)- {(Cl-)+(HCO3-)}

=135-(120+7)

=8 mEq/L

The normal anion gap is 6-12 mEq/L. Hence the anion gap is within the normal range.

Diarrhea causes metabolic acidosis due to intestinal loss of bicarbonate-rich fluid.

Other options:

Option B: Metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap is seen if the anion gap is >12 mEq/L. It occurs in conditions such as methanol poisoning, uremia, diabetic ketoacidosis, paracetamol poisoning, lactic acidosis, salicylate poisoning, etc. 

Option C: Respiratory acidosis occurs in conditions in which decreased ventilation (hypoventilation) increases the concentration of carbon dioxide in the blood and decreases the blood's pH. 

Option D: Lactic acidosis causes a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Pearl PM2409: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component | Normal Range | Optimal Value pH | 7.35 - 7.45 | 7.4 HCO3- | 22 - 28 mEq/L | 24 mEq/L pCO2 | 35 - 45 mmHg | 40 mmHg Anion gap | 6 - 12 mEq/L | <10 mEq/L O2 saturation | > 95% pO2 | 75 - 100 mmHg

Pearl PM1343: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic. A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: 78. The image given below is a lung resected during an autopsy of a patient with a history of chronic productive cough and recurrent chest infections. Which of the following is the corresponding finding on the radiographic image?
questions.solution:
The given image of the lung shows dilated bronchi in the lower lobes of a patient with a history of chronic productive cough and recurrent chest infections, suggesting the most probable diagnosis to be Bronchiectasis. Signet ring sign is the most characteristic radiological sign seen in bronchiectasis.

Bronchiectasis is a disorder in which destruction of smooth muscle and elastic tissue by inflammation stemming from persistent or severe infections leads to permanent dilation of bronchi and bronchioles. The bronchi and bronchioles are abnormally dilated, sometimes up to four times their normal size and can often be traced to the pleural surface. On cut section, they appear cystic and filled with mucopurulent secretions, especially in the lower lobes.

Bronchiectasis typically presents with a chronic productive cough, thick sputum, and crackles or wheezing on exam, often accompanied by airflow obstruction and occasional digital clubbing. Chest CT is the imaging modality of choice for the diagnosis of bronchiectasis. 

CT findings include 

* Signet-ring sign where the internal diameter of the bronchus is greater than that of the adjacent pulmonary artery

* Tram-track appearance

* Lack of bronchial tapering

* Tree-in-bud pattern which occurs due to the thickening of the dilated airways along with the inspissated secretions.

* Cysts originating from the bronchial wall (pronounced in cystic bronchiectasis)

The image given below shows the signet ring sign (arrows) seen in bronchiectasis:



Management includes antibiotic therapy, improved secretion clearance, bronchial hygiene, and anti-inflammatory therapy. In select cases, surgery can be considered, with resection of a focal area of suppuration. In advanced cases, lung transplantation can be considered.

Other options:

Option A: Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP) presents with patchy consolidative opacities near the subpleural region. A distinctive feature is the peribronchiolar/perilobar opacities, which are surrounded by a rim of subpleural sparing, known as the reverse halo sign. The image below demonstrates the reverse halo sign:



Option C: Westermark sign is seen in pulmonary embolism. It is defined by a hyper-lucent area with decreased vascularity due to reduced blood supply to the involved part of the lung (oligemia on the right upper lung) as shown below:



Option D: Air crescent sign is seen in aspergilloma.  Here, the fungal ball can be seen as an intracavitary mass surrounded by a crescent of air as shown below:



Pearl PM1165: Types of Bronchiectasis

Cylindrical/Tubular | Saccular/Varicose | Cystic * Mildest form of bronchiectasis

* Loss of normal airway tapering

* Bronchi have a uniform calibre, have parallel walls tram track sign and signet ring sign | * Further distortion of the airway wall along with more mucous and sputum production

* Beaded bronchi with interspersed sites of relative narrowing | * Most severe form of bronchiectasis and least common

* This form has large air spaces and a honeycombed appearance

* Air fluid levels present

questions.text: 79. The phase of skin graft uptake in which the cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses is known as:
questions.solution:
The phase of skin graft uptake in which the cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses is known as inosculation. It is the period during which the graft is most at risk for failure. 

Split skin graft survives the transplantation surgery by the following process:

* The graft survives the first 48 hours because of the imbibition of plasma from the wound bed.

* After 48 hours, fine anastomotic connections are made, which leads to the inosculation of blood.

* Neovascularization is the process by which new blood vessels formed will directly invade the graft and restore the pink color of the skin.

Pearl PM2297: Skin Grafting : Phases of Graft Uptake

Skin graft uptake occurs in three phases:

* Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): During the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from the host bed capillaries.

* Inosculation: Cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses.

* Neovascularization: Blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft.

Sensations return to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, followed by light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: Some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition, revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced with fibroblasts by day 7).

questions.text: 80. Which of the following structures is derived from the part labelled as X?

choices.text: Upper part of the head of the pancreas

questions.solution:
The part labelled as X is the ventral pancreatic bud. The uncinate process is derived from the ventral pancreatic bud.

The ventral pancreatic bud arises in close relation to the hepatic bud, in the inferior angle between the hepatic bud and the duodenum. It grows between the two layers of the ventral mesentery of the duodenum. It is smaller than the dorsal bud and appears later than the dorsal bud. The lower part of the head of the pancreas is also derived from the ventral pancreatic bud.

The dorsal pancreatic bud is the first to appear (at about the 4th week of gestation) and is larger when compared to the ventral bud. It grows between the two layers of the dorsal mesentery of the duodenum and is cephalic to the ventral bud. The upper part of the head, neck, body and tail are derived from the Dorsal pancreatic bud

The dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds arise from the dorsal and ventral walls of the terminal part of the foregut, respectively, before rotation of the midgut, caudal to the hepatic bud.



Change in the position of the pancreatic buds:

* The ventral pancreatic bud is on the ventral aspect, and the dorsal pancreatic bud is on the dorsal aspect of the duodenum before rotation of the duodenal loop.

* With the rotation of the duodenal loop to the right, the ventral pancreatic bud, along with the primitive bile duct, comes to the right, and the dorsal bud comes to the left of the duodenum. 

* The attachment of the ventral pancreatic bud along with the primitive bile duct (hepatic bud derivative) shifts to the left, moving closer to the dorsal pancreatic bud due to the differential growth of the wall of the gut

questions.text: 81. A 3 year old child visited the clinic with his parents with a complaint of decreased hearing. On examination, the patient has typical teeth as shown in the image. Which of the following drugs, if administered to the mother during pregnancy, would have prevented this condition in the child?
questions.solution:
The child's hearing loss and dental anomalies as shown in the image (Hutchinson’s Teeth) suggest congenital syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum. If a mother has untreated syphilis during pregnancy, it can be transmitted to the fetus. Penicillin G is the recommended treatment for preventing congenital syphilis when given to the mother during pregnancy. 

The image shows peg-shaped upper incisors, which is a part of the triad of stigmata for congenital syphilis i.e., Hutchinson’s Triad, which comprises of Hutchinson’s teeth, interstitial keratitis and sensorineural deafness. It is seen as a late feature of congenital Syphilis. Congenital syphilis with onset of clinical manifestations after 2 years is termed as late congenital syphilis.

Parenteral penicillin G is the only effective treatment for congenital syphilis, syphilis during pregnancy, and neurosyphilis.

Treatment of syphilis during pregnancy:

* Early syphilis - Benzathine penicillin G, 2.4 million units intramuscularly as a single injection; some recommend a second dose 1 week later to help prevent congenital syphilis.

* Late syphilis (> 1 year duration) - Benzathine penicillin G, 2.4 million units intramuscularly weekly for three doses.

Treatment of neurosyphilis:

* Aqueous crystalline penicillin G, 3–4 million units intravenously every 4 hours for 10–14 days.

* Procaine penicillin, 2.4 million units intramuscularly daily, plus probenecid 500 mg orally four times daily, both for 10–14 days.

Other Options:

Option A: Doxycycline is an antibiotic that is not recommended during pregnancy due to potential harm to the developing fetus, such as teeth discoloration and bone growth issues. Furthermore, doxycycline is not the appropriate treatment for syphilis.

Option B: Azithromycin is an antibiotic used for a variety of infections, including respiratory infections and certain sexually transmitted diseases like chlamydia. However, azithromycin is not effective for syphilis, and it is not a recommended treatment for syphilis in pregnancy.

Option C: Ceftriaxone is a broad-spectrum antibiotic often used to treat infections like gonorrhea or meningitis, but it is not effective against Treponema pallidum. Thus, it would not have prevented congenital syphilis.

Pearl PM2031: Features of congenital syphilis

| Early feature | Late feature Birth weight | Low birth weight may be <2500g | Mucocutaneous | Snuffles Maculopapular rash Pustules Mucous patches Condyloma lata Vesiculobullous lesions Rhagades Desquamation Alopecia | Rhagades Gummata Palatal perforation Dental | | Mulberry molars Hutchison's triad: It is characteristic of congenital syphilis. The components are: Hutchinson's teeth, Interstitial keratitis and Sensorineural deafness Laryngeal | Hoarse cry | Ocular | Chorioretinitis Uveitis Glaucoma | Interstitial keratitis Uveitis Glaucoma Gastro-intestinal | Hepatosplenomegaly Pancreatitis Enteritis | Renal | Nephritis Oedema & ascites | Lymphatics | Lymphadenopathy | Hematological | Thrombocytopenia Anemia Disseminated intravascular coagulation | CNS | Aseptic meningitis Chronic meningovascular syphilis Cranial nerve palsies Hydrocephalus | Mental delay VIII nerve deafness Convulsion disorders Paresis & paralysis Tabes Dorsalis Skeletal | Periostitis Osteochondritis causing pseudoparalysis Osteitis | Periostitis causing frontal & parietal bossing Sabre tibia, scaphoid scapula Thickening of the medial part of the clavicle Short maxilla & protuberant mandible Saddle nose Clutton's joint

Pearl PM2340: Stages of syphilis

Primary syphilis:

* Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.

* Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes

* Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:



* A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.

* C & D: Condyloma lata.

* E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia

* F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.

* G: Pigmentary plaques

* H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions

* Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

* Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor

* Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  

* CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta

* CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

* Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection

* Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection

Hutchinson’s triad is a triad of stigmata seen characteristically in congenital syphilis.

Components are as follows:

* Hutchinson's teeth

* Interstitial keratitis

* Sensorineural deafness (not conductive deafness)

questions.text: 82. A 15 year old patient with newly diagnosed type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). After stabilization, the doctor plans to start an insulin regimen for long-term blood glucose control. Which of the following statements about insulin therapy is correct?

choices.text: Insulin detemir has prolonged action due to subcutaneous zinc crystallization
Insulin glargine can not be mixed with other short acting insulin preparations
NPH insulin is a clear solution and can be distinguished from analog insulins by its transparency
Insulin glargine must be administered at the same time daily to avoid accumulation

questions.solution:
The correct statement is option B- Glargine can not be mixed with other short-acting insulin preparations.

Insulin glargine is a long-acting insulin analogue formulated as a clear solution at an acidic pH (around 4.0) to stabilize its hexameric form. Subcutaneous injection into the neutral pH environment of the body results in the formation of microprecipitates, leading to slow and prolonged absorption over 24 hours. Because of its acidic pH, insulin glargine must not be mixed with other insulins, especially short-acting insulins that are formulated at neutral pH. Mixing would cause precipitation or alter the pharmacokinetics.

Other options:

Option A: Insulin detemir is an insulin analogue that prolongs its action by binding to albumin via its fatty acid chain. In contrast, NPH insulin prolongs its action through subcutaneous zinc crystallization combined with protamine.

Option C: NPH insulin is a suspension of native insulin complexed with zinc and protamine in a phosphate buffer. This produces a cloudy or whitish solution, and is not as clear as other insulin solutions. 

Option D: Insulin glargine may be administered at any time during the day with equivalent efficacy, as it does not accumulate after several injections.

questions.text: 83. A child with severe mental retardation was found to have a total absence of myelin in the central nervous system. Laboratory investigations reveal the accumulation of galactosylceramide. Which of the following enzymes is deficient in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Krabbe’s disease and the enzyme deficient in this disease is β-galactosidase. 

Sphingolipidoses are a group of lysosomal storage disorders characterized by the accumulation of sphingolipids. Krabbe’s disease is an autosomal-recessive sphingolipidosis. It is a neurodegenerative disorder that occurs due to a deficiency in β-galactosidase.

Galactosylceramide is the main content in a myelin sheath. It is synthesized by oligodendrocytes and Schwann cells by galactosylation of ceramide. It is broken down by the enzyme β-galactosidase, a lysosomal hydrolase.

In Krabbe’s disease due to deficiency of the enzyme β-galactosidase, galactosylceramide accumulates in oligodendrocytes and Schwann cells. This accumulation causes the formation of globoid cells (hematogenous often-multinucleated macrophages containing undigested galactosylceramide). This results in the destruction of oligodendroglia and hence total loss of myelin in the central nervous system.

The image given below shows globoid cells seen in Krabbe's disease.



It is characterized by mental retardation, irritability, tonic spasms with light or noise stimulation, seizures, hypertonia, and later flaccidity. Optic atrophy is also present. Investigations reveal increased protein in the CSF.

Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation has been found to be effective as a treatment modality for Krabbe's disease.

questions.text: 84. Which of the following patients will be diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition?

choices.text: A 9 month old with MUAC of 12 cms
A 7 month old with weight for age below -3 standard deviations
A 6 month old with bilateral pedal edema
A 5 month old with MUAC of 11 cms

questions.solution:
A 6-month-old child with bilateral pedal edema is diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition. 

A child is diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition if any one of the following is present:

* Weight-for-height/length < –3 Z scores of the WHO child growth standards.

* Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) < 11.5 cm.

* Bilateral pitting edema (nutritional edema, usually starting in the feet/legs).

In children aged less than 6 months, MUAC is not used as a criterion for diagnosing SAM. 

Other options:

Option A: A 9-month-old child with MUAC of 12 cm has moderate malnutrition, not severe acute malnutrition. 

Option B: This is an incorrect option since for the diagnosis of SAM, the criteria include weight for height/length and not weight for age. A weight for age < 3 standard deviation indicates that the child is severely underweight, not severe acute malnutrition.

Option D: At 5 months, MUAC alone is not a valid indicator for SAM. Other assessments, like weight-for-length, would be needed. MUAC is only recommended in children aged 6–59 months.

questions.text: 85. The finding in the below-given image is seen in a case of:
questions.solution:
The image findings show Hollenhorst plaques are seen in central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO).

They are the cholesterol emboli seen in retinal arterioles. The most common cause of CRAO (Central retinal artery occlusion) is embolism.

The outer retina is supplied by the ciliary arteries, while the inner retina is supplied by the central retinal artery (CRA). Both sets of arteries are branches of the ophthalmic artery. Arterial occlusion can occur due to atherosclerosis (most cases), inflammation, vasospasm, and hypotension.

The ophthalmic artery is the first branch of the internal carotid artery, so any emboli from the carotid arteries can lead to CRAO. 

The emboli that are refractile, yellow-white in color, and made of cholesterol are called Hollenhorst plaques. Emboli can also be greyish, elongated fibrin-platelet aggregates, or non-scintillating white calcific particles. 

The goal of treatment is to restore blood flow. Antiplatelet therapy, decreasing intraocular pressure with timolol, acetazolamide and mannitol, and thrombolytic can be used. Rebreathing into a paper bag will help increase CO2 and consequently arterial vasodilation. 

Other options: 

Option B - Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) would have fundoscopy features of deep blot and flame-shaped haemorrhages in the posterior and peripheral retina, and cotton wool spots.

The image below shows flame-shaped haemorrhages in CRVO.



Option C - Cystoid macular oedema occurs when there is fluid accumulation in the outer plexiform and inner nuclear layers of the retina with cyst-like cavities. It would have fundoscopy features of loss of foveal depression, thickening of the retina, and multiple cystoid areas in the sensory retina. There may be optic disc swelling and a lamellar hole. Fundus fluoroscein angiography shows a flower petal pattern.



Option D - Central serous retinopathy is characterised by localised serous detachment of the retina at the macula due to leakage from the choriocapillaris. Detachment would be visible on fundoscopy with clear or turbid subretinal fluid, depigmented retinal pigment epithelium, and atrophic damage.

questions.text: 86. Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA) of the right ear of a patient with decreased hearing is shown below. What is the most likely combination of Weber and Rinne test results in this patient?

choices.text: Weber lateralizes to the left; Rinne positive on the right
Weber lateralizes to the right; Rinne negative on the right
Weber lateralizes to the right; Rinne positive on the right
Weber lateralizes to the left; Rinne negative on the right

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with unilateral sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) on the right side, as suggested by decreased hearing and the pure tone audiometry (PTA), which shows elevated thresholds (worse hearing) in the right ear across multiple frequencies, especially in the low and mid-range. SNHL typically presents with such findings and is associated with a positive Rinne test on the same side and Weber lateralizing to the contralateral ear (left).

Interpretation of the result:

* Red indicates the right ear.

* O indicates air conduction(AC). The threshold here is >15 dB, indicating abnormal AC

* < indicates bone conduction(BC). The threshold is >25 dB, indicating abnormal BC

* Both AC and BC are abnormal, which indicates a sensorineural hearing loss

* There is no air-bone gap

* Hence, it is right-sided sensorial hearing loss

Sensorineural hearing loss results from damage to the inner ear (cochlea) or auditory nerve. In this case, possible causes include viral infections, Ménière's disease, or acoustic neuroma. On Rinne test, air conduction (AC) > bone conduction (BC) in both ears — i.e., Rinne positive bilaterally, which is normal or sensorineural. On the Weber test, the tuning fork sound will lateralize to the better-hearing (left) ear in SNHL.

The Rinne test involves placing a vibrating tuning fork on the mastoid bone and then near the ear canal. A positive Rinne test, where air conduction is better than bone conduction, indicates normal hearing or sensorineural hearing loss. A negative Rinne test, where bone conduction is better than air conduction, indicates conductive hearing loss.

The Weber test involves placing a vibrating tuning fork on the forehead. If the sound lateralizes to one side, it can indicate either conductive hearing loss in that ear or sensorineural hearing loss in the opposite ear.



Other options:

Option B: Weber lateralizes to the right; Rinne negative on the right indicates right-sided conductive hearing loss, but the PTA shows sensorineural loss.

Option C: Weber lateralizes to the right; Rinne positive on the right indicates left-sided sensorineural hearing loss.

Pearl PM1750: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its intensity can be increased or decreased by 5dB.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:

* For AC: 15 dB

* For BC: 25 dB

questions.text: 87. A 12-year-old male presents with a 2-week history of left hip pain. On examination, he is limping and has decreased internal rotation and abduction of the left hip. His recent growth spurt has been accompanied by rapid weight gain. The x-ray is shown below. What is the most likely management to be done?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with left hip pain, along with a limp and restricted hip movement. His recent growth spurt and rapid weight gain increase the likelihood of a growth plate disorder. The x-ray reveals Trethowan’s sign, where Klein’s line fails to intersect the femoral head is suggestive of Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis (SCFE). The most likely management to be done is fixation with cannulated screws. 

In-situ pinning or percutaneous in situ screw fixation of the epiphysis to the femoral neck is the most commonly used treatment for SCFE.  They stabilise the femoral head and prevent further slippage. Forced closed reduction manoeuvres are proven to increase the risk of avascular necrosis (AVN).

SCFE is a displacement condition in which the metaphysis moves anteriorly and superiorly in relation to the epiphysis. It is commonly seen in overweight adolescents during rapid growth. It presents with progressive hip or knee pain, limping, and limited internal rotation. Left untreated, it can lead to severe complications, including AVN and early osteoarthritis. 

Clinical features:

* Pain in the thigh, groin, or knee

* On examination, the affected limb is shortened and externally rotated

* There is a limitation in abduction, flexion, and internal rotation on the affected side

Investigations:

* Trethowan's sign is seen in the X-ray

* MRI is the investigation of choice

The Klein line is a line drawn along the superior aspect of the femoral neck which normally intersects the epiphysis. In SCFE, Klein's line does not intersect the epiphysis and passes superior to it. This is known as Trethowan's sign.



Other options:

Option A and D: Russell’s traction or Thomas splint are used to treat a fractured femur, not a displacement condition like SCFE. 

Option B: Corrective osteotomy are performed for old fixed displacements or for severe slippage where in-situ pinning or percutaneous in-situ screw fixation cannot be done.

questions.text: 88. A child presents with symptoms of fever, pharyngitis, and acute follicular conjunctivitis following his return from a summer camp. After a detailed workup, he was diagnosed with pharyngoconjunctival fever. What is the nature of the causative virus?
questions.solution:
Pharyngoconjunctival fever is caused by adenovirus which is a non-enveloped, space-vehicle-shaped dsDNA virus.

Pharyngoconjunctival fever is an acute highly infectious illness with fever, pharyngitis, and acute follicular conjunctivitis with tender, enlarged preauricular adenopathy. The illness usually lasts for about 1-2 weeks followed by complete recovery. It is usually caused by serotypes 3, 7 and 14. It occurs usually, as outbreaks, in schools, summer camps, and prisons.

questions.text: 90. A 65-year-old patient presents with recurrent episodes of dizziness and syncope. The patient's ECG is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the ECG findings?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows alternating periods of sinus tachycardia followed by sinus bradycardia, which is characteristic of tachy-brady syndrome. In this ECG, the initial tachycardia is followed by a long offset pause and a junctional escape rhythm.

Tachy-brady syndrome, is a subset of sick sinus syndrome. This syndrome typically presents with symptoms such as dizziness, syncope, and palpitations due to dysfunction of the sinoatrial node, resulting in episodes of tachycardia and bradycardia. 

In this condition, tachycardia is most commonly due to atrial fibrillation (but it is not always present) with alternating symptomatic bradycardia and offset pauses. The presence of tachy-brady syndrome is an indication for pacemaker placement.

Other options: 

Option A: Brugada syndrome refers to a sodium channelopathy with a high risk of arrhythmias that can lead to sudden cardiac death. The ECG abnormality that is potentially diagnostic is a coved ST-segment elevation by >0.2 mV followed by a negative T wave in more than one anterior precordial lead (V1-V3). This has been referred to as the Brugada sign.





Option C: Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome is a congenital condition involving the presence of an abnormal accessory electrical conduction pathway called the Bundle of Kent between the atria & ventricles. ECG shows a short P-R interval <120 ms and a slurred initial upstroke of QRS complex referred to as the delta wave.



Option D: Romano-Ward syndrome is a cause of congenital long QT syndrome.

questions.text:
91. A patient is found to have reduced forced vital capacity (FVC) and increased FEV1/FVC ratio. His diffusion capacity of carbon monoxide (DLCO) is normal. Which of these conditions will you consider as possible differential diagnosis for this patient?
* Myasthenia gravis
* Interstitial lung disease
* Chronic bronchitis
* Pulmonary hemorrhage
* Massive pleural effusion
questions.solution:
A reduction in FVC and an increase in FEV1/FVC, indicates a restrictive lung disorder. The normal DLCO of the patient suggests that there is an extra-parenchymal restriction and thus, the likely diagnosis could be myasthenia gravis and massive pleural effusion.

These values are measured as a part of the pulmonary function test known as spirometry. At a given lung volume, when a person inhales to the total lung capacity and exhales as hard and completely as possible, the volume of expired air is recorded as forced vital capacity (FVC), and the volume of air expired in the first second is called the forced expiratory volume (FEV1).

Other options:

Option 2: Interstitial lung disease will show a restrictive pattern on spirometry, however the DLCO will be reduced in this condition.

Option 3: Chronic bronchitis will show an obstructive pattern with a reduction in both FVC and FEV1/FVC < 70%. It will also show a normal DLCO.

Option 4: Pulmonary hemorrhage will show a restrictive pattern on spirometry, however the DLCO will be increased in this condition.

questions.text: 92. Which of the following is the best measure to ensure enhanced recovery after a major laparoscopic surgery?
questions.solution:
Early oral hydration and nourishment and avoidance of unnecessary IV fluid administration favors the Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) protocol.

Epidural anaesthesia is used in the case of open surgery rather than in laparoscopic surgeries. As in laparoscopic surgery, the tissue trauma and wound size are smaller, and thus not recommended in laparoscopic surgery.

Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) protocol is designed to speed the patient's clinical recovery and reduce the cost and length of stay for the patient. It also includes:

* Preference for minimally invasive procedures (e.g., laparoscopic) over open procedures.

* Avoiding prolonged fasting with minimal perioperative starvation.

* Preference for local or regional anesthesia, and adequate pain control with patient-controlled analgesia. 

* Early oral hydration and nourishment, and avoidance of excessive IV fluid administration.

* Early removal of ryles tube and early feeding techniques, rather than IV fluid administration.

* Early mobilisation and planned physiotherapy. 

* Use of beta-blockers after a major surgery, as it modulates the effects of the hyperadrenergic state induced by surgical stress

* Discharge planning is started before the patient is admitted to hospital and involves support from stoma care nurses, physiotherapists etc.

questions.text: 93. A patient with fever, fatigue, recurrent infections along with petechiae and ecchymoses, and significant loss of weight underwent a peripheral smear examination as shown below. Which of the following statements does not apply to this condition?

choices.text: Marked cells can be CD23 positive
Marked cells can be myeloperoxidase positive

questions.solution:
The marked cells, which are myeloblasts, are generally not CD23 positive. CD23 is a B-lymphocyte marker.

The given clinical scenario involves a patient with symptoms suggestive of pancytopenia (fatigue-anemia, fever and infections-neutropenia, petechiae and ecchymoses-thrombocytopenia) and significant loss of weight, pointing to an underlying haematological malignancy. The peripheral smear shows characteristic myeloblasts with prominent nucleoli (yellow arrow) and Auer rods (black arrows), establishing the diagnosis of Acute Myeloid Leukaemia. 

In a peripheral smear, myeloblasts can be identified by the following characteristics: 

* Delicate nuclear chromatin

* Two to four nucleoli

* More cytoplasm than a lymphoblast

* Myeloperoxidase-positive azurophilic granules in the cytoplasm

* Azurophilic Auer rods, which are needle-shaped crystals, may be seen in the cytoplasm(black arrows)

Morphological differentiation of lymphoblast and myeloblast may become difficult; hence, immunophenotyping aids in the definitive identification of blast cells, as shown: LYMPHOBLAST | MYELOBLAST TdT+(all preB and preT lymphoblasts)

B-lineage ALL: CD19+ ,CD-10+(negative in immature B-ALL),PAX-5

T-lineage ALL: most commonly sCD3+ and also CD1, CD2, CD5, CD7. CD3 is negative in more immature tumours.

Additional marker positivity may be seen based on the degree of differentiation. | CD 34+, CD33+, CD13+,CD117+,MPO+

Based on the degree of differentiation and specific subtypes, markers may vary.

For eg, acute megakaryoblastic leukaemia subtype is CD41 and/or CD61 +

CD23+ is primarily of importance in differentiating between CLL/SLL and Mantle cell lymphoma. Both cancers are CD19+, CD20+, and CD5+, and CD23 is the differentiating marker. It is positive in CLL/SLL and usually negative in MCL.

MPO is a myeloblast marker, hence, the cells are positive for it, as are most types of AML. Only the M0 AML type is MPO negative. This case is not the M0 subtype, which will have undifferentiated cells without Auer rods.

Clinical features of acute myeloid leukaemia include:

* Fatigue due to anaemia

* Recurrent infections with opportunistic microbes like fungi, commensals, and Pseudomonads, along with fever due to neutropenia

* Mucosal and cutaneous bleeding manifestations, such as petechiae and ecchymoses, along with serosal bleeding into various body cavities due to thrombocytopenia

* Skin and gingival infiltration in specific subtypes

questions.text: 94. A young male patient came to the hospital with complaints of right-sided loin pain. The urine microscopy image is shown below. Which of the following is used in the treatment of these renal calculi?
questions.solution:
Urinary microscopy of the patient shows hexagonal crystals, which are suggestive of cystine stones. D-penicillamine can be used for treating cystine stones.

The basis of using D-penicillamine here is that it reacts with cystine to form a soluble salt that reduces the formation of cystine. It is a potentially toxic drug and should only be used if hydration and alkalinization fail.

Other options:

Option A: Acetohydroxamic acid may be considered for the treatment of struvite stone. It is a urease inhibitor. Urease enzyme generates ammonia from urea, elevating the pH of the urine and favoring the production of triple phosphate stones. However, it has to be used with caution due to the potential side effects.

Option B: Neutral orthophosphates halt the growth of existing oxalate calculi.

Option C: Allopurinol, a xanthine oxidase inhibitor, can be used to decrease uric acid production. Hence, it can be used in the treatment of uric acid renal calculi.

Pearl PM0311: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones



Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: 95. A histological cross-section of a muscle spindle is shown in the image. Identify the marked structure.
questions.solution:
In the given cross-section of a muscle spindle, the structure marked shows intrafusal muscle fibers.

Each muscle spindle is 3 to 10 mm long and consists of 3 to 12 tiny intrafusal muscle fibers that are pointed at their ends and attached to the glycocalyx of the surrounding large extrafusal muscle fibers.

The intrafusal fibers constitute the middle of the spindle and help control the basic tone of the muscle. Since there are either few or no actin and myosin filaments in the center of each fiber, the center does not contract when the ends do. It performs the role of a sensory receptor instead. The end portions that do contract are excited by small gamma(γ) motor nerve fibers which help control basic muscle tone.

Intrafusal fibers are of 2 types: (1) nuclear bag fibers, subdivided as dynamic and static nuclear bag fibers and (2) nuclear chain fibers. Intrafusal muscle fibres are innervated by gamma(γ) motor neurons. There are two types of γ motor neurons: (a) dynamic, which supply dynamic nuclear bag fibers, and (b) static, which supply static nuclear bag fibers and nuclear chain fibers.

questions.text: 96. A 6-day-old infant presents with fever, poor feeding and bulging fontanelle. During physical examination, she begins to convulse. CSF microscopy reveals bacilli that exhibit differential motility. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The infant presenting with fever, poor feeding and bulging fontanelle suggests a diagnosis of neonatal meningitis, and the bacilli exhibiting differential motility indicate the causative organism to be Listeria monocytogenes. 

This can occur due to perinatal transmission. Infants acquire infection in utero or by inoculation through an infected birth canal. Infection of pregnant women can lead to chorioamnionitis, which can lead to spontaneous abortions and stillbirths. Adults are infected due to the ingestion of contaminated food. It can also cause meningoencephalitis in the elderly.

Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive bacillus. It can grow at low refrigeration temperatures. It shows differential motility, which is that they show tumbling motility at 25°C but, at 37°C, it is non-motile as the peritrichous flagella produced by the bacillus work optimally between 20°C and 30°C. On semisolid agar, it has an umbrella-shaped growth pattern. They are facultatively intracellular and move from cell to cell using the host cell actin framework.

The most common bacterial causes of neonatal meningitis are Group B Streptococci, E. coli, L. monocytogenes, Streptococcus pneumoniae, both coagulase-positive and coagulase-negative staphylococci, and other gram-negative bacilli. Treponema pallidum and TB infection involving the central nervous system may also result in meningitis.

The diagnosis is established by a culture of L. monocytogenes from blood or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Cultures from the maternal cervix, vagina, lochia, and placenta, if possible, should be obtained when intrauterine infections lead to premature delivery or early-onset neonatal sepsis.

Some other organisms showing differential motility are Yersinia enterocolitica and Yersinia pseudotuberculosis.

Other options:

Option A: Group B streptococci, such as Streptococcus agalactiae, are known to cause neonatal meningitis. It shows beta haemolysis on blood agar. However, it does not show differential motility like Listeria monocytogenes.

Option C: Neisseria meningitidis is a gram-negative diplococcus and does not show differential motility. It is a common cause of meningitis in infants more than 1 month of age. 

Option D: Haemophilus influenzae is known to cause meningitis in age groups of two months to three years. This age incidence has been correlated with the absence of bactericidal anti-PRP antibodies. It is a pleomorphic, gram-negative bacterium.

questions.text: 97. A 45-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of severe, throbbing unilateral headaches lasting 12–24 hours, associated with nausea, vomiting, and photophobia. She has a history of myocardial infarction 3 months ago. Which of the following drugs is contraindicated for acute treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
Rizatriptan is contraindicated for the acute treatment of this patient. 

The patient is suffering from migraine, characterised by unilateral, throbbing headaches with nausea, vomiting, and photophobia lasting for 12–24 hours. Rizatriptan belongs to the class of triptans, which are contraindicated in this patient with a history of myocardial infarction. 

Rizatriptan, along with other triptans like sumatriptan and zolmitriptan, are selective 5-HT1B/1D receptor agonists. They work by causing vasoconstriction of intracranial blood vessels and inhibiting the release of pro-inflammatory neuropeptides, thus relieving migraine symptoms. 

Triptans are contraindicated in patients with a history of myocardial infarction, ischemic heart disease, cerebrovascular disease, peripheral vascular disease, or uncontrolled hypertension. This is because they can cause serious adverse effects like coronary vasospasm, transient myocardial ischemia, arrhythmias, and myocardial infarction, making them dangerous in patients with preexisting cardiovascular conditions.

Other options:

Option A: Lasmiditan is a selective serotonin 5-HT1F receptor agonist that does not cause vasoconstriction, hence safer in patients with cardiovascular disease.

Option C: Acetaminophen is an analgesic, commonly used for mild to moderate migraine attacks. It is safe to use in patients with cardiovascular disease

Option D: Rimegepant is a CGRP receptor antagonist used for acute migraine treatment. It does not cause vasoconstriction and is safe in cardiovascular patients.

questions.text: 98. A young woman with atrial fibrillation is started on unfractionated heparin. After 6 days, she complains of reddening, swelling, and severe pain in her lower limb. Her platelet count is 90,000/μL. Laboratory investigations reveal the presence of antibodies against heparin-platelet factor 4 complexes. Which of the following is the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Discontinue unfractionated heparin and start warfarin
Discontinue unfractionated heparin and start lepirudin
Reduce the dose of unfractionated heparin and start with low molecular weight heparin

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of deep vein thrombosis due to heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. The next step in the management of this patient is to discontinue unfractionated heparin and start lepirudin.

Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) results from the formation of antibodies against heparin-platelet factor 4 complexes. These antibodies also bind to the platelet Fc receptors and promote thrombosis. Features of HIT are usually seen after 5-10 days of starting heparin and are more common in females than in males. The platelet count usually drops to less than ≤100,000/μL or decreases to ≥50% compared to the levels before the initiation of heparin. The patients can also show the features of deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and acute myocardial infarction due to the extensive formation of thrombi.

Stop heparin immediately and start with parenteral direct thrombin inhibitors, such as lepirudin, argatroban, or bivalirudin, or factor Xa inhibitors, such as fondaparinux or rivaroxaban. Do not give platelet transfusions. Warfarin is not given until the platelet count returns to its baseline level.

Heparin acts by activating antithrombin. The antithrombin inhibits thrombin and factor Xa. It can be given subcutaneously or by continuous intravenous infusion. Heparin therapy requires monitoring and can be monitored using the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) or anti-factor Xa level.

Important side effects of heparin are:

* Bleeding is the most common side effect. Recent surgery, trauma, or concomitant use of antiplatelet or antifibrinolytic agents increases the risk. Serious bleeding due to heparin is treated using protamine sulfate.

* Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia

* Osteoporosis

* Modest elevations of hepatic transaminases.

Other options:

Option A: Starting platelet transfusions is incorrect. HIT is a prothrombotic disorder despite thrombocytopenia. Platelet transfusions can exacerbate thrombosis by providing additional platelets that may be activated by heparin-PF4 antibodies.

Option B: Discontinue unfractionated heparin and start warfarin is incorrect. Warfarin alone increases thrombosis risk in acute HIT due to its transient depletion of protein C and S (natural anticoagulants). Warfarin must be overlapped with a non-heparin anticoagulant (e.g., direct thrombin inhibitor) until platelets recover (>150,000/μL) to avoid catastrophic thrombosis (e.g., venous limb gangrene). Initiating warfarin without bridging is unsafe.

Option D: Reduce the dose of unfractionated heparin and start low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is incorrect. Both unfractionated heparin (UFH) and LMWH cross-react with HIT antibodies. Switching to LMWH does not mitigate the immune response and perpetuates the prothrombotic state. All heparin products must be discontinued in HIT, including LMWH.

Bivalent DTI- Lepirudin, Desirudin, Bivalirudin

Oral: Dabigatran 3) Indirect thrombin inhibitors | Unfractionated heparin

questions.text: 99. Which of the following is a contraindication for using ventouse for delivery?
questions.solution:
The contraindication to use ventouse for delivery is Brow presentation.

Ventouse is an instrumental device that assists in delivery by creating a vacuum between the cup and the fetal scalp.

Contraindications of the use of ventouse for delivery are:

* Brow presentation

* Breech presentation

* Face presentation

* Preterm fetus (< 34 weeks), as there are chances of scalp avulsion or subaponeurotic haemorrhage

* Suspected fetal coagulation disorder

* Suspected fetal macrosomia (≥ 4 kg)

Maternal indications of the use of ventouse for delivery are:

* Maternal exhaustion

* Conditions in which expulsive efforts are to be avoided, like cardiac disease, hypertensive crises, cerebrovascular diseases, and spinal cord injury

* Inadequate expulsive efforts

* Prolonged second stage of labour

* To cut short the second stage of labour in severe pre-eclampsia, cardiac disease or postcesarean pregnancy

Fetal indications of the use of ventouse for delivery are:

* Fetal distress 

* Low birth weight baby

* Postmaturity

Procedure :

* Application of the cup:

* The largest possible cup is selected

* The cup is placed at the flexion point which is against the fetal head nearer the occiput with the ‘knob’ of the cup pointing towards the occiput. Flexion or pivot point is an imaginary site located midsagittally about 6 cm from the centre of the anterior fontanel or about 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanel (as shown in the image below)

* A vacuum of 0.2 kg/cm2 is induced by the pump slowly, taking at least 2 minutes

* The pressure is gradually raised at the rate of 0.1 kg/ cm2 per minute until the effective vacuum of 0.8 kg/cm2 (608 mm Hg) is achieved in about 10 minutes.

* Traction:

* The traction is applied at a right angle to the cup and should be synchronous with the uterine contractions.

* Between the uterine contractions, the traction is released

* The traction is made using one hand along the axis of the birth canal, while the fingers of the other hand are placed against the cup to note the correct angle of traction, rotation, and advancement of the head.

Traction should be abandoned if:

* There is no descent of the presenting part with each pull

* Delivery is not imminent after three pulls.

Under any circumstances, the traction should not exceed more than 30 minutes. Once the head is delivered, the vacuum is reduced by opening the screw-release valve, and the cup is then detached.

An artificial caput succedaneum (chignon) is produced due to the sucking. It usually disappears within a few hours.

questions.text: 100. Identify the device.
questions.solution:
The device shown in the image is an Automatic Chest Compression Device.

It is an automated device that provides chest compression during cardiac arrest, without the need for human-performed manual compression. It is a mechanical cardiopulmonary resuscitation device.

The main types of mechanical cardiopulmonary resuscitation devices currently in use are:

* Pneumatic piston devices 

* Load-distributing band devices 

Advantages of mechanical cardiopulmonary resuscitation devices are:

* Allows chest compressions to be performed with consistent quality, especially in situations such as hypothermia

* Defibrillation can be safely performed during compressions

* Decreases interruptions to compressions and avoids exhaustion from prolonged manual chest compressions

* Requires fewer personnel to maintain ongoing CPR 

* Can facilitate percutaneous coronary intervention and initiation of ECMO during CPR

Disadvantages of mechanical cardiopulmonary resuscitation devices are:

* Not proven to be superior to manual compressions in major studies 

* Requires staff training and familiarity with equipment 

* Cost and availability issues

* Equipment or battery failure can lead to prolonged interruptions in CPR

* It may be ineffective for certain body types, and one size might not be suitable for all

* Prone to malpositioning over time

* Can cause patient trauma, like rib fractures

Other options:

Option A: Automated External Defibrillators are microprocessor-controlled devices that are capable of electrocardiographic analysis in differentiating shockable from nonshockable rhythms.



Option C: A Wearable Cardioverter Defibrillator is a battery-powered wearable device that has built-in defibrillators and is worn by someone at risk of sudden cardiac death. They automatically detect arrhythmias, and then they can automatically deliver a treatment shock to correct the arrhythmia and restore a normal rhythm to the heart.



Option D: Left Ventricular Assist Device drains blood from the apex of the left ventricular and, in a nonpulsatile manner, pumps oxygenated blood into the aorta, restoring blood delivery to the tissues. They are very useful in patients for whom heart transplantation can't be done.

questions.text: 101. Which of the following is likely to increase in a patient who is brought to the casualty with acute diarrhoea?
questions.solution:
A patient with diarrhoea has an increase in hematocrit as a relative change.

Dehydrating conditions such as diarrhoea, burns and vomiting, cause loss of fluid from the extracellular compartment. There is no loss from the intracellular compartment and no change in the osmolarity. ECF volume contraction therefore is reflected by a relative increase in hematocrit.

The reverse is what occurs as a physiological change in pregnancy, where ECF volume expansion is reflected as physiological anemia of pregnancy.



Diarrhoea is usually managed by volume replacement with IV fluids. Administration of normal saline, ie, isotonic fluid would similarly lead only to ECF volume expansion with no change in the ICF volume or the osmolarity.

Whenever hypertonic saline is added to the extracellular fluid (ECF), the extracellular osmolarity increases. It causes osmosis of water out of the cells into the extracellular compartment. Almost all the added sodium chloride remains in the extracellular compartment and fluid diffuses into the extracellular space to achieve osmotic equilibrium. The net effect is that the volume of ECF increases, the volume of intracellular fluid (ICF) decreases, and the osmolarity of both compartments increase. 

Whenever hypotonic saline is added to ECF, the osmolarity of ECF decreases. This leads to the movement of water from the ECF to the ICF until both attain the same osmolarity. Both the intracellular and extracellular volumes are increased by the addition of hypotonic fluid, but the intracellular volume increases to a greater extent. Osmolarity decreases in both the compartments.

* In ECF, a third specialized compartment, called the transcellular compartment (not shown in flow chart), is quantitatively small and includes the cerebrospinal, pleural, peritoneal, pericardial, synovial, intraocular and digestive fluids. Altogether it constitutes about 1-2 L.

* The ECF volume/intracellular fluid volume ratio is larger in infants and children than it is in adults, but the absolute volume of ECF in children is, of course, smaller than in adults. Therefore, dehydration develops more rapidly and is frequently more severe in children.

* All solutes and water that enter or leave the body do so via the ECF.

* The ICF and ECF are in osmotic equilibrium. Water moves between these compartments only when an osmotic pressure gradient exists.

* Equilibration of ICF and ECF osmolality occurs primarily by shifts in water and not shifts in solutes.

questions.text: 102. An adult patient presents with massive proteinuria, edema, and hematuria. The biopsy image is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and biopsy image showing uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall are suggestive of membranous glomerulonephritis.

Membranous nephropathy is a chronic immune complex–mediated disease characterized by diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall due to the accumulation of deposits containing immunglobulin. Immunofluorescence microscopy demonstrates that the granular deposits contain both immunoglobulins and complement, as shown below.



It presents as nephrotic syndrome with massive proteinuria, generalized edema, and hyperlipidemia. Hematuria, although more common in nephritic syndrome, is present in about one-third of the cases of membranous nephropathy. Most of the cases are primary. Some of the secondary causes include drugs (penicillamine, captopril, NSAIDs, gold), malignant tumors - lung, colon, and melanoma, infections like chronic hepatitis B and C, and autoimmune disorders.

Minimal change disease has negative immunofluorescence (Option D). In rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) type I and Goodpasture syndrome, immunofluorescence reveals a linear pattern (as shown below), which is a classic feature of anti–glomerular basement membrane disease (anti-GBM) disease (Option A & B).

questions.text: 103. A 57-year-old unresponsive male patient is brought to the hospital. He is pulseless and is not breathing. His lead II ECG rhythm strip is shown in the image below. What is the treatment for the given ECG abnormality?
questions.solution:
The ECG with no identifiable P wave, QRS complexes, and irregular rhythm is ventricular fibrillation (VF) and the treatment is defibrillation. 

Ventricular fibrillation is a disorganized ventricular rhythm. In a heart with ventricular fibrillation, there is little to no cardiac output as there is irregular cardiac contraction. In patients outside the hospital, sustained ventricular tachycardias are a common cause leading to ventricular fibrillation.

VF is a shockable rhythm. Thus, defibrillation must be performed in order to restore normal sinus rhythm according to advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) guidelines. In defibrillation, an electrical current is passed into the myocardium which 'resets' it by converting the dysrhythmia into a normal sinus rhythm. 

When the timing of electric current is adjusted according to the R waves or the QRS complex of the cardiac cycle, it is known as synchronized shock, which is administered in cardioversion. In ventricular fibrillation, because of irregular cardiac electrical activity, there are no R waves or QRS complexes to which the cardioversion can be synchronized. Hence, it is administered unsynchronized to the cardiac cycle.



Other options:

Option B - Magnesium sulfate is used to treat torsades de pointes. It is a type of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. 

Options C and D - Synchronised cardioversion and rate control are used to treat atrial fibrillation (AF). AF has normal QRS complexes with variable atrial activity resulting in irregular P waves of varying morphology.

questions.text: 104. A patient was brought to the emergency room following blunt trauma to his abdomen while playing sports. CT scan showed retroperitoneal hematoma. Trauma to which zone of retroperitoneum should always be explored surgically?
questions.solution:
Zone 1 injury should always be treated surgically.

Retroperitoneum is divided into 3 zones, based on the types of viscera and their differential management in blunt trauma.

The image given below shows the different zones of the retroperitoneum.



Zone 1 | Central | Always explored, after proximo-distal vascular control Zone 2 | Lateral | Only explored if the hematoma is pulsatile or expanding, else conservative/ angioembolization Zone 3 | Pelvic | Only explored if the hematoma is pulsatile or expanding, else conservative/ angioembolization

If there is a penetrative injury in any of the zones, surgical management is done.

Mattox maneuver is left medial visceral rotation to expose the aorta. The Cattell-Braasch maneuver is done by right medial visceral rotation to expose the inferior vena cava.

questions.text:
105. A cow-herder who was diagnosed with interstitial pneumonia soon after assisting in the birthing of his newborn calf now presented with fever and acute onset of valvular regurgitation twelve months after his pneumonia episode. On TEE, vegetations were noted on the valve, but serial blood cultures were negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?

TEE: Transesophageal echocardiography
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Q- fever.

The given clinical vignette describes a cowherd who was diagnosed with interstitial pneumonia soon after helping in the birthing of a newborn calf. This implies that the illness may be zoonosis associated with the parturition of animals.

Twelve months after the pneumonia episode, the patient presented with fever and new-onset valvular regurgitation, which prompted a transesophageal ECHO showing vegetation. This history is suggestive of infective endocarditis (IE), for which serial blood cultures are drawn and are negative. This implies a culture-negative cause for IE.

Q-fever or query fever is caused by the pathogen Coxiella burnetti, which is a small, pleomorphic, gram-negative coccobacillus that was previously thought to be a Rickettsia but now has its own genus. It can be found in ticks, but it is a zoonosis transmitted to humans either through inhalation of aerosols or through contaminated milk.

It is an occupational hazard among abattoir workers, shepherds, cowherds, and other individuals in close contact with animals, especially during or immediately after their parturition. Acute Q-fever presents with nonspecific signs and symptoms, such as fever, cough, vomiting, diarrhoea, photophobia, pneumonia, and less commonly anaemias, myocarditis, etc

The disease can result in a state of chronic fatigue called "Q-fever fatigue syndrome". Chronic Q-fever tends to occur months or years after the initial infection and can manifest as Q-fever endocarditis, infected prosthesis, infected aneurysms, and bone infections.

On TEE, endothelium-covered nodules are seen as vegetations on the valves, and new-onset valve regurgitation may be seen. Diagnosis requires a high index of clinical suspicion due to non-specific features and must be considered in all cases of culture-negative endocarditis.

Diagnostic methods include culture, which requires a level 3 biosafety cabinet, and hence is not done in routine practice or by DNA detection using PCR. IFA(indirect fluorescent antibody test) is the most preferred test that identifies antibodies and can differentiate acute and chronic infections.

The treatment of choice is with doxycycline, which may be substituted for trimethoprim-sulphamethoxazole in pregnancy. Doxycycline is given for acute Q-fever as 100mg BD for 14 days. For chronic Q-fever, doxycycline + hydroxychloroquine is given. Minimum treatment for native valve endocarditis is 18 months.

Due to the low minimum infective dose of Coxiella, it is a bioterrorism agent Category B.

Other Options:

Option B: Oroya fever is caused by Bartonella bacilliformis and manifests as fever and progressive anaemia due to bacterial infiltration of RBCs. Verruga peruana is are warts seen in this condition. It is also called Carrion's disease.

Option C: Trench fever is an exclusively human disease transmitted by the body louse. There is no zoonosis. It is associated with unhygienic conditions like wars and slum areas. It is also termed five-day fever and is caused by Bartonella quintana.

Option D: Endemic typhus is caused by Rickettsia typhi and transmitted by Xenopsylla, the flea. The reservoir of the infection is rats. It is a mild sporadic fever that is not of great public health importance. The disease presents with fever and chills. A characteristic rash appears on the fourth or fifth day, which starts on the trunk and spreads over the limbs but spares the face, palms and soles. By the second week, the patient becomes stuporous and delirious.
