questions.text: 106. An elderly patient with known cardiovascular disease presents with sudden onset vertigo. Suspecting a central cause of vertigo, which of the following features distinguishes lateral pontine syndrome from lateral medullary syndrome?

choices.text: Contralateral loss of pain and temperature over body
Ipsilateral lower motor neuron facial paralysis

questions.solution:
Ipsilateral lower motor neuron facial paralysis is seen in lateral pontine syndrome and helps differentiate it from lateral medullary syndrome.

Lateral pontine syndrome occurs due to occlusion of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery. The presence of complete ipsilateral facial palsy indicates an LMN lesion, which in turn points towards lateral pontine syndrome. If ipsilateral upper facial muscles are spared, this would indicate a UMN lesion, which in turn points towards lateral medullary syndrome.

Ipsilateral manifestations of lateral pontine syndrome include:

* CN VII: Lower motor neuron facial paralysis

* CN V: loss of pain and temperature sensation over the face.

* Vestibular nerve or nucleus: Horizontal and vertical nystagmus, vertigo, nausea, vomiting, oscillopsia.

* Auditory nerve or cochlear nerve: Deafness, tinnitus.

* Middle cerebellar peduncle: Ataxia of limb and gait.

* Descending sympathetic tract: Horner’s syndrome (miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis).

Contralateral manifestations of lateral pontine syndrome include loss of pain and temperature sensation over the body due to lateral spinothalamic tract involvement.

Occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery causes lateral medullary syndrome or Wallenberg syndrome. The clinical findings correspond to the neuroanatomical structures affected in the lateral portion of the medulla:

* Descending tract and nucleus of CN V (trigeminal)- loss of pain and sensation over the ipsilateral half of the face.

* Inferior cerebellar peduncle – ipsilateral ataxia (gait and limb)

* Lateral spinothalamic tract – loss of pain and temperature sensation over the contralateral half of the body.

* IX and X CN - ipsilateral paralysis of the palate, vocal cord, diminished gag reflex giving rise to dysphagia, dysarthria.

* Vestibular nucleus - nystagmus, vertigo, nausea

* Descending sympathetic tract – ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome (miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis)

* Genuflected upper motor neuron fibers to ipsilateral facial nucleus: ipsilateral weakness of lower face

questions.text: 107. A patient was started on the EMA-CO regimen after being diagnosed with choriocarcinoma with a WHO risk score of 8. Which of the following drugs does not form a part of this regimen?
questions.solution:
EMA-CO regimen for choriocarcinoma does not include Adriamycin.

The given vignette describes a case of choriocarcinoma which underwent WHO risk assessment with a risk score of 8. A score of >6 necessitates multidrug chemotherapy. One of the most commonly used regimens for multidrug therapy is the EMA-CO regimen. The regimen constituents are given below:

* Etoposide(Option D)

* Methotrexate 

* Actinomycin-D/Dactinomycin(Option B)

* Cyclophosphamide

* Oncovin/Vincristine(Option A)

The drugs are given in cycles, and beta HCG is monitored until it falls sufficiently. The toxicities associated with this regimen are detailed here. Etoposide is associated with neutropenia, myelosuppression, and alopecia. Methotrexate is associated with myelosuppression, mucositis, renal toxicity, and acute cerebral dysfunction. Leucovorin(Folinic acid) must be concomitantly given with methotrexate to prevent low folate levels in the body.

Dactinomycin can cause myelosuppression, skin ulceration and necrosis on extravasation. It has potent GI side effects such as diarrhoea and vomiting. Alopecia is often seen.  Cyclophosphamide is most notable for hemorrhagic cystitis, managed with Mesna. Vincristine is known to cause dose-related neurotoxicity, such as peripheral neuropathy and mild myelosuppression.

The WHO risk score, which is used to decide the treatment for gestational trophoblastic neoplasia, is given below: SCORES | 0 | 1 | 2 | 4 Age | Less than 40 | More than 40 | - | - Antecedent pregnancy | Mole | Abortion | Term | - Interval after an Index pregnancy

(months) | <4 | 4-6 | 7-12 | >12 Pretreatment serum beta-HCG | <103 | 103-104 | 104-105 | >105 Largest tumour size | <3cm | 3-4cm | 5cm or more | Site of Mets | - | Spleen, Kidney | GI | Liver, Brain No of Mets | - | 1-4 | 5-8 | >8 Previous failed chemo | - | - | 1 | 2 or more

Based on the score, the treatment is as follows:

* Low-risk GTN (score 0-6): Single-agent chemotherapy with methotrexate (MTX). 50 mg MTX is given IM on days 1, 3, 5, and 7, with folinic acid on alternate days 

* High-risk GTN (score 7 or more): Multi-agent chemotherapy, with or without adjuvant surgery or radiotherapy. The preferred multiple-agent regime is the EMACO regime.

Pearl PM0945: Risk factors and FIGO staging of Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia

Risk factors

* Older age

* β-hCG levels > 100,000 mIU/mL

* Uterine size that is large-forgestational age

* Theca-lutein cysts > 6 cm

* Slow decline in β-hCG levels

* Postevacuation uterine sonographic surveillance showing myometrial nodules or hypervascularity may be a predictor of subsequent neoplasia.

FIGO staging: Stage I | Disease confined to the uterus Stage II | GTD extends outside of the uterus but is limited to the genital structure Stage III | Lung metastasis with or without genital tract involvement Stage IV | Other metastasis

questions.text: 108. A 14-year-old girl with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections came with frequent urination. Her micturating cystourethrogram shows a 'spinning top' urethra, it is seen due to ________
questions.solution:
A spinning top urethra seen on cystourethrogram is due to a dilated urethra with bladder instability.

This condition is usually seen in females. The voiding cystourethrography shows a dilated urethra and a narrowed bladder neck with bladder wall hypertrophy. Inadequate relaxation of the external urinary sphincter results in this urethral finding.

The patient presents with recurrent urinary tract infections, enuresis and increased urgency. The condition may be managed with timed voiding and Kegel exercises.

Other options:

Option A: Ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the terminal ureter and is obstructive because of a pinpoint ureteral orifice.

Option C: Ectopic ureter is a ureter that drains outside the bladder.

Option D: Ureteropelvic junction obstruction is characterised by hydronephrosis and dilated ureter, depending upon the level of obstruction.

questions.text: 110. A young lady returning from a 3-week trip to the Mississippi River valley presented with palatal ulcers and red bumps on her shin. She has a mild flu-like illness. CXR showed pulmonary infiltrates with mediastinal lymphadenopathy. At room temperature, her sputum specimen culture revealed the following. On direct histopathological staining of the infected tissue sample, the causative organism would be seen as:
questions.solution:
Direct histopathological staining of the infected tissue sample would show narrow-based budding within macrophages.

The clinical vignette suggests a systemic granulomatous disease-Histoplasmosis, caused by a dimorphic fungus, Histoplasma capsulatum. The image given in the question shows characteristic tuberculate macroconidia forms in culture at 25 degrees Celsius.

It is endemic in the USA, particularly in the Ohio River Valley and Mississippi River Valley. The mode of transmission is the inhalation of spores, which usually circulate in the air after contaminated soil is disturbed. It is associated with bat droppings, especially in caves. Palatal ulcers and erythema nodosum can also be seen.

Histopathological staining of the specimens reveals tiny oval yeast cells (2–4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response is given below.



Culture - It is the gold standard method of diagnosis. Specimens should be inoculated onto media such as SDA, blood agar, and BHI agar in duplicate and incubated simultaneously at 25°C and 37°C. 

At 25°C, it forms a mycelial phase and produces white to buff brown colonies that consist of two types of conidia or spores - tuberculate macroconidia (with typical thick walls and finger-like projections, which is a characteristic feature) and microconidia( smaller, thinner, and smooth-walled). At 37°C, it gets converted into yeast form (creamy white colonies), which is best developed in special media like Kelley’s media.

Liposomal amphotericin B is the antifungal agent of choice in acute pulmonary and disseminated histoplasmosis. Itraconazole is recommended for chronic cavitary pulmonary histoplasmosis.

Other options:

Option A: Cigar-shaped yeast is seen in the microscopy of Sporothrix schenckii.

Option B: Broad-based budding yeast is seen in Blastomyces.

Option D: Spherules with endospores are seen in Coccidoides.

Pearl PM2370: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings





1. Histoplasma:

* Mycelial growth showing spherical spores, which are large (8-10 μm size) and thick-walled, with tubercular projections.

* Tiny oval yeast cells (2-4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.



2. Blastomyces: Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)



3. Coccidoides: Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20-80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.



4. Paracoccidioides: Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: 111. A patient with convulsions was brought to the emergency department. He had ingested a herbal medicine containing Strychnos nux vomica about 30 minutes back. Which of the following steps is incorrect about the management of this patient?

choices.text: Alkalization of urine to improve the excretion of strychnine
Keep the patient in a dark room, free from noise
Use of activated charcoal to adsorb strychnine

questions.solution:
Alkalization of urine to improve the excretion of strychnine is an incorrect statement about the management of this patient. Acidification of urine increases the excretion of strychnine.

The first step in the management of strychnine poisoning is to control convulsions with benzodiazepines or barbiturates to control seizures, and the patients should be placed in a dark room, free from noise and disturbance, to avoid triggering further convulsions. Short-acting barbiturates like pentobarbital sodium or sodium amytal can be given as they are antidotes for strychnine.

Activated charcoal can be used to adsorb unabsorbed poison after a thorough stomach wash with potassium permanganate. Ether can also be administered between the convulsions.  Acidification of urine can be done to increase the excretion of strychnine.

Strychnos nux vomica causes strychnine poisoning when one crushed seed or 50-100 mg is consumed. The patient usually presents with convulsions that are clonic initially but eventually become tonic. Risus sardonicus, opisthotonus, pleurothotonus and emprosthotonos can also be seen in the patient. Hypoxia causes medullary paralysis and death.

Pearl PM0900: Signs and Symptoms of Strychnine Poisoning

The clinical features of strychnine poisoning are:

* Convulsions - clonic-tonic type

* Reflex increased

* Awful taste

* Mind is conscious

* Pupils dilated

* Opisthotonos: arching back

* Emprosthotonos: arching forward

* Pleurothotonus: bending sideward

* Risus Sardonicus - fixed contraction of the facial muscles resulting in a peculiar distorted grin.

Strychnine poisoning case may resemble tetanus.

Although a poison, in relatively low doses it can be used as a medical stimulant for respiration.

Strychnine plant



Strychnine seeds

questions.text:
112. A 24-year-old resident sustains a needlestick injury from a blood-contaminated hollow-bore needle while inserting a central line in a patient with suspected HIV. He reports to the ART center within 90 minutes. What is the most appropriate next step for HIV PEP?

ART-Anti Retroviral Therapy, PEP- Post Exposure Prophylaxis

choices.text: Start 2-drug PEP now; add a third drug if source tests HIV-positive
Delay 3-drug PEP until the source tests HIV-positive
Start 3-drug PEP immediately; complete the 28 days course
Start 2-drug PEP immediately; complete the 14 days course

questions.solution:
Needlestick injuries involving hollow-bore, blood-contaminated needles pose the highest risk of HIV transmission in healthcare settings. When the source patient’s HIV status is unknown but there's high suspicion based on clinical indicators, post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) must not be delayed. Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) should be initiated when there is a high-risk exposure and the source is HIV-positive or of unknown status. 

PEP for HIV should be initiated as early as possible, ideally within 2 hours of exposure, and no later than 72 hours. The decision to begin PEP must be based on clinical risk assessment and should not be delayed while waiting for ELISA or other test results from the source. The preferred 3 drug regimen is Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir (TDF + 3TC + DTG), to be continued for 28 days.

During follow-up, while testing at 4–6 weeks (end of PEP) may indicate early seroconversion if highly sensitive antibody assays are used, this is not sufficient due to the potential delay in seroconversion caused by PEP itself. Hence, repeat HIV testing must be conducted at 3 months and again at 6 months post-exposure to rule out infection.

Other options:

Option A: 2-drug PEP is incorrect as current guidelines recommend starting 3 drugs rather than 2 drugs immediately.

Option B: A delay in initiating the prophylaxis may increase the chances of seroconversion.

Option D: This option is incorrect as the recommended regimen includes 3 drugs and the duration is 28 days.

questions.text: 113. A 25-year-old sportsperson presents with pain in the left knee after sustaining an injury while playing football. You observe the resident performing the following test on this patient. The test which is being done is_____
questions.solution:
The test done in the image is Apley's test, it is used to detect injuries to the menisci and it is done with the patient lying in the prone position.

Apley's test: This test is done with the patient prone, the knee is flexed to 90  degrees and rotated while a compression force is applied, which is called the grinding test. This reproduces symptoms if a meniscus is torn. Rotation is then repeated while the leg is pulled upwards by the doctor, holding the thigh down, which is called the distraction test. This produces increased pain only if there is ligament damage.



Other options:

McMurray's test: This test is used to detect injuries to the menisci. The patient is positioned in a supine posture with the knee fully flexed. The knee joint is stabilized and palpated using one hand, while the other hand is utilized to internally and externally rotate the leg. Gradual extension of the leg is performed during this examination. If there is any detectable clicking sensation or sound, it may indicate a meniscal injury.



Option C: Lachman test is also done to detect injuries to the anterior cruciate ligament. In this examination, the patient's knee is flexed at a 20-degree angle. The examiner uses one hand to hold the lower thigh and the other to grasp the upper part of the leg. The joint surfaces are then shifted backward and forwards upon each other. Any abnormal movement observed during this test may indicate a potential anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury.



Option D: The Thessaly test is done to detect meniscal tears. In this test, the affected knee is flexed at a 20-degree angle, and the patient places the foot flat on the ground. While being supported by the examiner, the patient bears their full weight on that leg. They are then instructed to twist their body to one side and then the other, repeating this movement three times, while maintaining the knee flexed at 20 degrees. Individuals with meniscal tears may feel pain along the medial or lateral joint line and may also sense a locking sensation in the knee.

Pearl PM1509: Mechanism of injury and tests for knee injuries

Structures | Mechanism of injury | Tests Menisci | Rotational force | McMurray test

Apley's grinding test

Squat test

Thessaly test Medial collateral ligament | Valgus force | Valgus stress test Lateral collateral ligament | Varus force | Varus stress test Anterior cruciate ligament | Anterior tibial displacement | Anterior drawer test 

Lachman test

Pivot shift test Posterior cruciate ligament | Posterior tibial displacement | Posterior drawer test

Sag sign

questions.text:
114. A patient presents with recurrent sinusitis and hematuria. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis is suspected. Which type of ANCA is most likely associated with his condition?

p-ANCA - perinuclear antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody

c-ANCA- cytoplasmic ANCA
questions.solution:
The most likely ANCA association with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) is c-ANCA against PR3 

PR3-ANCA is the most specific marker for GPA, with a sensitivity of around 80% and a specificity of over 90%. It targets proteinase 3, an enzyme found in neutrophil cytoplasm.

GPA formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis, is a systemic autoimmune vasculitis characterized by granulomatous inflammation and vasculitis of small-to-medium vessels. ANCAs are highly specific serological markers for ANCA-associated vasculitides (AAVs), which include GPA, microscopic polyangiitis (MPA), Churg-Strauss syndrome, and renal-limited vasculitis.

The two most important ANCA related to vasculitis are: 

* Anti-proteinase-3/ PR3-ANCA / c-ANCA - Directed against PR3, a neutrophil azurophilic granule constituent.

* Anti-myeloperoxidase/ MPO-ANCA / p-ANCA - Directed against MPO, a lysosomal granule constituent involved in oxygen-free-radical generation. MPO-ANCAs are induced by several therapeutic agents, particularly propylthiouracil.

Pearl PM0951: ANCA Antibodies

The antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are the antibodies that are targeted against the specific proteins present in neutrophils and monocytes. They can be further classified as: | Cytoplasmic ANCA (cANCA) | Perinuclear ANCA (pANCA) Directed against | Proteinase 3 (PR3) | Myeloperoxidase (MPO) Predominantly positive in | Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis) | Microscopic polyangiitis

Churg–Strauss syndrome 

Crescentic glomerulonephritis

Inflammatory Bowel Disease Staining pattern | Granular cytoplasmic staining | Perinuclear or nuclear staining

Pearl PM0954: Important Vasculitis with Features

Vasculitis | Predominant vessel involved | Inflammatory cells | Other features Temporal arteritis

(Large vessel vasculitis) | Temporal, vertebral and ophthalmic arteries, aorta | Lymphocytes, and macrophages | >40 years old, polymyalgia rheumatica, granulomas, giant cells Takayasu Arteritis

(Large vessel vasculitis) | (Medium-sized and large arteries) Aortic arch, great vessels, pulmonary artery, coronary and renal arteries | Lymphocytes, macrophages, neutrophils, granulomas, giant cells | Pulseless disease Polyarteritis Nodosa | Small or medium-sized muscular arteries, typically involving renal and visceral vessels | Neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells, | Spares pulmonary vessels, 30% of patients with  chronic hepatitis B Microscopic polyangiitis | Capillaries, small arterioles, venules | Neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells, | Necrotizing glomerulonephritism (90% of patients) and pulmonary capillaritis leukocytoclastic vasculitis Churg-Strauss Syndrome | Medium and small arteries | Eosinophils (required), lymphocytes, macrophages, neutrophils | Associated with asthma, allergic rhinitis, lung infiltrates, peripheral hypereosinophilia, and extravascular necrotizing granulomata.

questions.text: 115. All of the following metabolic reactions are carried out by non-microsomal enzymes, except:
questions.solution:
Glucuronide conjugation is the only phase II metabolic reaction that is carried out by microsomal enzymes.

Phase II reactions carried out by non-microsomal enzymes:

* Glycine conjugation

* Glutathione conjugation

* Sulfate conjugation

* Methylation

* Acetylation

Pearl PM1734: Phases of drug metabolism

Phase I reactions: They attach functional groups to the drugs. This usually leads to the inactivation of the drug. 

Examples:

* Oxidation

* Reduction

* Hydrolysis

* Cyclisation

* Deamination

Phase II reactions: They attach conjugates to the drugs. This facilitates drug elimination from the tissue. 

Examples:

* Glucuronide conjugation

* Sulfate conjugation

* Glycine conjugation

* Glutathione conjugation

* Acetylation

* Methylation

All phase II reactions are mainly conducted by the non-microsomal enzymes except glucuronidation.

questions.text: 116. In the recently passed law for replacing the colonial legal sections, which of the following is the replacement of the Indian Evidence Act (IEA)?
questions.solution:
In the recent change in legal sections, the Indian Evidence Act (IEA) has been replaced by Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam (BSA).

Other options:

Option A: Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita is the official criminal code in the Republic of India. It took effect on July 1, 2024, replacing the Indian Penal Code after being passed by the parliament in December 2023.

Option B: Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita is the main legislation in India for administering substantive criminal law and aims to consolidate and amend the law relating to Criminal Procedure.

Option D: Bhartiya Nagarik Sakshya Sanhita is a redundant option since such a law does not exist in our constitution.

questions.text: 117. A 16-year-old girl presented with primary amenorrhea. On evaluation, her height is normal and the breast development is appropriate for her age. However, the axillary and pubic hair is sparse. On ultrasound, an absent uterus is noted. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has primary amenorrhea, sparse axillary and pubic hair, and an absent uterus, indicating androgen insensitivity syndrome.

Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) is an X-linked recessive disorder in which there is a decrease in the function of the androgen receptor. They appear as phenotypically normal females at birth and often present with primary amenorrhea at puberty. External genitalia will appear normal with scant or absent pubic and axillary hair, shortened vagina. The uterus and fallopian tubes are absent. However, they develop breasts during pubertal maturation due to abundant androgen-to-estrogen conversion. Testes may be palpable in the labia or inguinal area or in the abdomen.

There are two causes of primary amenorrhea with the absent uterus and the differences between them are as follows: Presentation | Mullerian agenesis | Androgen insensitivity /Testicular feminization syndrome Inheritance pattern | Sporadic | X-linked recessive Karyotype | 46, XX | 46, XY Breast development | Yes | Yes Axillary and pubic hair | Yes | No Uterus | Absent | Absent Gonad | Ovary | Testis (Intraabdominal) Testosterone | Female levels | Male levels Associated anomaly | Yes | No

Other options:

Option B: Mullerian agenesis would have normal pubic and axillary hair but absent or rudimentary uterus.

Option C: Turner's syndrome is associated with the presence of a uterus, short stature and raised FSH levels.

Option D: Amenorrhea due to hypothalamic failure may be due to eating disorders, excessive exercise, or stress. It can also be inherited like Kallmann syndrome. The uterus is normal with decreased FSH and LH levels.



Pearl PM2182: Disorders of Sexual Development

Disorder | Complete androgen insensitivity | Mullerian agenesis | Turner syndrome | Complete XY dysgenesis (Swyer syndrome) Cause | X-linked mutation of androgen receptor | Hypoplastic or absent Mullerian ductal system

Also called Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome | Complete or partial absence of one X chromosome | SRY gene mutation on the Y chromosome Reproductive organs | Absent uterus and upper vagina, cryptorchid testis | Absent or rudimentary uterus and upper vagina, normal ovaries | Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads | Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads Breast | Yes | Yes | Variable | No Axillary/Pubic hair | Minimal to absent | Normal | Normal | Minimal to absent Karyotype | 46 XY | 46 XX | 45 XO or 

45 X mosaicism | 46 XY

Note: 

Turner's syndrome have different chromosomal anomalies:

* 45 XO which is seen in 40-50% patients 

* 45 X mosaicism (eg, 45,X/46,XX or 45,X/47,XXX, or 45,X mosaics with the X chromosome anomalies)

questions.text: 118. Which of the following histopathological findings is most characteristic of medulloblastoma?
questions.solution:
The most characteristic histopathological finding of medulloblastoma is the "Homer Wright rosettes".

Medulloblastoma is the most common malignant brain tumor in children. It arises in the cerebellum, usually in the midline (vermis), leading to truncal ataxia and hydrocephalus due to compression of the fourth ventricle.

It is classified as a primitive neuroectodermal tumor (PNET), meaning it is derived from embryonal neural precursors and shows limited differentiation. Medulloblastomas are highly cellular and tend to spread through cerebrospinal fluid, sometimes leading to "drop metastases" along the spinal cord.

Histopathologically, the classic hallmark of medulloblastoma is the presence of Homer-Wright rosettes, in which tumor cells form circular arrangements around a central area of eosinophilic neuropil, representing neuritic processes. The background often shows a faintly eosinophilic fibrillary material (neuropil), consistent with immature neuroblastic tissue. These findings reflect the neuroectodermal origin and differentiation pattern of the tumor and help distinguish it from other pediatric brain tumors.



Other options:

Option A: Pseudopalisading necrosis is seen in glioblastoma multiforme.

Option B: Perivascular pseudorosettes are characteristic of ependymomas.

Option D: Rosenthal fibers are elongated eosinophilic structures seen in pilocytic astrocytomas.

Pearl PM2482: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

* Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas

* Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 

* Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions

* Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 



Medulloblastoma:

* Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells

* Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped

* Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil



Ependymoma:

* Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 

* Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel



Oligodendroglioma:

* Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 

* Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries



Retinoblastoma: 

* Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei

* Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen

* Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center

* Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: 119. The plain X-ray of the erect abdomen of a 30-year-old male, who came with complaints of acute abdominal pain and distension is shown in the below image. All of the following radiological signs can be seen in the given condition except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and x-ray images are suggestive of pneumoperitoneum. All the given signs are seen in this except the spinnaker-sail sign.

The spinnaker sign (also known as the angel wing sign) is a sign of pneumomediastinum seen on neonatal chest radiographs. It refers to the thymus being outlined by air , with each lobe displaced laterally and appearing like spinnaker sails.



Pneumoperitoneum refers to air within the peritoneal cavity. Signs of Pneumoperitoneum that can be seen on a supine radiograph are:

* Right upper quadrant gas:

*

* Perihepatic

* Subhepatic

* Morrison’s pouch

* Fissure for ligamentum teres

* Rigler’s (double wall) sign

* Ligament visualisation:

* Falciform (ligamentum teres)

* Medial umbilical (inverted V sign)

* The Telltale Triangular air

The image below shows oval lucency seen on supine film, divided by the falciform ligament, resulting in the so-called football sign in a neonate with a large pneumoperitoneum.



The supine abdominal radiograph of the patient showing the presence of air in the bilateral subphrenic spaces and a linear density on the ventral surface of the liver (arrow), known as the falciform ligament sign.



Rigler’s sign is also known as the double-wall sign. As seen in the image below, both the inner and outer walls of the bowel are visible.

questions.text:
120. A 9-month-old baby is brought for routine vaccination. The mother of the baby enquires about the vaccines to be given for the prevention of pneumonia. How is PPV23 vaccine different from PCV13 vaccine?

PPV23-Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine 23

PCV13-Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine 13

choices.text: PPV23 cannot be given to children < 2 years of age
PPV23 can be given via the intramuscular route
PPV23 can be given to post-splenectomy individuals

questions.solution:
The correct answer is PPV23 cannot be given to children <2 years of age. It is a polysaccharide vaccine and children below 2 years of age and immunocompromised patients do not respond well to the vaccine; hence, this vaccine is avoided in these groups. 

Both the PPV23 and PCV13 vaccines can be administered intramuscularly and are suitable for individuals who have undergone splenectomy; they are both polysaccharide vaccines.

Pneumococcal vaccines include the following:

* Pneumococcal conjugate vaccines (PCV): 10-valent (PCV10) and 13-valent (PCV13)

* Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPV) 23: 23-valent polysaccharide vaccine (PPV23)

Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV) 13 | Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPV)23 It is a polysaccharide vaccine of 13 serotypes of Streptococcus pneumoniae conjugated to a nontoxic variant of diphtheria toxin. | It is a polysaccharide vaccine from 23 types of pneumococcal bacteria. In India, 2 primary doses at 6 and 14 weeks and 1 booster is given at 9–12 months via the intramuscular route. | It is available for adults and children over 2 years of age, who respond well to the vaccine. It can be given intramuscularly or subcutaneously. Regardless of the presence of underlying medical conditions (e.g., HIV-infected children, sickle cell disease, post-splenectomy state, or immunocompromised state due to other reasons), PCV should be given according to the national schedule. | It is recommended for selected clinical settings, such as the following:

* Post-splenectomy state 

* Sickle-cell disease

* Chronic diseases of heart, lung, liver, or kidney

* Generalized malignancies

* Organ transplants

When primary immunization is initiated with one of these vaccines, it is recommended that the remaining doses are administered with the same product. WHO recommends the inclusion of PCVs in childhood immunization programs worldwide.

questions.text: 121. A 50-year-old lady presented with a 1.5 cm pigmented lesion on the face which is growing rapidly and is associated with itching. Dermoscopy examination is shown below which revealed an atypical, pigmented network. The dermatologist performs an excisional biopsy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 1.5 cm pigmented lesion on the face which is asymmetrical, with an irregular border, made of black and brown pigments, and increasing rapidly in size, points towards a diagnosis of malignant melanoma. 

Dermoscopy is similar to a simple magnifying lens applied on the skin surface with an intervening oil layer. It is used for better visualization of surface lesions. It helps in differentiating malignant melanoma from other benign lesions in case of doubt. Other uses include examination of scabies burrows or trichoscopy and tungiasis.

Dermoscopic appearance patterns have been classified and specific scoring systems devised (ABCD dermoscopy score and seven-point checklist) to diagnose malignant melanoma. The following dermoscopic appearances point toward a diagnosis of malignant melanoma:      

* Atypical network (seen as circled in question image - the spaces are placed at irregular intervals)

* Atypical vascular structures

* Atypical blotch

* Atypical dots and globules

* Regression structures

* Crystalline structures

* Negative network

* Streaks

* The blue-white veil over raised areas

* Peripheral tan structureless areas.

If dermoscopic appearances point towards melanoma, a biopsy is done and accordingly treatment is initiated. If dermoscopic structures point towards a benign lesion, monitoring can be done.

Other options:

Option A: A dysplastic nevus is formed at the dermo-epidermal junction. They are usually smaller in size than melanoma, have a fuzzy border, and are more likely to show brown-tan pigmentation. Any blue-black pigmentation should raise suspicion of melanoma. The majority of dysplastic nevi regress on their own

Option B: Congenital melanocytic nevus may be small, medium, or large size (>20cm). A large-sized mole may show an atypical network and have a risk of melanoma growth. But a history of being present since birth or infancy needs to be present.

Option C: Acquired melanocytic nevus (common mole) is rarely more than 1cm in size. It also does not show an atypical network.

The image below demonstrates how a dermoscopy is performed:



Pearl PM0391: Clinical Findings suggestive of Melanoma

The ABCDE of melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:



A : Asymmetry

* Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape

B : Border irregular

* Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill-defined

C : Color variation

* The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color

D : Diameter >6 mm

* Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser)

E : Evolution

* There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole

questions.text: 122. A 20-year-old female singer presents to you with a weakness of voice after having multiple recordings in the studio. Indirect laryngoscopy shows the following finding. This appearance of the glottis is due to the weakness of which of the following muscle(s)?
questions.solution:
The indirect laryngoscopy image shows a keyhole appearance which is seen in phonasthenia. It is caused by the weakness of both thyroarytenoid and interarytenoid muscles.

Phonasthenia is the weakness of voice due to fatigue of the laryngeal muscles. This leads to a phonatory gap visualized by indirect laryngoscopy. The shape of the gap depends on the muscles involved:

*

* Thyroarytenoid alone: elliptical space

* Interarytenoid alone: triangular space

* Both thyroarytenoid and interarytenoid: keyhole appearance

This condition is treated by voice rest and vocal hygiene.

Spasms of the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle (option D) cause abductor dysphonia.



Pearl PM1978: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

* All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)

* All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)

Action | Muscle Opening of the inlet of larynx | Thyroepiglotticus Closing of the inlet of larynx | Aryepiglotticus, Interarytenoids Abductor of vocal cords | Posterior cricoarytenoid Adductor of vocal cords | Lateral cricoarytenoid Tensor of vocal cords | Cricothyroid Relaxer of vocal cord | Thyroarytenoid Modulator of larynx | Vocalis

Safety muscle of larynx: Posterior cricoarytenoid

Safety muscle of tongue: Genioglossus

The muscle of whispering: Lateral cricoarytenoid

Vocalis is known as the modulator of larynx because, the anterior part of the vocalis muscle can tense the vocal cord, and its posterior part can relax the vocal cord.

questions.text: 123. A 53-year-old woman is diagnosed with breast cancer. Immunohistochemistry staining revealed the findings as shown in the image below. Which among the following adjuvant treatments will you provide for this patient?
questions.solution:
The immunohistochemistry staining shown in the above image is ER+, PR+, and HER2+, which is triple positive or luminal type B. The adjuvant treatment of choice for this patient is endocrine therapy + chemotherapy + trastuzumab.

Positive staining is indicated by the presence of brown-colored tissue.

* The Estrogen receptor (ER) and Progesterone receptor (PR) are both nuclear receptors, hence, the nucleus is stained brown if positive.

* The human epidermal growth factor receptor type 2 (HER2) is a membrane receptor, hence the cell membrane is stained brown if positive.

The image below shows positive and negative staining for ER, PR, and HER2:



The adjuvant treatment modalities currently in practice include:

* Endocrine treatment such as tamoxifen or ovarian suppression. It is given to patients with tumours that are hormone receptor-positive (either ER+ or PR+).

* Anti-HER2 therapy with trastuzumab (humanized monoclonal antibody). It is given to patients with tumours that are HER2 overexpressing.

* Chemotherapy as per the American Society of Clinical Oncology guidelines should be considered for patients with positive lymph nodes, HER2-positive disease, tumors >5 mm, triple-negative tumors, or with lympho-vascular invasion.

questions.text: 124. A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with acute pain in the abdomen. He gave a history of admission to the hospital a month ago for a similar complaint, but has no previous records. CECT abdomen showed a solid and liquified necrotic collection in the pancreas with a well-defined inflammatory capsule. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of the patient with acute abdominal pain and a CECT abdomen showing a heterogeneous collection in the pancreas with a well-defined inflammatory capsule suggests walled-off necrosis of the pancreas.

Walled-off necrosis (WON) refers to a localized collection of necrotic pancreatic tissue and fluid, enclosed by a mature inflammatory wall, typically forming about four weeks after an episode of acute pancreatitis. The collection is sterile, to begin with, but often becomes subsequently infected, probably because of the translocation of gut bacteria.

Based on the revised Atlanta classification, peripancreatic fluid and its collections can be classified into 4 different types based on their morphology and time of presentation.

* IEP - Interstitial Edematous Pancreatitis

* APFC - Acute Peripancreatic Fluid Collection: Non-necrotic fluid collection presenting within 4 weeks

* Pancreatic pseudocyst:  Non-necrotic fluid collection when it undergoes encapsulation (after 4 weeks)

* Necrotising Pancreatitis

* ANC - Acute Necrotic Collection:  Necrotic fluid collection presenting within 4 weeks

* WON - Walled-Off Necrosis:  Necrotic fluid collection when it undergoes encapsulation (after 4 weeks)

Duration since onset | IEP | Necrotizing pancreatitis < 4 weeks after onset (not encapsulated) | APFC | ANC ⇓ Undergoes encapsulation ⇓ ≥ 4 weeks after onset  (encapsulated) | Pancreatic pseudocyst | WON

ANC, APFC, WON, and pancreatic pseudocysts can be infected or non-infected. Collections that contain non-liquefied material or show the presence of gas, are more likely to be infected.

Management includes conservative measures. Sterile necrotic material should not be drained. Infected fluid can be drained by internal drainage into the stomach under endoscopic ultrasound guidance or by percutaneous drainage. In patients with overwhelming sepsis, laparotomy may be needed to perform a necrosectomy.

Other options:

Option A: Acute necrotic collection develops within 4 weeks of the acute pancreatitis and does not have a well-defined wall. There is presence of necrotic collection.

Option C: Pseudocyst pancreas is a homogenous collection of amylase-rich fluid enclosed in a well-defined wall of fibrous or granulation tissue and develops after 4 weeks of the acute pancreatitis. Image given below shows pseudocyst pancreas.



Option D: Acute peripancreatic collection is a homogenous fluid collection that develops within 4 weeks of mild pancreatitis and has no encapsulating wall.

Pearl PM1639: Vascular complications of pancreatitis

Arterial pseudoaneurysm:

* It is caused by damage to the vessel wall by pancreatic elastase

* The most common vessel affected is the splenic artery, but the superior mesenteric artery (SMA), cystic artery, and gastroduodenal artery (GDA) may also be affected

* Spontaneous rupture results in massive bleeding

* Clinical manifestations include sudden onset of abdominal pain, tachycardia, and hypotension.

* CT angiography is the investigation of choice

* Treatment

* Arterial embolization

* Ligation of the affected vessel in refrac­tory cases

Vascular thrombosis:

* The vessel usually affected is the splenic vein, but in severe cases, it can extend into the portal venous system

* Clinical features include splenomegaly, gastric varices, and splenic vein occlusion

* Treatment:

* Mostly conservative

* Throm­bolytics in the acute early phase

questions.text:
125. You are a medical officer in a PHC, and the stock of vaccine vials available in the PHC is limited. You use a previously used vaccine vial for a child. The VVM and the expiry date are within the normal limits. According to the new guidelines, what is the most probable vaccine vial you would have used in this case?

VVM- Vaccine Vial Monitor
questions.solution:
According to the new guidelines, the most probable vaccine vial that would have been used in this case is the Inactivated Japanese encephalitis vaccine.

According to the current guidelines, the Open vial policy applies to DPT, TT, Hepatitis B, Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV), Liquid Pentavalent, PCV,  injectable IPV, Rotavirus vaccine, and Japanese encephalitis vaccine (inactivated). The open vial policy does not apply to rotavirus vaccine with VVM on the cap, it applies only to the new rotavirus vaccine with VVM on the label (Option D).



It does not apply to Measles/MR, BCG (Options A and B), which is under NIS (reconstituted vaccine) and rabies vaccine, yellow fever vaccine, which is not under NIS (reconstituted vaccine), covid vaccine (not a reconstituted vaccine). 

Vaccine vials opened in the session site can be used in more than one immunisation session for up to four weeks, provided -

* The expiry date has not passed.

* Vaccines are stored strictly under the appropriate temperature range both during transportation & storage at the cold chain point.

* The vaccine vial septum has not been submerged in water or contaminated in any way.

* An aseptic technique has been used to withdraw all doses.

* The vaccine vial monitor (VVM) has not reached the discard point.

Ensure all open vials have been recorded with the date and time of opening. All vials (open or unopened) should be transported in a zipper bag in the vaccine carrier and recorded in the stock register. Well-sealed, conditioned ice packs should be used in vaccine carriers, and water should not be allowed to accumulate where vaccine vials and diluents are stored.

Pearl PM0697: Open Vial Policy

Open vial policy allows for reuse of partially used multidose vials of applicable vaccines under the Universal Immunization Programme in subsequent sessions up to 4 weeks subject to certain conditions and thereby reducing vaccine wastage.

It is applicable only for DPT, TT, hepatitis B vaccine, OPV, liquid pentavalent vaccine, rotavirus vaccine(new version with the VVM on the side), and JE vaccines (inactivated). It is not applicable to BCG and measles vaccines. 

Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be used in more than one session up to four weeks if expiry date has not passed, if storage and transport was appropriate, no contamination has occurred in vial septum, asepsis in withdrawing was practiced and if vaccine vial monitor has not reached discard point.

Open vials should not be submerged in water. All open vials should have a record of date and time of opening. At the end of a session, all vaccines should be returned to the cold chain point and segregated as re-usable and non-reusable. All open vials of BCG, measles must be destroyed after 48 hours or before next session, whichever is earlier.

In case of any adverse events following immunization, all open vials should not be discarded until investigation is complete. All vials must be transported in zipper bags in the vaccine carrier and recorded in stock register. Ice packs used should be well sealed.

Pearl PM0698: Vaccine Vial Monitors

* Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.

* It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.

* If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.



* Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.

* The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.

* VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text:
126. Which of the following correctly describes a mechanism by which fructose 2,6-bisphosphate regulates glycolysis in hepatocytes?

PEP- Phosphoenol pyruvate

PFK-1- Phosphofructokinase-1

choices.text: Activates pyruvate kinase and blocks PEP carboxykinase
Formed by PFK-1 under regulation of Insulin
Activates PFK-1 to promote glycolysis and is regulated by glucagon
Inhibits hexokinase to reduce glucose use in fed state

questions.solution:
The correct mechanism by which fructose 2,6-bisphosphate regulates glycolysis in hepatocytes is to activate PFK-1 to promote glycolysis, and it is regulated by glucagon.

Fructose 2,6-bisphosphate (F2,6BP) is a potent allosteric regulator of two key enzymes:

* Activates phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) → promotes glycolysis

* Inhibits fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase (FBPase-1) → inhibits gluconeogenesis

So it plays a dual role: stimulates glycolysis and inhibits gluconeogenesis.

It is synthesised and degraded by a bifunctional enzyme known as PFK-2/FBPase-2 (phosphofructokinase-2/fructose-2,6-bisphosphatase). Hormonal control in the liver is as follows:

* Insulin (fed state) → activates PFK-2 → ↑ F2,6BP → ↑ glycolysis

* Glucagon (fasting state) → stimulates production of cAMP → activates Fructose 2,6 Bisphosphatase (FBPase-2) → break down of F2,6BP into F6P → results in decreased levels of F2,6BP → inhibits glycolysis & promotes gluconeogenesis.

Option A: This is an incorrect statement because F2,6BP does not directly act on pyruvate kinase or PEP carboxykinase. Pyruvate kinase is regulated by phosphorylation (also under hormonal control), but not directly by F2,6BP.

Option B: F2,6BP is formed by phosphorylation of fructose-6-phosphate by PFK-2, not PFK-1. PFK-1 is the enzyme activated by F2,6BP, not the one that makes it.

Option D: F2,6BP has no effect on hexokinase since the enzyme has no role in glucose metabolism in the liver. In the liver, glucokinase is the enzyme used for glucose metabolism. Also, glucose use increases in the fed state and is not reduced.

questions.text: 127. Which of the following is false about miRNA?

choices.text: DICER is involved in the processing of miRNA

questions.solution:
The inhibition is done at the level of translation.

RNA interference (RNAi) is a biological process in which miRNA/ siRNA molecules inhibit gene expression by neutralizing targeted mRNAs.The microRNA (miRNA) belongs to a group of non-coding genes. The miRNA genes are transcribed but not translated into proteins. They play a role in the regulation of the expression of the target gene by post-transcriptional silencing.

Mechanism:

* The miRNA gene present in the nucleus is transcribed to primary miRNA, which is further converted to pre-miRNA by an enzyme DROSHA intranuclearly and exported to the cytoplasm by an export protein.

* The pre-miRNA undergoes trimming, by an enzyme called DICER, into mature single-stranded miRNA.

* The mature miRNA is associated with a multiprotein aggregate called RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC).

* The target mRNAs contain seed sequence in their 3′ untranslated region (UTR) that determines the specificity of miRNA binding and gene silencing.

Depending on the base pairing between the miRNA strand and its target mRNA, the RISC causes gene silencing either by mRNA cleavage or by repressing its translation.

siRNA is similar in function to miRNA and is used in RNA interference.

miRNA expression has been found to be dysregulated in many cancers. Such misregulation is thought to have a causal role in the pathogenesis of such cancers. Some types of miRNAs are oncogenic (referred to as oncomiRs) and are overexpressed in cancerous tissue. On the other hand, tumour-suppressive miRNAs that counteract oncogenic characteristics are found to be underexpressed in cancers.

questions.text: 128. A postmenopausal patient underwent surgical staging for a mass in the uterine corpus. The resected specimen was sent for histopathology and identified as clear cell carcinoma with TP53 mutation. Which of the following features is typically seen in patients who develop this type of cancer?
questions.solution:
Atrophic endometrium is generally seen in patients developing Type 2 endometrial carcinoma.

The given clinical scenario describes a postmenopausal woman who underwent surgical staging for carcinoma endometrium. The cancer was identified as clear-cell endometrial carcinoma with Tp53 mutation, which is characteristic of Type 2 endometrial carcinomas. These cancers typically arise in atrophic postmenopausal endometrium.

Endometrial carcinomas are divided into two distinct types, each of which has different presentations and prognosis as detailed in the pearl given below. Type 2 endometrial cancers typically arise in older postmenopausal females with atrophic endometrium who have a hypoestrogenic state and no significant history of excess estrogen exposure.

Type 2 cancers are frequently serous or clear-cell on histopathology and have early Tp 53 mutations with poor differentiation. They generally are aggressive with extensive intraperitoneal and lymph node metastasis and harbor a poor prognosis and poor/no response to hormonal therapy.

Type 1 cancers are typically associated with proliferative endometrial hyperplasia, increased endometrial thickness, and a hyperestrogenic state or history of excess estrogen exposure such as :

* Unopposed and unsupervised HRT after menopause (Option D), especially for prolonged durations.

* Chronic anovulatory cycles such as in PCOS (Option A) and infertility

* Premenopausal state

* Tamoxifen in women with breast cancer

* Oestrogen-producing tumors such as Granulosa cell tumors (Option C)

* Nulliparity(increases cumulative estrogen exposure)

* Later age at menopause 

* Early age at menarche

* Obesity(due to increased peripheral conversion)

* Metabolic syndrome(due to obesity)

* Thyroid disease, Type 2 DM, Hypertension 

Another risk factor is Lynch-II syndrome. Combined OCPs are protective.

questions.text: 129. A urethral swab was taken from a patient with suspected gonococcal urethritis. Which transport medium can be used for the swab?
questions.solution:
Amies medium can be used as a transport medium for the urethral swab from the patient with suspected gonococcal urethritis.

In a case of suspected gonococcal urethritis, Urethral swab specimens should ideally be transported immediately. If not possible, then Amies medium (charcoal-containing medium) should be used, or it can be collected in charcoal-coated swabs kept in Stuart’s transport medium. Amies medium and Stuart’s medium are used as a transport medium for Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

Transport mediums are used for the transport of clinical specimens suspected to contain delicate organisms or when a delay is expected while transporting the specimens from the site of collection to the laboratory. Bacteria remain viable in the transport media and do not multiply.

Other options:

Option B: Cary Blair medium is used as a transport medium for Shigella, Salmonella and Vibrio cholerae.

Option C: Venkatraman-Ramakrishnan medium is used as a transport medium for Vibrio cholerae.

Option D: Buffered glycerol saline medium is used as a transport medium for Shigella and Salmonella.

questions.text: 130. A 42-year-old man with chronic plaque psoriasis presents with joint pain, morning stiffness for more than 1 hour, and swelling of the DIP joints. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
The best drug in this case scenario will be Ustekinumab. 

The patient in the question is a 42-year-old man with chronic plaque psoriasis and joint involvement (DIP swelling, morning stiffness >1 hour), which suggests psoriatic arthritis (PsA).

Ustekinumab is a monoclonal antibody targeting IL-12 and IL-23. It is effective for moderate-to-severe plaque psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis. It is administered subcutaneously and bypasses liver metabolism. Ustekinumab is generally well tolerated, with common side effects including nasopharyngitis, headache, upper respiratory infections, and injection site reactions.

Other options:

Option A: Tralokinumab is a fully human IgG4 monoclonal antibody that binds to type 2 cytokine IL-13. It is licensed for use in adults with moderate to severe atopic dermatitis.

Option C: Omalizumab is a recombinant humanised monoclonal antibody against the Cε3 domain of IgE. It is used in severe allergic asthma (IgE-mediated) and is effective in treating chronic urticaria.

Option D: Dupilumab is an IL-4 receptor antagonist. It is licensed for use in adults with moderate to severe atopic dermatitis, severe asthma with type 2 inflammation and severe chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps.

questions.text:
131. A patient came to the OPD with complaints of blurred vision and dull ocular pain along with photophobia for the past few weeks. On examination, iris colour was normal and marked ciliary congestion was noted. IOP was 15mm Hg. The anterior chamber showed the below finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?

IOP- Intraocular Pressure
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the most likely diagnosis is Granulomatous uveitis.

The given clinical vignette depicts a patient with complaints of photophobia, blurred vision, and ocular pain for few weeks(chronic condition). The ocular examination shows marked ciliary congestion along with the image which depicts gravitational keratic-precipitates in the anterior chamber of the mutton-fat variety, a hallmark of granulomatous uveitis. IOP is 15 mm Hg(normal).

Granulomatous uveitis is an etiological type of uveitis characterized by a Type IV hypersensitivity reaction in the uveal tissue of the eye, marked by granulomatous inflammation due to either infiltration by living organisms or an autoimmune process. Common agents implicated include:

* Infectious: Tuberculosis, Leprosy, Brucellosis, Leptospirosis etc

* Non-infectious: Sarcoidosis, Sympathetic ophthalmitis, Vogt-Koyanagi Harada Syndrome

It is a chronic inflammatory process of a proliferative nature induced due to a foreign body. The pathological reaction is characterized by lymphocytes and monocytes which transform into epitheloid cells and giant cells, forming nodules such as iris nodules near the pupillary border (Koeppe nodule) or near the collarette(Busacca nodule).

There is minimal aqueous flare and large, nodular, mutton-fat keratic precipitates deposit at the back of the cornea in a gravitationally dependent manner at the bottom of the AC in a triangular conformation due to aqueous currents.

Diagnosis is by clinical features combined with thorough ocular examination, hematological tests and specific tests to identify the etiological agent. Treatment in the acute phase is with steroids and cycloplegics, NSAIDs and immunosuppressants, and treatment for whatever is the specific cause.

Other Options:

Option A: In Fuch's heterochromic iridocyclitis, there is low-grade chronic cyclitis causing the lightening of iris color(in this patient, iris colour is normal) and the presence of stellate KPs on the cornea. Secondary posterior-subcapsular cataract frequently develops along with secondary glaucoma. In this patient, there is no decoloration of the iris or stellar KPs excluding this condition.

Option B: UGH syndrome is uveitis-glaucoma-hyphaema syndrome which is a triad of these three symptoms that used to frequently occur in individuals implanted with an anterior chamber rigid IOL. Small, fine KPs are seen. As there is no history of AC-IOL implant in this patient or hyphema/glaucoma, this diagnosis is unlikely.

Option D: Glaucomatocyclitic crisis is an acute, recurrent, mild uveitis along with secondary glaucoma, which is out of proportion to the inflammation(IOP normal in this patient). The AC contains small, flat KPs, and the IOP is very high. As these features are not seen in this patient, it is excluded as a differential diagnosis.

questions.text: 132. Which of the following is an executioner caspase?
questions.solution:
Caspase 3 is an executioner caspase.

Caspases are proteases containing a cysteine in their active site and cleave proteins after aspartic residues. They exist as inactive proenzymes and must undergo enzymatic cleavage to become active. The presence of active caspases is a marker for cells undergoing apoptosis. 

There are two types of caspases:

* Initiator caspases - They are activated first. They, in turn, activate executioner caspases. Caspases 8, 9, and 10 are initiator caspases.

* The mitochondrial pathway leads to the activation of the initiator caspase 9.

* The death receptor pathway leads to the activation of the initiator caspases 8 and 10.

* Executioner caspases- The terminal caspases trigger cellular fragmentation. Caspases 3, 6 and 7 are executioner caspases.

questions.text: 133. A 12-year-old girl was brought to the hospital after a history of sexual abuse. Prior to the examination, stained portions of the girl's clothing were taken for analysis. The stain was extracted using 10% hydrochloric acid, following which a reagent containing potassium iodide, iodine, and water was added to it. Identify the correct statement about the test performed.

choices.text: Dark brown crystals indicate the presence of semen
The reaction is based on presence of prostatic secretions
It is a confirmatory test for the presence of semen
It detects the presence of acid phosphatase

questions.solution:
The correct statement here is that dark brown crystals indicate the presence of semen. The test described here is the Florence test. It is used to detect seminal fluid.

The suspected seminal stain is extracted with 10% hydrochloric acid, and a drop of it is placed over a slide. A coverslip is placed over it, and a drop of Florence solution (potassium iodide, iodine, and water) is made to run under the coverslip. If semen is present, dark brown rhombic or needle-shaped crystals of choline iodide appear immediately. Choline originates from the seminal vesicles. 

The test is not confirmatory for the presence of semen, however, a negative reaction rules out the presence of semen. Confirmation of the presence of semen can be done only if there is presence of at least one unbroken spermatozoon, or detection of  sperms by electrophoretic LDH isoenzyme.

Other tests for Semen detection include:

* Barberio's Test: Yellow needle-shaped crystals on the addition of picric acid. Reaction is based on prostatic secretions.

* Acid Phosphatase Test: Detects the presence of acid phosphatase (from prostatic secretions) in the seminal fluid.

* Creatine Phosphokinase: Spermatozoa contain a high level of creatine phosphokinase, which can be detected.

* Immunological detection of P30, MHS 5 or MAB E6

questions.text: 134. A 38-year-old chronic alcoholic patient was driving under alcohol influence and met with an accident. He is admitted with a shaft of femur fracture. On the third day of admission, he develops severe restlessness and altered sensorium. He has visual and tactile hallucinations. Which of the following drugs should be avoided for the management of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of altered sensorium with visual and tactile hallucinations following alcohol withdrawal is suggestive of delirium tremens. Antipsychotics like Clozapine are avoided in the management of delirium tremens as they lower the seizure threshold, placing the patient at a greater risk for developing alcohol-withdrawal seizures.

Antipsychotics are used to manage the psychotic symptoms in cases of delirium but in cases of delirium associated with alcohol withdrawal the use of antipsychotics is not recommended. All antipsychotics except pimavanserin are associated with an increased risk for seizures, with clozapine having a dose-dependent seizure risk.

Delirium tremens is a medical emergency that occurs during alcohol withdrawal. It is an acute condition and usually develops within 3-4 days of the last drink. It has symptoms of both delirium and alcohol withdrawal. In the above scenario, delirium tremens precipitated as the patient was admitted into the hospital ward and couldn't consume alcohol for three days. The clinical features of delirium tremens are:

* Altered sensorium with disorientation

* Perceptual distortions, most frequently tactile or visual hallucinations

* Autonomic hyperactivity with tachycardia, fever, anxiety, insomnia, hypertension, and sweating

* Fluctuating levels of psychomotor activity, ranging from agitation to lethargy

* Altered sleep-wake cycle

Benzodiazepines such as diazepam (intravenously) or chlordiazepoxide (orally every 4 hours) are given in order to deal with the symptoms. It is also recommended to administer thiamine in patients with alcohol-related disorders to prevent Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome. Patients that do not respond even to high-dose benzodiazepines, should be administered Propofol or Dexmedetomidine in closely-monitored doses.

Note: Haloperidol is the only recommended antipsychotic given in cases of severe psychosis in Delirium tremens.

questions.text: 135. A teenage girl comes to your clinic complaining of easy bruising. She gives a history of prolonged intake of antibiotics to treat her acne. Which among the following vitamin deficiencies might have led to her present condition?
questions.solution:
History of easy bruising after prolonged use of antibiotics is suggestive of menaquinone/vitamin K deficiency. Prolonged use of antibiotics leads to vitamin K deficiency. This is due to the loss of normal bowel flora that synthesizes menaquinones (vitamin K2). Menaquinones type of vitamin K is produced by gut bacteria.

Vitamin K is required for the functioning are the blood-clotting factors II, VII, IX, X, protein C, and protein S. Vitamin K deficiency causes easy bruising, bleeding, elevated prothrombin time, and hemorrhagic disease in newborns.

Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin. The following are the vitamers of vitamin K:

* Phylloquinone (Vitamin K1) is the normal dietary source of Vitamin K that is found in green vegetables.

* Menaquinone (Vitamin K2) is synthesized by intestinal bacteria.

* Menadione (Vitamin K3) is a synthetic compound that is metabolized to phylloquinone.

questions.text: 136. A 3-year-old boy presents with recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, including pneumonia and skin abscesses. Lab diagnosis shows that the infections are with Staphylococcus aureus and Candida. Flow cytometry shows an absence of dihydrorhodamine (DHR) fluorescence. Which of the following best explains the pathophysiology of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Impaired formation of the phagocyte NADPH oxidase complex
Defective leukocyte adhesion due to mutations in β chain of CD11/CD18 integrins

questions.solution:
This boy has recurrent infections and an absent DHR fluorescence, which are hallmark features of Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD). CGD is caused by a defect in the phagocyte NADPH oxidase complex, which is essential for generating superoxide radicals during the oxidative burst in neutrophils and macrophages.

Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is a rare, inherited immunodeficiency most commonly seen in boys due to an X-linked recessive mutation, though autosomal recessive forms can occur in girls. It results from defects in the NADPH oxidase complex, a critical enzyme in phagocytes responsible for producing reactive oxygen species (ROS).

Without functional NADPH oxidase, phagocytes cannot generate superoxide radicals or hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂), which are essential for killing engulfed pathogens. This leads to defective intracellular killing, making patients highly susceptible to recurrent infections, particularly with catalase-positive organisms like Staphylococcus aureus, Serratia marcescens, Burkholderia cepacia, Aspergillus, Candida, Salmonella, and Nocardia.

The dihydrorhodamine (DHR) flow cytometry test, which detects ROS production, is the current gold standard diagnostic tool; the absence of fluorescence indicates impaired NADPH oxidase activity. The older nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT) test also shows a negative result in CGD due to the same functional defect.

Management of CGD involves long-term prophylactic antibiotics and antifungals, with bone marrow transplantation as a potentially curative option in severe cases. Corticosteroids may be used to treat inflammatory complications such as granulomatous colitis or urinary tract obstruction. 

Other options:

Option B: Defective lysosomal trafficking within neutrophils is present in Chediak-Higashi syndrome, which presents with partial albinism and giant granules in neutrophils.

Option C: Defective IL-17 signaling is seen in Hyper-IgE Syndrome (Job Syndrome) which leads to eczema, recurrent staph abscesses, and pneumonia.

Option D:  Defective leukocyte adhesion because of mutations in the β chain of CD11/CD18 integrins is seen in Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 1.  This disrupts the adhesion of leukocytes to blood vessel walls (endothelium), which prevents these immune cells from migrating into infected tissues. As a result, individuals are highly susceptible to recurrent, severe bacterial infections. It can also present with delayed separation of the umbilical cord and absent pus formation.

Pearl PM2352: Chronic granulomatous disease

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is due to the defect in NADPH oxidase. This interferes with the killing of bacteria by oxidative burst. Hence, the patients are at increased risk of infection from catalase-positive bacteria.



It can be:

* X linked - Defect in one of the membrane-bound components (gp91phox) or

* Autosomal recessive - Cytoplasmic components (p47phox and p67phox)

Diagnosis of CGD includes:

* Nitroblue tetrazolium test - This is the standard for phagocyte oxidase activity measurement. The colorless compound NBT is reduced to blue formazan by the activity of the functional phox enzyme system. Normally, more than 95% of the granulocytes will be positive. The NBT is negative in CGD due to absence of phox enzyme activity.

* Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test - The most accurate diagnostic test for CGD. Normally functioning phagocytic cells oxidize DHR to the strongly fluorescent compound rhodamine which is quantified by flow cytometry.

questions.text: 137. A 6-year-old boy has chronic, itchy, red patches with excoriations on his elbows and the backs of his knees. His mother notes he frequently rubs his eyes and has a history of seasonal allergies and asthma. Examination reveals prominent infraorbital folds under both lower eyelids as shown below. Which of the following best describes this finding?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation is classic for atopic dermatitis. The presence of infraorbital folds under the eyes often results from chronic periorbital edema and persistent rubbing, are known as Dennie-Morgan folds.

They appear as linear or crescent-shaped folds just below the lower eyelids and become more visible with chronic inflammation and allergic symptoms.



Atopic dermatitis is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that occurs due to type 1 hypersensitivity reaction triggered by exogenous agents. It is often associated with allergic rhinitis and bronchial asthma. It presents with erythematous, pruritic patches or plaques, often associated with a personal or family history of atopy. Flexural surfaces are commonly involved in adults.

In infants, it presents as erythema and edematous papules in the face and extensor aspect of the knees and elbows. The papules are intensely itchy and may become exudative and crusted as a result of rubbing.

Other options:

Option A: Hertoghe’s sign refers to the loss of the lateral third of the eyebrows, often seen in hypothyroidism due to Hashimoto's thyroiditis.



Option C: Otto Veraguth folds are triangular palpebral folds running diagonally from the lateral corners of the eyes, medially upward to the medial end of the eyebrows, seen in depression, a neuropsychiatric sign, not related to allergy.



Option D: Allergic salute is the habitual upward rubbing of the nose with the palm in patients of allergic rhinitis, often leading to a transverse nasal crease — it's a behavioural sign, not an anatomical fold.

questions.text: 138. An opioid overdose victim with severe respiratory depression was brought to the casualty. You start the patient on the most potent drug known to reverse respiratory depression in this condition. Which of the following graphs represents the action of this drug?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for the reversal of respiratory depression in opium overdose is naloxone which acts as a competitive opioid antagonist represented by graph 3.

Competitive antagonist is an agent which blocks or reduces the action of an agonist on a receptor but does not have any effect of its own. Naloxone acts on the µ receptors in the brainstem respiratory centres.

Naltrexone is also an opioid antagonist that blocks opioid effects, particularly euphoria, and discourages per­sons with opioid dependence from substance-seeking behaviour. It is not the first choice in acute opioid overdose.

Graph 1 represents the agonist: An agonist is an agent which initiates the normal physiological response when combined with a receptor. Example: Salbutamol is a beta-2 receptor agonist. 

Graph 2 represents a partial agonist: An agent which produces a submaximal or partial effect when combined with a receptor. Example: Buprenorphine and butorphanol are partial agonists at opioid receptors.

Graph 4 represents an inverse agonist: An agent which activates a receptor to produce an effect in the opposite direction to that of the agonist. Example: β-Carboline is an inverse agonist at the benzodiazepine site of the GABA-A receptor.

According to the receptor occupation theory, the ability of a drug to bind to a receptor is its affinity, and the ability to induce functional change in the receptor is designated as the intrinsic activity (IA) of the drug. These 2 properties are independent of each other.

The intrinsic activities of the above groups of drugs are given below: Type of drugs | Intrinsic activity Agonists | 1 Partial agonists | >0 to <1 Competitive antagonists | 0 Inverse agonists | <0 to -1

The image given below shows the action of various types of selective receptor modulators:



Pearl PM1560: Pure opioid antagonists

Naloxone: short-acting opioid antagonist with duration of action of 1-2 hours. Used in opioid overdose and respiratory depression in newborns due to perinatal opioid use.

Naltrexone: long-acting opioid antagonist with effects lasting till 48 hours. Used for prevention of relapse in opioid addiction treatment. It is associated with hepatotoxicity. It does not suppress craving in opioid addiction but suppresses craving in chronic alcoholics.

Nalmefene: long-acting opioid antagonist with a half-life of 8-10 hours administered intravenously. Used in opioid overdose like naloxone.

questions.text: 139. In which of the following structures, is the click-or-pop sensation encountered during spinal anesthesia?
questions.solution:
The click-or-pop sensation in spinal anesthesia is encountered while piercing ligamentum flavum and dura mater.

The spinal needle is introduced parallel to the midline and is advanced through the layers. There is a characteristic loss in resistance felt when the needle passes through ligamentum flavum and dura. On piercing the ligamentum flavum, the first click-or-pop sensation is encountered. On further advancement of the needle, there is a second click or pop sensation encountered on piercing the dura. For spinal anesthesia, the needle is inserted until penetration of the dura-subarachnoid membranes, which is signaled by free-flowing cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).

The following structures are pierced during spinal anesthesia, in that order:

* Skin

* Subcutaneous tissue

* Supraspinous ligament

* Interspinous ligament

* Ligamentum flavum 

* Dura mater

* Arachnoid

questions.text: 140. A 20-year-old primigravida presents to the labour room at 42 weeks of gestation. On examination, the amniotic sac is intact, the cervix is unripe, in the midline, soft in consistency, 3cm dilated, cervical length of 3cm, and the vertex is at -1. What is the most appropriate management of the patient?

choices.text: Favourable score, use Cerviprime for cervical ripening
Unfavourable score, use Cerviprime for cervical ripening
Favourable score, proceed for caesarean section
Unfavourable score, proceed for caesarean section

questions.solution:
The Bishop score of the patient is 8, which is favourable, and the most appropriate management of the patient is to use Cerviprime for cervical ripening.

For the given scenario:

* The cervix is in the midline, hence score = 1 

* Soft in consistency, hence score = 2

* 3cm dilated, hence score = 2

* Cervical length of 3cm, hence score = 1

* The vertex is at -1, hence score = 2 

Therefore, the total score is 8. Induction of labour will be done for the primigravida as the cervix is unripe, the pregnancy has crossed 42 weeks, and the Bishop score is favourable.

The Bishop score is calculated as follows: Parameters | 0 | 1 | 2 | 3 Cervix Dilatation | Closed | 1-2 | 3-4 | 5+ Cervical length | >4 | 2-4 | 1-2 | <1 Cervix Consistency | Firm | Medium | Soft | - Cervix Position | Posterior | Midline | Anterior | - Head station | -3 | -2 | -1,0 | +1, +2

Total score = 13; Favorable score = 6-13; Unfavorable score = 0-5

Induction of labour can be done for a favourable score using a cerviprime gel that contains prostaglandins to help in cervical ripening. The woman should be in bed for 30 minutes following application and is monitored for uterine activity and fetal heart rate.

Other options:

Option C and D: The woman will not be taken up for caesarean section as she is a primigravida without cephalopelvic disproportion or any other indication for caesarean section.
