questions.text: 141. A 10-year-old boy from a rural area presents with prolonged fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and pancytopenia. A rapid diagnostic test for Leishmania donovani is positive. Which of the following is the insect transmitting this disease?
questions.solution:
This patient with a fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and rapid test positive for Leishmania donovani, is most likely suffering from visceral leishmaniasis. The vector in image 2 is sandfly, which is responsible for transmitting Leishmania donovani, the causative agent of visceral leishmaniasis, also known as kala-azar.

Sandflies are generally small insects, light or dark brown. They are smaller than mosquitoes. Their body and wings are densely clothed with hair. Their wings are up-right and lanceolate in shape and their legs are longer compared with the size of the body. They hop about and do not fly much. The species of sandfly responsible for transmitting the disease kala-azar is Phlebotomus argentipes. 

Kala-azar is a chronic and potentially fatal disease if left untreated. It presents with prolonged fever, weight loss, massive hepatosplenomegaly, and pancytopenia due to bone marrow suppression and splenic sequestration. The disease is endemic in parts of South Asia, East Africa, and South America. Diagnosis is often supported by rapid antigen tests (e.g., rK39), and confirmation may involve the detection of amastigotes in tissue samples. Amphotericin B is the first-line drug used in India. 

Other options: 

Option A: Aedes mosquito exhibits hunchback, wings are unspotted, has long legs and scaled wings with a prominent proboscis; transmits dengue, and chikungunya.  It has white stripes on the body and is often and referred to as the “Tiger mosquito”.

Option C: Tsetse flies or glossinae are the blood-sucking flies that resemble the common houseflies. They are yellow or dark brown in color. When folded, their wings overlap each other like the blade of a scissor. They have a non-retractile proboscis which is rigid and adapted for piercing the skin and sucking the blood. They are vectors for trypanosomiasis or sleeping sickness and are only found in regions in Africa.

Option D: Mansonia mosquitoes are big, black or brown mosquitoes with speckling on their wings and legs. They breed in ponds and lakes containing certain aquatic plants, especially the floating types like Pistia stratiotes and water hyacinth. The disease transmitted by the mansonia species of mosquito is Brugian filariasis.

questions.text: 142. A young patient with a history of atopy presented with frequent nighttime awakening due to cough and breathlessness. The patient underwent a PFT, which showed diurnal peak flow variability of 20%. Which of the following pharmacological agents can be given as part of a provocative test to help diagnose the condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests bronchial asthma; a Methacholine challenge test can be used to diagnose this condition.

Methacholine is a cholinergic agonist that acts directly on the smooth muscles of the airway causing bronchoconstriction. It can be used to diagnose bronchial hyperresponsiveness by conducting a bronchoprovocation test. First, the patient must be requested to abstain from any medications that have been given to reduce bronchial hyperresponsiveness.

Then, a baseline spirometry is taken followed by nebulization of increasing concentrations of methacholine. The FEV1 is measured after every dose along and the provocative dose (PD20) or concentration(PC20) required to achieve a 20 percent or greater fall in the FEV1. PD20 of ≤ 200mcg is considered positive whereas ≥ 400mcg is considered negative. A PC20 ≤8mg/ml is positive whereas ≥16mg/ml is negative.

The test has high sensitivity and a strong negative predictive value for ruling out asthma when done properly. Other pharmacological agents that can be used are Mannitol and hypertonic saline.

Other Options:

Option B: Edrophonium is a short-acting anticholinesterase, a drug that inhibits the enzyme acetylcholinesterase, but only transiently. It is used in confusing cases of myasthenia gravis as an adjunct to support the diagnosis. Atropine must be kept in hand in case of any adverse effects.

Option C: Beclomethasone is an inhaled corticosteroid that is used in the maintenance treatment of bronchial asthma. It is given as an inhaled diproprionate prodrug which is converted to an active metabolite in the lung. Side effects are similar to other ICS such as hoarseness of voice and candidiasis.

Option D: Indacaterol is a very long-acting beta-agonist with beta2 selective activity which is approved for the treatment of COPD. Other drugs in this category are vilanterol and olodaterol. Indacaterol shows fast onset of action and little tachyphylaxis with long-term use.

Of note is PFT done with short-acting beta-agonists like Salbutamol for bronchial asthma. Reversibility of PFT which is indicated by a >12% rise in the FEV1 or an absolute increase by >200 ml within 15 minutes of administering beta-agonist is diagnostic of bronchial asthma responsive to beta-agonist.

questions.text: 143. A one-and-a-half-year-old baby is brought to the emergency ward with a generalized tonic-clonic seizure that has lasted for 20 mins without regaining consciousness. The baby is stabilized and then administered intravenous lorazepam. Despite 2 doses, the seizure continues. Which drug is to be given next?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is that of status epilepticus (SE). The drug that is to be administered after lorazepam is IV fosphenytoin.

SE is characterized as ongoing convulsive activity or recurring generalized convulsive seizure activity without recovering consciousness. According to the new definition of SE, two time frames have been defined for each type of seizure. They are called t1 and t2. t1 is the time to reflect as to when the treatment should be initiated and t2 is the time at which continuous seizure activity will lead to long-term complications.

In generalized tonic-clonic seizures, t1 is 5 min and t2 is 30 min. The initial choice of therapy is a benzodiazepine, which includes either of the following:

* Intravenous lorazepam

* Intravenous diazepam 

* Intramuscular midazolam- If IV access is not available

If the seizure still continues, we can repeat the above dose once again. If there is no response even after repeat doses, then a single dose of either of the antiepileptics can be given,

* Intravenous fosphenytoin 

* Intravenous valproic acid 

* Intravenous levetiracetam

questions.text: 144. Which among the following is the active principle present in the dried fruit shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the seeds of Semecarpus anacardium, and its active principles are semecarpol and bhilawanol.

Common names are marking nut, bhilwan, bibva, bhela, and oriental cashew.

The juice when applied locally to the skin produces irritation, painful blisters, itching, and eczematous eruption. The seeds are used to produce an artificial bruise. Symptoms such as pain, fever, and painful passage of brownish urine may be seen.

A large dose taken orally can produce blisters in the mouth and throat, with gastroenteritis. It also produces dyspnea, cyanosis, tachycardia, coma, and death. The fatal period is 12 to 24 hours.

Medicolegal importance is the use of the juice by malingerers to fabricate wounds. Instilled in the eyes it can cause conjunctivitis or ophthalmia due to its local irritant effect.



Other options

Option A: Calotropin is one of the active principles of Calotropis.



Option C: Abrin is the active principle of Abrus precatorius



Option D:  Ricin is the active principle of Ricinus communis.

questions.text: 145. An unimmunized child with a persistent cough underwent a pernasal swab, which was cultured on an enriched, selective medium and yielded characteristic mercury drop/bisected pearl colonies as shown below. Along with isolation, what is the ideal management strategy?
questions.solution:
The given scenario leads to a diagnosis of whooping cough. Azithromycin is started for this patient.

The given clinical vignette describes a child who has not been immunized presenting with a persistent cough. A pernasal swab taken has been cultured on the Bordet Gengou selective, enriched medium, and Bordetella pertussis is grown, as evidenced by the characteristic mercury drop/ bisected pearl colonies.

Bordetella pertussis is the causative agent of Whooping cough, an important pediatric respiratory condition preventable by immunization with the DPT vaccine. Other species known to infect humans are B.parapertussis and B.bronchoseptica.

B.pertussis is an ovoid coccobacillus that is a non-motile, non-sporing, Gram-negative, encapsulated obligate aerobe. Specific culture media are Bordet-Gengou and Regan-Lowe medium. 

On Bordet Gengou agar, characteristic dome-shaped, small, glistening mercury drop/ bisected pearl colonies are produced, surrounded by a hazy zone of hemolysis. Aluminum paint appearance is seen when the bacteria grow in a confluent pattern.



The disease pattern involves 3 stages each spanning approximately 2 weeks after an initial incubation period of 1-2 weeks.

* Catarrhal: Best response to antibiotic, difficult to identify, maximum infectivity, low-grade fever with dry cough and catarrh seen.

* Paroxysmal: Associated with classic paroxysms of whooping cough after which the disease is named. There is a long bout of continuous coughing followed by a classic whoop sound as the patient inspires air into an almost emptied lung. Post-tussive emesis and exhaustion are common.

* Convalescent: Cough frequency and severity decrease and gradually abate.

The major virulence protein is the PT- pertussis toxin. Diagnosis is by taking a pernasal/postnasal swab and subjecting it to microscopy and culture as described above. PCR is routinely used now (in catarrhal and early paroxysmal stages) due to poor culture yield.

In immunised patients, these tests may be negative in the paroxysmal stage. The best test in these individuals is detecting a change in antibody titre in the acute and convalescent phase. CBC usually shows leucocytosis with relative lymphocytosis.

The drug of choice for the treatment of B. pertussis remains Azithromycin in all age groups. If Azithromycin is unavailable,  Erythromycin may be used. 

The dosage of Azithromycin are:

* Infants < 6 months: 10mg/kg/day as a single dose for 5 days 

* Infants > 6 months and children: 10mg/kg/day on day 1 followed by 5mg/kg/day on day 2-5. 

* In adults, it is 500 mg/day on day 1 and 250 mg/day on day 2-5.

Erythromycin is specifically avoided in children < 1 month of age due to the risk of inducing infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. Azithromycin can be used in this age group. Second-line agents are Clarithromycin (not recommended < 1 month) and Trimethoprim-Sulphamethoxazole (contraindicated < 2 months). 

Patients with suspected pertussis are placed under isolation protocol with respiratory droplet precautions and isolated immediately on arrival in a suspected case or outbreak, following which azithromycin is started and the individual should be isolated for 5 days after commencing the antibiotic.

Other Options:

Option A, B, and C: Bordetella species are usually resistant to Penicillin so it is not an effective antibiotic for treatment of the condition. There is no role for the routine use of antitoxin immunoglobulin preparations for treating whooping cough.

questions.text: 146. A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset palpitations and dizziness. Her ECG is shown below. Vagal maneuvers are attempted but fail to terminate the arrhythmia. Intravenous adenosine is administered, and the rhythm abruptly converts to normal sinus. Which of the following best explains the therapeutic effect of adenosine in this patient?

choices.text: Enhances vagal tone to the AV node
Slows conduction through the His-Purkinje system

questions.solution:
The patient presents with sudden-onset palpitations and dizziness, and ECG shows a regular, narrow-complex tachycardia suggestive of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). Adenosine works by temporarily blocking AV nodal conduction.

Management for hemodynamically stable regular narrow-complex tachycardia (likely PSVT) begins with vagal maneuvers to increase AV nodal refractoriness; if ineffective, intravenous adenosine is the next step. If the rhythm remains or recurs, non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (e.g., verapamil, diltiazem) or beta-blockers can be used. For recurrent or incessant cases, antiarrhythmic drugs or catheter ablation may be considered. In cases with hemodynamic instability, immediate cardioversion is indicated.

Adenosine binds to A1 receptors in the AV node, causing hyperpolarization of the tissue and suppression of calcium-dependent action potentials, which temporarily halts AV nodal conduction. This interruption breaks the reentrant loop and allows the restoration of normal sinus rhythm.

Other options:

Option A: Enhances vagal tone to the AV node: This is the mechanism of vagal maneuvers like carotid massage or Valsalva. Adenosine acts directly on receptors, not by increasing vagal tone.

Option B: Slows conduction through the His-Purkinje system: This is the primary action of Class I antiarrhythmics like Flecainide and Procainamide, which block sodium channels to slow depolarization in fast-conducting tissues.

Option D: Increases atrial refractory period: Class III antiarrhythmics like Amiodarone and Ibutilide increase the refractory period in atrial tissue by blocking potassium channels and prolonging repolarization.

questions.text: 147. Which of the following best describes Mirizzi syndrome?

choices.text: Gallstone  impacted directly in the common bile duct causing intraluminal obstruction and jaundice
Gallstone impacted in the common hepatic duct causing intrinsic obstruction and bile leak
Gallstone impacted in the cystic duct or gallbladder neck causing extrinsic compression of the common bile duct and jaundice
Gallstone impacted in the renal pelvis causing ureteric colic and hematuria

questions.solution:
Mirizzi syndrome is described as a gallstone impacted in the cystic duct or gallbladder neck, causing extrinsic compression of the common bile duct and jaundice.

Mirizzi syndrome is a rare complication of longstanding gallstone disease where a gallstone becomes impacted in the cystic duct or gallbladder neck (Hartmann’s pouch). This impacted stone causes extrinsic compression of the adjacent common bile duct (CBD). As a result, bile flow is obstructed, leading to cholestasis.

MRCP or ERCP is used to diagnose Mirizzi syndrome. Surgical removal of the cystic duct, diseased gallbladder, and the impacted stone is the definitive management.

Pearl PM1530: Mirizzi’s syndrome

Gallstone becomes impacted in the cystic duct or neck of the gallbladder producing CBD obstruction and jaundice.



* ERCP, PTC, MRCP will usually demonstrate the characteristic extrinsic compression of the CBD. 

* Surgery consists of removing the cystic duct, diseased gallbladder, and the impacted stone.

questions.text: 148. A patient presents with an inability to close the left eye, purse the lips, raise the eyebrows, or whistle following cranial surgery. There is a loss of taste sensation from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue. The Schirmer test is normal, and the stapedial reflex is present. What is the most likely site of nerve injury?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient has paralysis of the facial muscles, loss of taste sensation from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue with normal Schirmer test, and stapedial reflex. Therefore, the most likely site of facial nerve injury is above the stylomastoid foramen.



The course of the facial nerve is divided into intracranial (cisternal), intratemporal and extratemporal portions.

Intracranial portion- The facial nerve nucleus lies in the caudal pontine reticular formation near the trapezoid nucleus and nucleus of the trigeminal nerve. Fibres from this nucleus curve around the abducens nucleus and emerge at the cerebellopontine angle.

The intratemporal portion is from the internal acoustic meatus to the stylomastoid foramen. This is further divided into meatal, labyrinthine, tympanic (horizontal), and mastoid (vertical) segments.

* Meatal- The facial nerve passes through the internal acoustic meatus along with the nervus intermedius, cochlear nerve, and superior and inferior vestibular nerves. It passes above the transverse crest. It is separated from the superior vestibular nerve by Bill's bar.

* Labyrinthine segment is from the internal acoustic meatus to the first genu near the geniculate ganglion. It is the shortest and narrowest part of the facial nerve and is susceptible to vascular compression.

* Tympanic part- is the horizontal part of the facial nerve. It curves around the oval window niche then lies just anterior and inferior to the lateral semicircular canal. After this, the nerve makes a second bend (genu) to continue as a vertical part.

* Mastoid part- is the longest part and runs up to the stylomastoid foramen.

Branches from the intratemporal facial nerve:

* Greater superficial petrosal nerve- It arises from the geniculate ganglion. It contains parasympathetic fibres for the lacrimal gland and palate.

* Nerve to stapedius- It arises from the facial nerve in the posterior wall of the tympanic cavity. It supplies stapedius muscle

* Chorda tympani leaves the facial nerve around 6mm above the stylomastoid foramen. It contains parasympathetic fibres that supply the submandibular and sublingual salivary glands via the submandibular ganglion and taste fibres from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

Extratemporal portion - The facial nerve emerges from the base of the skull at the stylomastoid foramen and supplies the posterior belly of the digastric, stylohyoid, occipitofrontalis, and other facial muscles.

Option A- Injury proximal to the geniculate ganglion will damage the greater superficial petrosal nerve, nerve to stapedius, chorda tympani, and muscular branches. There is loss of lacrimal secretions, loss of stapedial reflex, loss of taste in the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue, and facial paralysis.

Option B- Injury above the stapedius will lead to damage of nerve to the stapedius, chorda tympani, and muscular branches. There is loss of stapedial reflex, loss of taste in the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue, and facial paralysis.

Option D- Injury at or below the stylomastoid foramen will lead to paralysis of facial muscles, but the taste sensation, stapedial reflex, and secretions of the eye are normal.

questions.text: 149. A 30-year-old woman presents with malaise and decreased urine output over the past 3 days. She was started on rifampicin 7 days ago. She denies dysuria or hematuria. On examination, she has a faint, non-blanching, maculopapular rash on her trunk. Laboratory tests show raised creatinine and eosinophilia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform renal biopsy to confirm the diagnosis
Discontinue rifampicin and repeat renal function tests after a week
Initiate Tacrolimus to counter the immune response
Obtain anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA) testing to rule out vasculitis

questions.solution:
The most appropriate next step in management is to discontinue rifampicin and repeat renal function tests after a week. 

In this clinical scenario, the patient presents with new-onset acute kidney injury (elevated creatinine), recent antibiotic use (rifampicin), a maculopapular rash and eosinophilia, which are all classic features of acute interstitial nephritis (AIN). The first step in management is to immediately discontinue the suspected offending agent, as this can lead to recovery of kidney function. 

Acute interstitial nephritis (AIN) is an immune-mediated inflammation of the kidney interstitium and tubules, most commonly triggered by medications such as antibiotics, NSAIDs, and proton pump inhibitors.

Clinical features of AIN typically include acute kidney injury developing days to weeks after drug exposure, often accompanied by a maculopapular rash, peripheral eosinophilia, and nonspecific symptoms like malaise or flank tenderness. Fever and eosinophilia may occur, but are not always present.

Diagnosis is mainly clinical, based on the combination of recent exposure to a potential trigger and evidence of acute kidney injury. Urinalysis may show pyuria, white blood cell casts, or hematuria. Urine eosinophil testing is unreliable and not recommended. Although a kidney biopsy showing interstitial infiltration with eosinophils can confirm the diagnosis, it is usually reserved for unclear or severe cases.

Treatment of AIN involves immediate discontinuation of the suspected offending agent, which often leads to recovery. If kidney function fails to improve in 1 week or if the injury is severe and rapidly progressive, glucocorticoids such as prednisone may be considered to accelerate recovery, but they are not first-line therapy. 

Other options:

Option A: Renal biopsy is done in cases of atypical features and if no improvement is seen after stopping the offending drug and initiating supportive care after 1 week or if there is rapid deterioration of renal function.

Option C: Immunosuppressive drugs like Tacrolimus are initiated when granulomatous or immune-mediated interstitial nephritis is confirmed on biopsy.

Option D: ANCA testing is not the next step of management since there is no evidence of vasculitis, like hematuria, red blood cell casts, and respiratory symptoms, along with rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: 150. A 42-year-old female undergoes bariatric surgery via a novel minimally invasive approach. Postoperatively, she is surprised to find no abdominal incisions or visible scars. The operative note highlights technical challenges in closing the internal access site. Which of the following best describes the surgical technique used in this case?
questions.solution:
Natural Orifice Transluminal Endoscopic Surgery (NOTES) technique involves accessing the abdominal cavity through a natural orifice such as the mouth, vagina, or rectum.

An internal incision is made in a visceral organ (e.g., the stomach or vaginal wall) to reach the peritoneal cavity, allowing for scarless surgery. In the case described, the absence of external incisions indicates a NOTES procedure. One major technical challenge with NOTES is the internal closure of the organ through which access was gained, as this must be secure to prevent infection or leakage.

It has cosmetic benefits (no visible scars), reduced postoperative pain, quicker recovery, and possibly fewer wound-related complications. 

Other options:

Option A: Laparoscopic single-incision surgery (SILS) is a minimally invasive technique done through a single port. It reduces scarring compared to multi-port laparoscopy but still involves a visible incision.

Option B: Robotic-assisted laparoscopic surgery (RALS) involves the use of robotic systems like the Da Vinci platform to perform surgeries with enhanced precision, control, and 3D visualisation through multiple small abdominal ports. The site of incisions and scars can be seen on the ports created. 

Option C: Laparoscopic gastric bypass surgery is a minimally invasive surgery where instruments are inserted through the abdomen, and hence, the scars can be seen.

questions.text: 151. A 45-year-old male patient with poor dental hygiene presents to you with complaints of severe pain during swallowing and difficulty opening the mouth. He also has a neck swelling, as shown in the image, which he says has been increasing over the past 3 days. O/E, there is a woody hard swelling of the floor of the mouth. This condition can occur due to infection in all of the following spaces of the mandible except _________
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Ludwig's angina, which is the infection of the mandibular spaces occurs due to infection in the Sublingual, Submandibular, and Submental spaces of the mandible. Here Parotid space is not involved.

The Submandibular Space lies between the mylohyoid muscle and the superficial layer of deep cervical fascia. The fascia is tightly attached to the mandible and the hyoid bone. The space contains the submandibular salivary gland and the lymph nodes. It communicates with the sublingual space and with the submental space. 

Sublingual Space lies above the mylohyoid muscle and underneath the oral mucosa. 

Submental Space lies between the symphysis of the mandible anteriorly, the hyoid bone below and posteriorly and the anterior belly of the digastric muscle laterally. The mylohyoid muscle forms the floor of this space. It is bounded by the superficial layer of deep cervical fascia inferiorly. 

Both compartments freely communicate in the midline with the opposite side. Therefore infection rapidly becomes bilateral.

Dental infections are the most common cause and account for 80% of the cases.

Clinical features:

* Marked difficulty in swallowing (odynophagia) with varying degrees of trismus.

* When infection is localised to the sublingual space, structures in the floor of the mouth are swollen, and the tongue seems to be pushed up and back.

* When the infection spreads to the submandibular regions become swollen, tender and impart a woody-hard feel.

* Usually, there is cellulitis of the tissues rather than frank abscess.

* The tongue is progressively pushed upwards and backwards, threatening the airway.

Treatment:

* Systemic antibiotics.

* Incision and drainage of an abscess.

* Tracheostomy, if there is severe obstruction of the airway.

questions.text: 152. The image below is of a patient who underwent an eye surgery. Which of the following is an indication for this procedure?

choices.text: Congenital coloboma of the uveal tract

questions.solution:
The image shows a peripheral iridotomy(PI) hole in the upper left quadrant of the iris. Among the given options, acute congestive glaucoma is the most likely indication for a PI.

A peripheral iridotomy is a surgical procedure used in the definitive management of acute congestive glaucoma after initial control of symptoms. It involves the creation of a direct communication between the posterior chamber and the trabecular meshwork, allowing aqueous humor to drain out of the eye. 

An important consequence of PI is that the iris stops bowing forward into the trabecular meshwork, facilitating aqueous drainage. PI is usually performed using an Nd: YAG laser and the opening is at least 150-200 microns for best results. The hole is made in the mid-periphery of the iris in the 11 or 1 o'clock position. Postoperatively, steroids and anti-glaucoma drugs are indicated to control inflammation and prevent a rise in IOP. 

Patency of the PI is tested after 2-4 weeks and gonioscopy is repeated. In case a chronic raised IOP is detected, further medical and surgical management is warranted. Usually, the outcome of PI is good and IOP falls to the normal range. Prophylactic laser PI is usually given to the unaffected eye, to prevent an acute attack.

The treatment of acute angle closure glaucoma includes:

*  After ensuring no cardiovascular risk, the patient must be administered IV mannitol and/or IV acetazolamide 500mg to reduce the extremely high IOP seen in these patients. Additionally, corneal edema reduces along with better perfusion to the iris.

* Topical pilocarpine must be instilled at 2% concentration to constrict the pupil and pull the bunched-up iris away from the closed angle to facilitate drainage.

* Other topical anti-glaucoma drugs may be used as required for IOP control.

* Mechanical pushing of the central cornea with a moist cotton swab may be attempted to displace the aqueous into the periphery towards the angle. 

* Definitive management is with a mandatory laser PI as discussed above in both eyes once initial medical management is done.

Other Options:

Option A: Congenital coloboma of the uveal tract is an incomplete closure of the uvea, usually in the lower part of the eye associated with deficient iris and uveal tissue. Prophylactic laser delimitation of the lower retina may be done to prevent detachment. PI is not indicated.

Option C: Primary congenital glaucoma is due to the abnormal development of the trabecular meshwork. Medications are usually not very effective and the treatment of choice is surgical goniotomy or a trabeculotomy. PI is not effective as it is not an acute condition and the problem is in the trabecular meshwork.

Option D: Toxic anterior segment syndrome is a post-cataract complication involving sterile inflammation of the anterior segment due to ethylene gas used to sterilize IOLs or the lens material. Treatment is with steroids, not PI.

questions.text: 153. A 62-year-old male patient arrives at the emergency department of a medical college hospital, presenting with slurred speech and right-sided weakness that has persisted for the last three hours. His blood pressure is measured at 200/100 mmHg. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are likely suggestive of a stroke. Non-contrast CT head is the first imaging to be done in a suspected case of stroke to differentiate between hemorrhagic and ischemic etiology.

Once stroke is suspected, the first priority is to assess airway and blood pressure, followed by establishing the time last normal. As soon as the diagnosis of stroke is made clinically, a non-contrast CT (NCCT) head is done to differentiate between hemorrhagic and ischemic stroke, because the management of the two is entirely different. IV thrombolysis therapy can only be considered in stroke patients with ischemic aetiology only after ruling out haemorrhage.

When the symptom onset is less than 4.5 hours and there is no haemorrhage on NCCT, the patient is eligible for IV thrombolysis therapy. Ischemic stroke is difficult to detect on NCCT in the initial few hours. Immediate NCCT is primarily helpful in ruling out hemorrhagic stroke in patients with ischemic stroke. Early ischemic changes can be detected using MRI brain using DWI sequence, however, MRI is time-consuming, not easily available and is not preferred in acute settings. So, NCCT is the next step in management before starting an IV thrombolysis therapy (Option A).

Later, CT angiography is done to find out if the occlusion is in the larger arteries of the brain, such as the internal carotid artery, middle cerebral artery, and basilar artery. Such occlusions involve large clots and fail to open with IV thrombolysis alone. For these patients, mechanical thrombectomy is done.

Conventional x-ray cerebral angiography (Option D) remains the gold standard method for detecting and measuring arterial narrowing due to atherosclerosis in the brain’s vessels. Because it carries risks including vessel injury, groin bleeding, embolic stroke, and contrast-induced kidney injury, it is reserved for cases in which noninvasive techniques cannot provide sufficient diagnostic information.

Mechanical thrombectomy (Option B) is also indicated in patients presenting after 4.5 hours but within 24 hours, with the angiography/perfusion study showing good perfusion of the penumbra.

Pearl PM1788: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

* Clinical diagnosis of stroke

* Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours

* Age ≥ 18 years

* CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

* Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment

* Bleeding diathesis

* Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage

* Major surgery in preceding 14 days

* Minor stroke symptoms

* Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days

* Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text: 154. A 20-year-old man presented to the emergency department with complaints of breathing difficulty. The arterial pressure waveform is shown below. Which of the following heart sounds coincides with the arrow?
questions.solution:
The image shows an arterial pulse waveform with an arrow pointing to the dicrotic notch. The second heart sound coincides with the dicrotic notch.

The dicrotic notch represents a brief rise in aortic pressure that occurs immediately after the aortic valve closes at the end of the systole. As the left ventricle finishes ejecting blood and begins to relax (isovolumetric relaxation), the aortic valve shuts to prevent backflow.

This sudden closure causes a momentary backflow of blood toward the valve, creating a small, transient increase in pressure, visible as the dicrotic notch. It is a key marker of the transition from systole to diastole and coincides with the second heart sound (S2).

questions.text: 155. A patient suffered a penetrating injury to the arm, resulting in a nerve injury that affected the coracobrachialis muscle. Which other muscle is most likely to be paralyzed in this patient?
questions.solution:
The Biceps brachii muscle is likely to be paralyzed in this patient.

The given clinical scenario involves a patient who suffered penetrating trauma to the arm, resulting in a nerve injury that affected the coracobrachialis muscle, which is seen in musculocutaneous nerve palsy.

The musculocutaneous nerve( C5, C6, C7) arises from the lateral cord of the brachial plexus opposite the lower border of the pectoralis minor. It pierces and supplies the coracobrachialis, following which it gives branches to the Brachialis and Biceps brachii before terminating as the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm.

The musculocutaneous nerve may be injured in penetrating injuries in the arm(the most common mechanism), or by anterior shoulder dislocation or fracture of the neck of the humerus. Usually, injury to this nerve is accompanied by injury to other structures of the brachial plexus, such as in Erb’s palsy.

Clinical examination for the musculocutaneous nerve involves:

* Testing muscles: Biceps brachii (flexion and supination at forearm), Brachialis ( flexion at the forearm), Coracobrachialis (flexion at the shoulder ), of which Biceps is the most reliable muscle, and its bulk can be palpated to rule out compensatory flexion by Brachioradialis when testing the musculocutaneous nerve.

* Sensations: Lateral aspect of the forearm from the elbow to the wrist. Total anesthesia in injury is uncommon.

Musculocutaneous nerve injuries do not cause severe disability, hence, suture repair may not be undertaken in the elderly. After surgical repair, the outcome is usually good.



Other Options:

Option A: Teres major is supplied by the lower subscapular nerve. The Teres minor is supplied by the axillary nerve, which is frequently injured in anterior shoulder dislocation. Teres minor assists in lateral rotation of the arm at the shoulder joint, while Teres major is a medial rotator, adductor, and extensor of the arm.

Option C: Flexor carpi radialis is supplied by the Median nerve and is affected in high median nerve injuries, such as those around the elbow. It flexes and abducts the hand at the wrist joint.

Option D: Flexor carpi ulnaris is supplied by the Ulnar nerve and is affected in high ulnar palsy, such as those seen in medial epicondyle of the elbow fracture. It flexes and adducts the hand at the wrist joint.

questions.text: 156. A patient who had nephrotic proteinuria was observed to have an unusual pattern on the nails, shown below. The pattern fades on applying pressure. What is this characteristic nail finding called?
questions.solution:
The image shown is that of Muehrcke lines, which are specific for hypoalbuminemia.

The given clinical scenario describes a patient who has nephrotic proteinuria. This implies that the patient will have albuminuria and hypoalbuminemia. In such a patient, transverse white lines may be seen on the nail which are termed as Muehrcke's lines.

The white lines are paralell to the lunula and separated by pink areas. They are frequently found on the 2nd,3rd and 4th nails and tend to spare the thumb. They fade on applying pressure on the nail and are believed to occur due to localized edema over that part of the nail bed.

A special feature of these lines is that they disappear on IV administration of albumin and correction of the plasma protein deficit. Hence, they are reversible and an example of apparent leuconychia. Other causes of apparent leuconychia are Terry's nails and half-and-half nails (half white-half dark/normal). All causes of apparent leuconychia fade on applying pressure.

Other Options:

Option B: Aldrich-Mees lines are transverse white lines parallel to the lunula. They are seen in thallium/arsenic poisoning and chemotherapy(eg daunorubicin) and are a type of true leuconychia, which means that they do not fade on applying pressure. They occur due to abnormal keratinization at the nail bed. The below image shows Mees lines:



Option C: Beau's lines are partial thickness transverse grooves on the nail that occur due to improper nail plate formation, which occurs when its synthesis is disrupted by a local or systemic insult. These grooves run parallel to the lunula and may be deeper in the center. They are typically found on the great toe and thumb. Causes are myocardial infarction, mumps, measles, trauma, inflammation or neurological events etc



Option D: Hutchinson's sign is seen in melanonychia which is a longitudinal band of melanised(dark) nail associated with the extension of the pigmentation to the periungual skin. It is an important indicator to assess for acral lentiginous melanoma which tends to occur in the fingers.

questions.text: 157. Given below is an X-ray of the dorsolumbar spine in oblique view, showing a Scottie Dog. Where is this seen?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray of the spine in oblique view is a normal oblique view with a preserved Scottie dog.

The Scottie-dog sign/ Scottish terrier dog sign is a sign used to describe a normal oblique view of the dorsolumbar spine. On an oblique view, the pars interarticularis area of the vertebra appears like a Scottish dog. Whenever there is a fracture or other abnormality in the pars interarticularis, this dog is abnormal.

Below is given an image of a normal Scottish dog sign:



If the Scottish dog appears to be wearing a collar, then it is a defect in the pars interarticularis, namely spondylolysis. Spondylolysis is a condition in which there is a break in the pars interarticularis, usually seen in the L5 lumbar vertebra. An image of a Scottish dog wearing a collar is shown below:



If the Scottish dog appears to be beheaded, with a large distance between the "head" and the "body" of the dog, it is suggestive of spondylolisthesis. Spondylolisthesis is a condition where there is forward displacement of one vertebra over the one beneath it , most often seen in L5 over S1.

Meyerding classified spondylolisthesis into 5 grades based on the degree of displacement of the vertebra. Grade 5 which is >100 percent displacement of the vertebra is called spondyloptosis. In spondyloptosis, there will be an even wider gap between the neck and head of the dog. The below image shows a beheaded Scottish dog :

questions.text: 158. A 30-year-old male with confirmed multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) is started on the BPaLM regimen (New MDR regimen by WHO). Which of the following is not an exclusion criterion of this regimen?
questions.solution:
Abdominal tuberculosis is not an exclusion criterion of the BPaLM regimen for MDR-TB.

Exclusion criteria of the BPaLM regimen include - 

* Person with documented resistance to Bedaquiline, Linezolid, and/ or Pretomanid.

* People with severe forms of extrapulmonary-MDR-TB, like CNS TB, spinal/ skeletal TB, or disseminated TB (miliary TB or TB with multiorgan involvement)

* Age < 14 years 

* Person with significant liver dysfunction [LFT (Liver enzymes and/ or total bilirubin); AST/ALT>3.0 x Upper Limit of Normal (ULN) and Total Bilirubin >2.0 x ULN]

* Person with significant cardiac conduction abnormalities, including structural heart disease, long QT syndrome, AV blocks, re-entry arrhythmias 

BPaLM is a combination of four drugs- Bedaquiline, Pretomanid, Linezolid and Moxifloxacin, which are given for 6 months. The shorter duration of treatment and better efficacy of this regimen in comparison to the conventional 20-month regimen make it a better alternative. All four drugs are bactericidal but have different mechanisms of action: 

* Bedaquiline (Bdq)– inhibits the ATP synthase enzyme of mycobacteria  

* Pretomanid (Pa)- inhibits the mycolic acid synthesis of the bacterial cell wall

* Linezolid (Lzd)– inhibits protein synthesis by acting on the 50s ribosome.

* Moxifloxacin- a fluoroquinolone, which inhibits DNA gyrase and topoisomerase.

Pearl PM1720: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases.  All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II) Type of TB Case | Intensive Phase | Continuation Phase New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) | 2 months HRZE | 4 months HRE (Only HR as per WHO guidelines) Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

* Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.

* Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 

* Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.

* Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.

* Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

questions.text: 159. A 35-year-old woman presented with postural dizziness and fatigue. On examination, her skin shows hyperpigmentation on her lips, palmar creases, knuckles, and in the paraumbilical region. On examination, her pulse is 96 bpm and her blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg. She has history of autoimmune hypothyroidism. Which of the following syndromes can be suspected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is suggestive of Primary adrenal insufficiency / Addison’s disease. Along with association of autoimmune hypothyroidism with signs or symptoms of Addison’s disease, we can suspect Schmidt’s syndrome in this patient.

Primary adrenal insufficiency or Addison's disease, occurs due to the impaired secretion of both glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids, resulting in various clinical manifestations. Clinical features include weakness and fatigue, weight loss, hyperpigmentation, hypotension, and electrolyte imbalance(hyponatremia and hyperkalemia).

Adrenal destruction from autoimmune causes is the most common cause. It is often associated with infectious etiology predominantly tuberculous, adrenal replacement by metastatic tumor, and adrenal haemorrhage. 

Schmidt's syndrome, also known as Autoimmune Polyglandular Syndrome Type 2 (APS-2), is a rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the combined occurrence of Addison's disease (primary adrenal insufficiency) with other autoimmune conditions such as hypothyroidism, hyperthyroidism, premature ovarian failure, vitiligo, type 1 diabetes mellitus or pernicious anemia. It is seen associated with HLA-DR3, CTLA-4 mutations.

Primary adrenal insufficiency when associated with hypoparathyroidism, chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis, or rarely lymphomas, we can suspect, Autoimmune Polyglandular Syndrome Type 1 (APS-1). It is seen associated with AIRE gene mutation.

Other options:

Option A: Myxedema coma can present with hypotension and features of hypothyroidism, but it is characterized by decreased mental status, hypothermia, bradycardia, hyponatremia, hypoglycemia, and hypoventilation.

Option B: Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome is adrenal gland failure due to haemorrhage, commonly caused by sepsis. Typically, bacteria responsible for this syndrome is Neisseria meningitidis, which leads to massive bleeding into one or both adrenal glands.

Option D: Conn syndrome is characterized by excessive production of aldosterone by the adrenal glands. Patients commonly present with fatigue, muscle weakness, headaches, palpitations, and high blood pressure.

Pearl PM1419: Causes of Adrenocortical Insufficiency

* Anatomical destruction of gland

* Autoimmune (Addison's disease)

* Isolated autoimmune adrenalitis (polygenic)

* Infections - HIV, tuberculosis, fungi

* Surgical removal

* Acute hemorrhagic necrosis (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome)

* Amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis

* Enzyme inhibitors – metyrapone, ketoconazole

questions.text: 160. A 60-year-old male, who is a known case of alcoholic liver disease, presents with reduced urine output. On ultrasonography, both kidneys appear normal and you suspect hepatorenal syndrome in this patient. A progressive rise in which of the following blood parameters is considered most appropriate while making this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hepatorenal syndrome is characterized by a progressive rise in serum creatinine in a patient who has established acute or chronic liver disease.

Hepatorenal syndrome (HRS) is a form of functional renal failure without any renal pathology that occurs in some patients with advanced cirrhosis or acute liver failure. The pathophysiological hallmark is severe renal vasoconstriction.

Clinical presentation includes:

* A progressive rise in serum creatinine

* Nonoliguria or oliguria, depending upon the severity and duration

* No or minimal proteinuria (less than 500 mg per day)

* A very low rate of sodium excretion.

The diagnosis of HRS is one of exclusion and depends mainly on the serum creatinine level, as no specific tests establish the diagnosis of HRS. 

There are two types of HRS:

* Type 1 HRS: There is progressive impairment in renal function and a marked decline in creatinine clearance within 1–2 weeks of presentation.

* Type 2 HRS: There is a drop in glomerular filtration rate with elevated creatinine levels. It has a better prognosis than type 1 HRS.

Ultrasound of the kidney shows a normal study, and hyaline casts may be observed, indicating prerenal failure.

Management:

* Stop diuretics

* Albumin infusion at 1g/kg/day

* Medical management:

* Vasopressin analogs- Terlipressin

* Somatostatin analogs- Octreotide

* Alpha-adrenergic agonists- Midodrine, Noradrenaline

* Definitive treatment: Liver transplantation

questions.text: 161. What will happen to the intensity of radiation according to the inverse square law if the distance from the source is increased from 1 metre to 4 metres?
questions.solution:
The intensity of radiation will become 1/16 times if the distance from the source is increased from 1 metre to 4 metres.

The exposure rate to radiation decreases by the inverse square of the distance between the measurement location and the source. This principle is called the inverse square law. This relationship is only valid for point sources. 

Intensity of Radiation ∝ (1/distance)²

Intensity of Radiation ∝ (1/4)²   ∝ (1/16)

questions.text: 162. In the below-given project, which pathway if delayed causes a delay in the entire project?

choices.text: Start-->task A--> task D--> task E--> Finish
Start--> task B--> task C--> Finish

questions.solution:
Here the longest pathway is option C as it consists of (5+6)11 days, and so is the critical path.

The critical path is the longest path in the network analysis. Any delay in the critical path will delay the entire project. The critical path method is a type of network technique. 

The other common type of network technique is the program evaluation and review technique. An arrow diagram that depicts the logical sequence of events that must take place is constructed. The time duration that can be allotted to each activity is easily calculated. This helps to minimize any delays in the implementation of the plan.

Other options:

Option A: It is only 2 days, so it cannot be the critical pathway.

Option B: It adds up to 10 days and therefore is not the critical pathway.

Option D: Although task D is the longest activity, it is not the longest pathway.

Pearl PM0164: Network Analysis in Health Management

A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Two types of network analysis: PERT and CPM

1. Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)

* An arrow diagram of all events in logical sequence is drawn.

* Time to finish each activity can be calculated and critical activities can be identified.

* It aids in planning, scheduling and monitoring of the project.



2. Critical Path Method (CPM)

* The longest path of the network is called the critical path.

* A delay in the critical path will cause a delay in the entire project.

questions.text: 163. What is the correct statement regarding the wound indicated by the red arrow in the given image of the skull?

choices.text: It is an entry wound because the outer table appears bevelled
It is an Exit wound because the inner table appears bevelled
It is an Exit wound because the outer table appears bevelled
It is an entry wound because the inner table appears bevelled

questions.solution:
In the given image, bevelling is seen on the outer table and a punched out hole is seen on the inner table. So, it is an exit wound.

Entry wound: The initial contact of the missile punches a clean hole through the outer table of the skull. Where the bullet emerges internally, the inner table is then unsupported and a cone-shaped plug is detached, forming a crater that is appreciably larger than the external hole.

* Bevelling: inner table

* Punched out hole: outer table

Exit wound: If the bullet traverses the cranium and penetrates the opposite side, the same pattern occurs, this time with the small hole on the inner table and the crater on the outside.

* Bevelling: outer table

* Punched out hole: inner table

questions.text: 164. An abdominal X-ray of a baby who presented with abdominal distension and hematochezia showed air in the bowel wall. Which of the following is the greatest risk factor for the development of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a baby presenting with abdominal distension and hematochezia, with X-ray findings of pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall) is suggestive of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). Prematurity is the greatest risk factor for developing NEC.

NEC is the most common life-threatening gastrointestinal disorder in newborns. It is characterized by mucosal or transmural inflammation resulting in necrosis of the intestinal tract. It most commonly affects the distal ileum and proximal colon. Three major risk factors implicated are prematurity (the greatest risk factor), formula feeding, and bacterial colonization of the intestine.

Babies usually present within the 2nd or 3rd week of life with abdominal distension and tenderness, feed intolerance, and occult/gross blood in the stool. Systemic features include hypotension, bradycardia, lethargy, and temperature instability.

Diagnosis can be made with a plain abdominal X-ray. The important signs are pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall), portal vein gas, and pneumoperitoneum (indicates perforation).

The given X-ray shows pneumatosis intestinalis (black arrows).



Management of NEC includes supportive measures like keeping the baby nil per oral (NPO), nasogastric decompression, intravenous fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and inotropic support if indicated. Perforation is an absolute indication for surgery. The most effective preventive strategy is the use of human milk.

questions.text:
165. During an antenatal USG for a fetus with a congenital anomaly, the radiologist divided the uterus into four quadrants and measured the single deepest vertical pocket in each quadrant, given below. Identify the most likely inference based on the given findings:

Quadrant 1: 7cm Quandrant 2: 11cm Quadrant 3: 6cm Quadrant 4: 5cm

choices.text: Mother may have taken ACE inhibitors

questions.solution:
The most likely inference based on the given findings of polyhydramnios on the AFI scan is that the fetus may have esophageal atresia.

The given clinical scenario describes a pregnant mother undergoing an antenatal ultrasound for her fetus who has a congenital anomaly. The sonologist divides the uterus into four quadrants and finds the single deepest vertical pocket of amniotic fluid in each quadrant. This information can be used to extrapolate the amniotic fluid index or AFI.

The AFI can be calculated as the sum of the single deepest pocket in each quadrant. This will be Q1+Q2+Q3+Q4=7cm+11cm+6cm+5cm= 29cm.

Normal AFI values are from 5-25 cm. Less than 5 cm is considered as oligohydramnios and >25cm is considered as polyhydramnios. Hence the inference in this AN scan is that the pregnancy is complicated by polyhydramnios.

Polyhydramnios can occur when there is esophageal atresia  as the foetus is unable to swallow amniotic fluid, which is one of the mechanisms by which the volume of amniotic fluid is regulated in pregnancy. Failure to swallow amniotic fluid due to esophageal obstruction causes pooling of the fluid and polyhydramnios.

Polyhydramnios on AFI scans can be graded as mild(25-29.9), moderate(30-34.9), and severe(35 cm and more). Here there is mild polyhydramnios.

Another method to quantify the amniotic fluid is by a single deepest pocket (SDP) which is measured in the sagittal plane and a minimum pocket of 1cm should be present for measurement. Fetal parts and umbilical cord must not hinder the assessment.

The normal range of SDP is considered >2cm and <8 cm. <2cm is considered oligohydramnios and>8cm is polyhydramnios. A general rule of thumb is that AFI is usually three times the SDP.

Other options:

Options A and B: Both NSAIDs and ACE inhibitors are known to cause oligohydramnios by reducing placental perfusion and harming the fetal kidneys.

Option C: Renal agenesis in the fetus reduces amniotic fluid volume as urine is not produced in adequate quantity resulting in oligohydramnios.

Pearl PM1829: Causes of oligohydramnios and polyhydramnios

* Neck masses

* Esophageal atresia

* Aneuploidy

* Hydrops fetalis

* TTTS Placental | Failure of secretion:- e.g. Amnion nodosum | Chorangioma of placenta

questions.text: 166. A patient came to the emergency department with dyspnea and palpitations. He is a known case of chronic kidney disease. ECG of the patient is given below. 10% calcium gluconate was infused intravenously to tackle cardiac instability. What is the next step in management of this patient?

choices.text: Potassium bicarbonate or potassium citrate  administration
900 mg of calcium in 1 L of 5% dextrose
Volume expansion with 4-6 litres of saline to treat hypercalcemia

questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation and the tall T waves on ECG indicate hyperkalemia, which is commonly seen in a patient with chronic kidney disease. After immediate antagonism of the cardiac effects of hyperkalemia with calcium gluconate, the next step in management of hyperkalemia is rapid reduction of plasma K+ concentration using intravenous insulin.

The earliest ECG change with hyperkalemia is usually the peaking (“tenting”) of the T waves. With further increases in the serum potassium concentration, the QRS complexes widen, the P waves decrease in amplitude and may disappear, and finally, a sine-wave pattern leads to asystole unless emergency therapy is given. 

The steps of management of hyperkalemia are as follows - 

* Immediate antagonism of the cardiac effects of hyperkalemia: Calcium raises the action potential threshold and reduces excitability, without changing the resting membrane potential, thereby reversing the depolarising blockade due to potassium. 10 ml of 10% calcium gluconate should be infused intravenously over 2-3 minutes with cardiac monitoring. Effects start in 1-3 mins.

* Rapid reduction of plasma K+ concentration by redistribution into cells: Insulin shifts K+ into the cells; 10 units of intravenous regular insulin followed by 50 ml of 50% dextrose. Effects start in 10-20 minutes. β2-agonists with insulin have additive effects on potassium concentration. 10-20 mg of nebulised albuterol in 4 ml of normal saline, inhaled over 10 minutes. Effects start at 30 mins

* Removal of potassium: Cation exchange resins such as sodium polystyrene sulfonate (SPS) exchange Na+ for K+ in the GI tract and increase faecal excretion of K+. 15-30 g of powder in a suspension with 33% sorbitol. Novel intestinal potassium binders have recently become available for the management of hyperkalemia. These agents lack the intestinal toxicity of SPS and are preferred over SPS for the management of hyperkalemia. Hemodialysis is the most reliable and effective method.

Therapy with intravenous saline may be beneficial in hypovolemic patients with oliguria and decreased distal delivery of Na+, with the associated reductions in renal K+ excretion. 

Other options:

Option B: Potassium bicarbonate or potassium citrate  administration is done in cases of hypokalemia. ST depression, prominent U waves, and prolonged repolarization are the ECG changes seen in hypokalemia.

Option C: Constant intravenous infusion of calcium gluconate or 900 mg of calcium in 1 L of 5% dextrose is used in the treatment of persistent hypocalcemia. Hypocalcemia causes prolongation of the QT interval. There is a lengthening of the ST segment, while the T wave (which correlates with the time for repolarisation) remains unaltered.

Option D: Hypercalcemia causes shortening of the QT interval and a decrease in the ST segment duration. Initial therapy of significant hypercalcemia begins with volume expansion because hypercalcemia invariably leads to dehydration; 4–6 litres of intravenous saline may be required over the first 24 hours.

questions.text: 167. A study is performed where the mothers of both low birth weight (LBW) and normal birth weight babies are questioned regarding their intake of oral hypoglycemic agents (OHA) during the 1st trimester to determine the association of LBW and OHA intake in the first trimester. Which measure of association is appropriate for this study?
questions.solution:
The study design mentioned is a case-control study design to evaluate the strength of association between a risk factor and outcome. Hence, the best-suited measure would be the odds ratio.

Note that because the proportion of people in a case-control study who have the disease is determined by the researcher’s choice, and not by the actual proportion in the population, such studies cannot determine the incidence or prevalence of a disease, so they cannot determine the risk of contracting a disease. However, the strength of the association between a risk factor and the disease can still be evaluated with a case-control study, by examining the proportions of the people with and without the disease who had and had not, been exposed to the risk factor.

Other options:

Option A - Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates of disease (or death) between an exposed group and the non-exposed group. It is often expressed as a percentage. The terms "risk difference" or "cumulative incidence difference" refers to attributable risk.

Option C - Relative risk (RR) is the ratio of the incidence of the disease (or death) among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed.

Option D - Population-attributable risk is the incidence of the disease (or death) in the total population minus the incidence of disease (or death) among those who were not exposed to the suspected causal factor. Population attributable risk is measured by multiplying attributable risk with the population prevalence of exposure.

Pearl PM0267: Odds Ratio

* Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.

* Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.

* It is also known as cross product ratio.

* A representation of the odds ratio (OR) is given in the picture below:

Calculation of odds ratio (OR) = (a/b)/(c/d) = ad/bc where,  | Cancer Exposure | | Yes | No Yes | a | b No | c | d

* OR < 1 indicates possible protection (negative association) as the frequency of exposure is lower among cases than controls.

* OR = 1 indicates no association of risk with exposure, or that the event is equally likely in both groups.

* OR > 1 indicates increased risk (positive association) as the frequency of exposure is greater among cases than controls.

Pearl PM0269: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

* Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).

* It is also called risk ratio.



* It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.

* RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)

* RR = 1 indicates no association.

* RR > 1 indicates positive association.

* RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.

* Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 

| Cancer Exposure | | yes | no yes | a | b no | c | d

Attributable Risk:

* Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.

* It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: 168. During a routine physical examination of a female patient, you notice the following discoloration. She gives no other significant history. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image depicts a blue-gray macular patch over the acromioclavicular region, corresponding to the posterior supraclavicular and lateral cutaneous brachial nerve distribution, suggestive of Nevus of Ito.

Nevus of Ito is a dermal melanocytosis involving the acromioclavicular region and the upper chest. It is a benign lesion and is also known as naevus fusoceruleus acromiodeltoideus. Q‐switched laser systems are the first-line treatment, as they achieve higher rates of pigment clearing. 

Other options - 

Option A: Mongolian spots are seen in infants. They are bluish-grey pigmented areas, commonly seen over the sacrum. They usually resolve during childhood.

The image below shows Mongolian spots.



Option B: Becker nevus is a hyperpigmented nonlinear lesion commonly present over the upper trunk. It is common in men and appears within the first 2 decades, typically at puberty. The lesion is frequently hypertrichotic.

The below image shows Becker's nevus.



Option D: Nevus of Ota is an extensive, bluish, patchy, dermal melanocytosis. It affects the sclera and the skin adjacent to the eye. It is distributed along with the first and the second branches of the trigeminal nerve. The below image shows the nevus of Ota.

questions.text: 169. A 25-year-old female presents with chronic watery diarrhoea that persists even during fasting. There is no history of recent infection. Investigations reveal hypokalaemia but no signs of infection. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?

choices.text: Secretory diarrhoea with stool osmotic gap < 50 mOsm/kg
Secretory diarrhoea with stool osmotic gap > 50 mOsm/kg
Osmotic Diarrhoea with stool osmotic gap > 50 mOsm/kg
Osmotic Diarrhoea with stool osmotic gap < 50 mOsm/kg

questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis of the patient with chronic watery diarrhoea that persists even during fasting is Secretory diarrhoea with stool osmotic gap < 50 mOsm/kg.

Secretory diarrhoea occurs due to derangements in fluid and electrolyte transport across the enterocolonic mucosa. The diarrhoea is watery, large-volume, painless and persists with fasting. The patient has chronic watery diarrhoea with hypokalaemia, which suggests the most probable cause to be a Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide-secreting tumour (VIPoma).

The stool osmotic gap can be calculated by 290 – 2 (stool [Na+] + stool [K+]), where 290 mOsm/kg is the serum osmolality. A stool osmotic gap < 50 mOsm/kg signifies secretory diarrhoea, while a gap of >50–100 mOsm/kg indicates the presence of unmeasured osmoles, suggesting osmotic diarrhoea.

Other causes of secretory diarrhoea are:

* Gastrinoma

* Carcinoid 

* Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid 

* Chronic ethanol consumption

* Bowel resection

Other options:

Options C and D: Osmotic diarrhoea occurs when ingested osmotically active solutes draw enough fluid into the lumen to exceed the reabsorptive capacity of the colon. It stops with fasting or with discontinuation of the causative agent. The stool osmotic gap is more than > 50 mOsm/kg.

questions.text: 170. According to the provisions in the POCSO Act, which of the following is incorrect?

choices.text: Trial must be held in camera, in private
Medical examination must be conducted in the presence of the parents of the child
A child's statement can be recorded at the child’s residence
The child's medical examination must be conducted after the registration of an FIR

questions.solution:
The child's medical examination must be conducted after the registration of an FIR is incorrect. A child's medical examination can be conducted before FIR registration at the Investigating Officer's (IO) discretion.

Key provisions in the POCSO Act:

* Punishment is applicable for abetment or attempt to commit offences under the Act. Attempted offences are punishable up to half the punishment of the completed offence.

* Reporting the offence to the police is mandatory. Failure to report is punishable with up to 6 months imprisonment, a fine, or both.

* Police are mandated to register an FIR in all child abuse cases.

* A child's statement can be recorded at their residence or in a place where the child is comfortable (Option C).

*  A child's statement should be preferably recorded by a woman police officer in civil dress.

* A child's medical examination can be conducted before FIR registration at the Investigating Officer's (IO) discretion.

* Medical examination must be conducted in the presence of the parents of the child or in the presence of some other person whom the child trusts (Option B).

* The trial must be held in camera, that is, in private and not in open court where the public can view proceedings (Option A). The identity of the child must not be revealed.

* The burden of proof is shifted to the accused due to the innocence and vulnerability of the children.

* Punishment is provided for false complaints or malicious information.

* The media is prohibited from disclosing the child's identity without Special Court permission. Breaching media identity protection is punishable with 6 months to 1 year imprisonment.

questions.text: 171. A 2-week-old infant is brought in with lethargy, poor feeding, and vomiting. Laboratory findings include metabolic acidosis, hypoglycemia, and neutropenia. Tandem mass spectrometry shows elevated C5-carnitine levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with symptoms of hypoglycemia (lethargy, poor feeding) and elevated C5-carnitine levels is most likely suffering from isovaleric acidemia.

Isovaleric acidemia (IVA) is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the IVD gene, leading to deficiency of isovaleryl-CoA dehydrogenase, an enzyme involved in leucine metabolism. This results in the accumulation of toxic metabolites like isovaleric acid, isovalerylglycine, and C5-carnitine, detectable via newborn screening using tandem mass spectrometry.

Symptoms often present in the first weeks of life and include lethargy, poor feeding, vomiting, metabolic acidosis, hypoglycemia, and neutropenia. A distinctive “sweaty feet” or “rancid cheese" odour is a classic clue. Severe cases can progress to seizures, coma, and death if untreated. Episodes may be triggered by infections, high protein intake, or fasting.

Diagnosis is made by finding elevated C5-carnitine in blood and isovalerylglycine in urine, confirmed by IVD gene testing. Acute management includes IV fluids, glucose, carnitine, glycine supplementation, and treating hyperammonemia. Long-term care requires protein restriction and continued carnitine ± glycine to prevent metabolic crises.

Other options:

Option A: Methylmalonic acidemia presents with metabolic acidosis and elevated methylmalonic acid.

Option B: Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency presents with hyperammonemia without metabolic acidosis.

Option D: Maple syrup urine disease is characterised by a sweet maple syrup odour, not sweaty feet, and elevated branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, valine), not C5-carnitine.

questions.text: 172. While performing thyroidectomy on a patient with malignancy, a major portion of the recurrent laryngeal nerve had to be removed. The surgeon anastomosed the ansa cervicalis to the recurrent laryngeal nerve edges to maintain the continuity. What will this anastomosis help with?

choices.text: Maintains sensory input to the vocal cord
Returns mobility of the vocal cord
Maintain neurological input to the muscles of the larynx

questions.solution:
An anastomosis of the ansa cervicalis helps to maintain neurological input to the muscles of the larynx. 

In cases where a recurrent laryngeal nerve is injured during surgery, the transected ends are identified and they are reanastomosed. In cases where a length of nerve has to be removed due to invasion by malignancy, anastomosis of the ansa cervicalis is considered. This does not return mobility of the vocal cord (Option B) but maintains neurological input to the muscles of the larynx. This improves the vocal quality as it prevents denervation and muscle atrophy.

Ansa cervicalis innervates the sternohyoid, sternothyroid, and omohyoid muscles, which are responsible for depression of the hyoid bone. The recurrent laryngeal nerve takes sensory input from below the vocal cords. Motor supply to all the muscles of the vocal cord is supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve except the cricothyroid muscle.

Recurrent laryngeal nerve injury may be unilateral or bilateral, transient or permanent and causes a change in voice. Permanent vocal cord paralysis should be treated conservatively with speech therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Ansa cervicalis is not responsible for maintaining sensory input to the vocal cord. The sensory input to the larynx is by:

* internal laryngeal nerve (branch of the superior laryngeal nerve)- up to the level of the vocal cords

* recurrent laryngeal nerve- below the level of the vocal cords.

Option B: Anastomosis of the ansa cervicalis to the recurrent laryngeal nerve does not return the mobility of the vocal cord.

Option D: Ansa cervicalis is not responsible for maintaining the cough reflex. The cough reflex is initiated by irritation of the tracheal or laryngeal mucosae and mediated by the vagus nerve.

questions.text: 173. A forensic examiner is called to a crime scene. He refers to a chart to estimate time since death based on various post mortem changes. Which graph represents rigor?
questions.solution:
This graph illustrates the progression of various post-mortem (PM) changes to estimate the time since death. Curve 2 represents rigor mortis.

The X-axis represents time after death (in hours), and the Y-axis represents body temperature in degrees Celsius. 

Rigor mortis typically sets in around 2–4 hours after death, peaks at 12–24 hours, and gradually resolves by 36–48 hours as muscle proteins degrade. This produces a bell-shaped curve. 

Curve 1 shows a steady decline in body temperature, corresponding to algor mortis (cooling)—the process by which the body equilibrates with the ambient temperature.

Curve 3 indicates lividity and pooling of blood in dependent areas, causing purplish skin discoloration. It begins within 15 minutes and is well-developed within 4 hours. It sets in at its maximum at 6-12 hours and remains constant after that.

Curve 4 indicates decomposition. It starts after 24–36 hours and progressively increases with time.

questions.text:
174. A 35-year-old female from a rural area presents with fatigue and pallor for the past few weeks. Her lab reports are: Hemoglobin: 7.0 g/dL, Hematocrit: 21%, Reticulocyte count: 3%. Which of the following is the most likely interpretation of these findings?

Maturation time correction = 2

choices.text: Adequate marrow response, suggestive of hemolytic anemia
Adequate marrow response, suggestive of hypoproliferative anemia
Inadequate marrow response, suggestive of hypoproliferative anemia
Inadequate marrow response, suggestive of hemolytic anemia

questions.solution:
The lab findings indicate inadequate marrow response suggestive of hypoproliferative anemia since the reticulocyte production index is calculated to be 0.7.

In this clinical scenario, the patient is anemic as indicated by a significantly low hemoglobin (7.0 g/dL) and hematocrit. An accurate assessment of the reticulocyte count is essential for the initial classification of anemia. To properly interpret the reticulocyte count, the following corrections are necessary:

1. Calculation of Corrected Reticulocyte Count (CRC) which is given by the formula:

CRC= Reticulocyte count × (Patient’s hematocrit​/Normal hematocrit)

Assuming normal hematocrit to be 45%, CRC = 3 x (21/45) = 1.4

2. Calculation of Reticulocyte Production Index (RPI) to adjust for the prolonged life span of prematurely released reticulocytes in the blood which is given by the formula:

RPI = CRC/Maturation time correction

Substituting the value of CRC and Maturation time correction (given as 2), RPI = 1.4/2=0.7

* An RPI >2 indicates an adequate marrow response suggestive of conditions like hemolysis or blood loss

* An RPI <2 suggests an inadequate marrow response pointing towards hypoproliferative anemias like iron deficiency, chronic disease, or marrow failure or or maturation disorders like folate and vitamin B12 deficiency. 

In this case, since RPI is very low (0.7), this is suggestive of hypoproliferative anemia because the bone marrow has failed to appropriately increase red cell production relative to the severity of anemia. In hemolytic anemia, the RPI is typically ≥2.5 because the bone marrow responds vigorously to increased red cell destruction by ramping up production. Since this patient has an inadequate marrow response, hemolytic anemia is unlikely.

questions.text:
175. A 46-year-old alcoholic presents to your OPD with fissuring of the lips, cracking at angles of the mouth, red eyes, and oily scaly rash on the scalp. Among the following co-factors of enzyme complexes, which one is most affected?

NAD: Nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide

TPP: Thiamine pyrophosphate

FAD: Flavin-adenine-dinucleotide
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency. FAD and FMN are the coenzymes of riboflavin, hence, the cofactor most affected in this scenario is FAD.

FMN is formed by ATP-dependent phosphorylation of riboflavin, while FAD is synthesised by further reaction with ATP in which the AMP moiety is transferred onto FMN.

Riboflavin, or vitamin B2, deficiency manifests as angular stomatitis, magenta tongue, seborrhea, and corneal vascularisation. It is seen in alcoholism, and individuals with a poor diet and decreased intake of dairy products.

Other options:

Option A: NAD+ is the coenzyme of vitamin B3 (nicotinic acid, niacin). Deficiency causes pellagra (diarrhoea, dermatitis, dementia).

Option B: TPP is the coenzyme of vitamin B1 (thiamine). Deficiency causes beriberi (neuropathy, heart failure) or Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome (confusion, ataxia).

Option D: Coenzyme A is the coenzyme of vitamin B5 (pantothenic acid). Deficiency is rare but causes fatigue, numbness, and gastrointestinal issues.
