questions.text:
176. A patient who was operated on for a perforated appendix is suspected to have an intra-abdominal collection around the liver and sent to the radiologist for imaging.
When the patient lies in the supine position for USG, what is the most probable site into which this fluid collection will drain?
questions.solution:
The most probable site into which the fluid collection will drain is Morrison's pouch.

The given clinical scenario describes a case of intra-abdominal collection after an appendectomy, for which the patient is sent to the radiologist for USG. On lying in the supine position, intra-abdominal collections like pus/blood/fluid will tend to gravitate towards the most dependent position, which is the right subhepatic space/ Morison's pouch.

The peritoneal cavity is divided into a number of potential spaces that can become sites for harbouring intra-abdominal collections. The Right subhepatic space is called Morrison's pouch/ Hepatorenal pouch of Morison. A schematic diagram of the spaces around the liver showing Morrison's pouch is given below:



Relations of the right subhepatic space or Morison's pouch :

* Anteriorly: Inferior surface of the right lobe of the liver, gallbladder

* Posteriorly: Right adrenal gland, the upper part of the right kidney, the second part of the duodenum, the hepatic flexure of the colon, the transverse mesocolon, and part of the head of the pancreas

* Superiorly: Inferior layer of the coronary ligament

* Inferiorly: Communicates with the general peritoneal cavity

* Right and left: Limited by the diaphragm on the right and communicates with the omental bursa on the left

In a seated position, in females, the fluid content will tend to gravitate towards the rectouterine pouch or the Pouch of Douglas (Option C), which is the most dependent part on sitting. The pouch of Douglas is bounded anteriorly by the uterus and posteriorly by the rectum. In males, in the seated position, the rectovesical pouch is the most dependent place in the peritoneal cavity.

Other options:

Options A and B: Left and right paracolic gutters are present on either side of the descending and ascending colon, respectively and are responsible for tracking pus and other fluid between the upper and lower quadrants of the abdomen.

questions.text: 177. A 60-year-old male presents with enlargement of neck nodes. Examination of the left ear reveals conductive hearing loss with the tympanogram showing the following type of curve. Involvement of which of the following cranial nerves completes the features of Trotter's triad seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with a type B tympanogram, is suggestive of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Conductive deafness (i.e. eustachian tube blockage) along with the involvement of 5th and 10th cranial nerves together constitutes Trotter's triad seen in this condition.

A tympanogram helps determine the compliance or stiffness of the tympano-ossicular system, thereby indicating the healthy or diseased status of the middle ear. A type B tympanogram is a flat or dome-shaped graph and indicates no changes in compliance with pressure changes. It is seen in patients with middle ear fluid or a thick tympanic membrane.  

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma can cause,

* Conductive deafness (eustachian tube blockage),

* Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia due to involvement of CN V and

* Palatal paralysis due to involvement of CN X

This is collectively called as Trotter’s triad.

The commonest site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmuller. It is mostly seen in the fifth to seventh decades, with Males being more prone than females.

Presenting symptoms include,

* Cervical lymphadenopathy (most common)

* Hearing loss

* Nasal obstruction

* Epistaxis

* Cranial nerve palsies - The 6th Cranial nerve is most commonly involved among all the cranial nerves.

* Headache

* Earache

* Neck pain

* Weight loss

Radiotherapy is the treatment of choice for nasopharyngeal cancer.

* Stages I and II are treated by radiotherapy alone.

* Stage III and IV require concomitant radiation and chemotherapy or radiation followed by chemotherapy.

Pearl PM0227: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: 178. Name the ligament through which the left gastric artery passes and identify the embryological origin of this ligament in the image.
questions.solution:
The left gastric artery is present in the hepatogastric ligament, which is a part of the lesser omentum. The lesser omentum is derived from the ventral mesentery marked as B in the image given.

The structures marked in the image are:

A: Dorsal mesentery B: Ventral mesentery



Mesenteries are double layers of the peritoneum that enclose an organ and connect it to the body wall. They provide pathways for vessels, nerves, and lymphatics to and from the abdominal viscera.

Ventral mesentery: Only the foregut has a ventral mesentery. It is attached to the terminal part of the esophagus, the stomach, and the upper part of the duodenum. The ventral mesentery is derived from the septum transversum. When the liver grows into the mesenchyme of the septum transversum, it divides the ventral mesentery into 2 parts:  

* Lesser omentum- extends from the lower portion of the esophagus, the stomach, and the upper portion of the duodenum to the liver. It contains the hepatogastric and hepatoduodenal ligaments. The hepatoduodenal ligament contains the portal triad. (Option A, B)

* Ligaments of the liver- all ligaments of the liver (falciform ligament, right and left triangular ligaments, and coronary ligaments), except ligamentum teres

Dorsal mesentery: The foregut, midgut, and hindgut have dorsal mesentery. This connects the organs to the posterior abdominal wall. It runs from the lower end of the esophagus to the cloacal region of the hindgut. It has the following special names in different regions:

* Dorsal mesogastrium (or greater omentum)- stomach 

* Dorsal mesoduodenum- duodenum

* Mesentery proper- jejunum and ileum

* Mesoappendix- appendix

* Transverse mesocolon- transverse colon

* Sigmoid mesocolon- sigmoid colon

* Gastrosplenic ligament (stomach to the spleen), lienorenal ligament (spleen to the left kidney), and gastrophrenic ligament (stomach to diaphragm) are derived from the dorsal mesentery.



Pearl PM1128: Peritoneal folds and their contents

The following table shows various peritoneal folds (omenta, mesenteries and ligaments) and their contents. Peritoneal fold | Content Lesser omentum

a)    Hepatoduodenal ligament 

b)    Hepatogastric ligament | Hepatic artery, portal vein, and common bile duct

Right and left gastric vessels Greater omentum (along the greater curvature of the stomach) | Right and left gastro-epiploic vessels Gastrosplenic ligament | Short gastric and left gastro-epiploic branches of splenic artery Gastrophrenic ligament | Left inferior phrenic artery Gastrocolic ligament | Right gastroepiploic artery Splenorenal/Lienorenal ligament | Splenic vessels. Also contains the tail of the pancreas Mesentery | Jejunal and ileal branches of superior mesenteric artery Transverse mesocolon | Middle colic vessels Sigmoid mesocolon | Sigmoid and superior rectal vessels

questions.text: 179. In a surgery for a patient with carcinoma cervix, the uterus, cervix, upper 1.5cm of the vagina, the medial half of parametrium including lymph nodes and medial half of the uterosacral ligament was removed and the uterine artery was clamped at the point where it crosses the ureter. Identify the procedure:
questions.solution:
The given surgery best describes a Modified radical hysterectomy.

In the given clinical scenario, a patient with carcinoma cervix is undergoing a surgical procedure where the entire uterus,cervix, the medial half of the parametrium and lymph nodes and the upper 1.5 cm of the vagina are removed and the uterine artery is ligated at the point that it crosses the ureter. This description is consistent with a modified radical hysterectomy/ Wertheim's hysterectomy. 

Types of hysterectomy and their characteristics are given below: HYSTERECTOMY | UTERUS AND CERVIX | PARAMETRIUM

PARACOLPOS | UTERINE VESSELS | UTEROSACRAL LIGAMENT | VAGINA Simple/Extrafascial

(Option A)

(Type 1) | Removed | Preserved | Ligated at the uterine isthmus | Transect at uterine insertion | Preserved Modified Radical/Wertheim

(Type 2) | Removed | Removed medial to ureter | Ligated at the level of ureter | Transected midway between the uterus and rectum | Remove 1-2 cm Radical 

(Option B)

(Type 3) | Removed | Removed medial to uterine vessel origin | Ligate at origin from internal iliac vessels | Transect near rectum | Remove > or equal to 2cm Subtotal hysterectomy

(Option D) | Cervix preserved | Preserved | Ligate at uterine isthmus | Transect at uterine insertion | Preserved

Types 1-3 are part of the Piver and Rutledge classification for hysterectomy which initially divided hysterectomy into 5 types of which only types 1-3 are in use today, as shown above.

Wertheim's hysterectomy is done for carcinoma cervix of stage IA1 who have positive margins after conization and do not possess enough cervical tissue for repeat conization. It may also be done in Stage 1A1 with LVSI (lymphovascular space involvement) and in IA2 tumours with good results. This surgery poses a significant risk of ureteric injury as the limits of dissection extend upto the ureter.

Radical hysterectomy is preferred for IA2,1B1,1B2 uptil 2A1 lesions beyond which chemoradiation is considered a more suitable treatment modality. Extrafascial hysterectomy is done for preinvasive carcinoma cervix and may be attempted for IA1 lesions.

Subtotal hysterectomy is done when it is desirable to retain the cervix. The indications are in ruptured interstitial pregnancy, uterine rupture and as part of peripartum caesarian hysterectomy for any emergency indication. It is generally not preferred in cervical carcinoma. It is better termed as supracervical hysterectomy.

questions.text: 180. A 55-year-old woman presents with a fracture of the femur. The surgeon used the implant shown below for internal fixation of her fracture. Identify the implant?
questions.solution:
Kuntscher's cloverleaf intra-medullary nail, also known as the K-nail, can be used for internal fixation of femoral fractures and as shown in the image.

Kuntscher's cloverleaf intra-medullary nail (K nail) - 

* It is used for the treatment of femoral fractures.

* It is based on the concept of three-point fixation, i.e., at either end and at the isthmus.

* The eye at the end of the nail is useful while removing it.

* Cloverleaf shape on the cross-section provides good rotational stability.



Other options

Option B: Square nail is used for the management of fractures of the forearm bones, as shown in the image below.



Option C: Interlocking nails are used in the management of fractures of the femoral and tibial shafts, as shown in the image below.



Option D: Steinmann's Pin- It is a stout, straight steel rod of a diameter ranging from 3 to 6 mm. It is used for skeletal traction— common sites being the upper end of the tibia, supracondylar region of the femur, and calcaneum. Bohler’s stirrup is used for holding the Steinmann pin in skeletal traction.



Pearl PM1017: Orthopedic Instruments

questions.text: 181. In the management of Alzheimer's disease, which of the following drug is an NMDA antagonist?
questions.solution:
Memantine is an NMDA antagonist useful in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease.

* NMDA receptor permits the passage of Ca2+ and other cations present on hippocampal neurons.

* Tacrine was the first approved anticholinesterase for Alzheimer’s disease. But, a high incidence of enhanced alanine aminotransferase and hepatotoxicity limited the use and was subsequently withdrawn.

* Donepezil, galantamine, and rivastigmine are centrally acting cholinesterase inhibitors indicated for Alzheimer’s disease.

Treatment of Alzheimer's disease:

* Drugs which increase cholinergic activity: Donepezil, Rivastigmine, Galantamine

* NMDA antagonist: Memantine

* Antioxidants can also be given

Pearl PM0404: Alzheimer’s disease

Alzheimer’s disease:

* Age of onset > 60 years

* Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) < 24

* Diagnosis: Clinical

* 2 or more areas of cognitive deficits

* Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive function

* No disturbance in consciousness

* Other systemic causes must be ruled out 

Risk Factors:

* Most important risk factor: Old age

* Other risk factors – Family history, presenilin-1, presenilin-2, Apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE ε4 allele), Ubiquitin, Down syndrome and smoking.

Protective factors: NSAIDs and Apolipoprotein E2

Causes: Decrease in acetylcholine causing depletion of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert resulting in short-term memory defects. 

Early findings:

* Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)

* Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighborhood)

* Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)

* Cognitive impairment with a progressive decline

* Anosognosia 

* Visual processing dysfunction (posterior cortical atrophy syndrome)

* Difficulties with naming and repetition (logopenic aphasia)

Late findings:

* Psychotic symptoms: delusions

* Apraxia: Difficulty to perform learned motor tasks

* Lack of insight regarding deficits

* Non-cognitive neurologic deficits: Pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures

* disrupted sleep - wake pattern.

* Urinary incontinence.

* Loss of procedural memory

Histopathology:

* Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles (composed of tau proteins), neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease.



CT/MRI:

* Later stages: Cortical and subcortical atrophy prominent in parietal and temporal lobes, particularly hippocampus. 

Treatment:

* NMDA antagonist: memantine

* Cholinesterase inhibitors: donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine.

* Monoclonal antibodies against the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide - lecanemab, donanemab

questions.text: 182. All of the following diseases are transmitted by the vector shown in the image except:
questions.solution:
Scrub typhus is not caused by the vector shown in the image (tick).

The vector shown is a hard tick and transmits tick typhus, viral encephalitis (e.g., Russian spring-summer encephalitis), viral fevers (e.g., Colorado tick fever), viral hemorrhagic fevers (e.g. KFD in India), tularemia, tick paralysis, and babesiosis.

The following image shows a soft tick.



Scrub typhus is transmitted by trombiculid mite which is as shown below.



Pearl PM1684: Ticks

* The two types of ticks are hard ticks and soft ticks.

* The general morphology of ticks includes an oval-shaped body, four pairs of legs, and no antennae.

Head | Situated at the anterior end. | Lies on the underside of the body (ventrally). Not visible from above. questions.text: 183. You are an intern posted in the Obstetrics and Gynecology Department, where the resident asks you to bring the following instruments for a procedure. What is the most likely procedure planned?
questions.solution:
Pipelle aspirator (a) and Vabra (b) aspirator are shown in the image above, which are used to obtain endometrial sampling.

It is performed as an outpatient procedure without anaesthesia or under sedation. The cervix is not dilated, and a biopsy curette is inserted, and a strip or two of the endometrial tissue is obtained for histological study. It should be done preferably 1 or 2 days before the onset of menstruation. The material removed should be fixed immediately in formalin saline and submitted for histological examination.

In a postmenopausal woman, the normal endometrium should not exceed 4 mm in thickness (In a perimenopausal woman, it should not exceed 10 mm). If it exceeds 4 mm in a postmenopausal woman, then histopathological examination (HPE) of the endometrium is mandatory, irrespective of the presence or absence of symptoms.

questions.text: 184. A 10-year-old child was brought to the emergency with a history of fever, abdominal pain, and vomiting for 3 days. The symptoms started a few weeks after returning home from a village fair. The child was icteric and had tenderness in the right upper quadrant. Laboratory tests showed transaminitis with AST level 1000 IU/L, but serum IgG levels were normal. Ultrasound showed hepatomegaly with echo texture as shown below and associated gall bladder wall thickening. No antipyretics were given for his fever. What is the management for his condition?
questions.solution:
A child with a history of attending a village fair and presenting with fever, vomiting, jaundice, and tender hepatomegaly, showing typical starry sky echo-texture and associated gall bladder wall thickening on ultrasound and markedly raised transaminases, is likely suggestive of acute hepatitis A. The management of Acute hepatitis A includes supportive treatment.

Acute viral hepatitis (e.g., hepatitis A, B, or E) is typically a self-limiting condition characterised by acute inflammation of the liver. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of feco-oral transmission, which makes hepatitis A and E the differentials, however, hepatitis A is more commonly seen in children, making it more likely in our case.

Hepatitis A virus (HAV) is an icosahedral, non enveloped virus that causes hepatitis A infection. It is the most common cause of acute hepatitis in children. HAV is transmitted by the fecal-oral route. Usually, it is due to contamination of food or water. It may transmit from person to person due to poor hygiene.

It has an incubation period of 15 - 45 days. It may present with constitutional symptoms of nausea, vomiting, anorexia, malaise, myalgia, arthralgia, headache, and photophobia. A low-grade fever between 38° and 39°C is more often present in hepatitis A. 1-2 weeks after the constitutional symptoms, patients present with jaundice and tender hepatomegaly.

Ultrasound finding of hepatomegaly with typical starry sky echo-texture is seen in acute hepatitis of any etiology. Gallbladder wall thickening is more closely associated with hepatitis A.

This is followed by a recovery phase where the constitutional symptoms disappear but the hepatomegaly and elevated transaminases are still present. Full recovery is expected 1-2 months after the onset. Diagnosis of HAV is confirmed by IgM anti-HAV during acute illness. It can be prevented by HAV vaccination.

Other Options:

Option A: N-acetylcysteine therapy is indicated in acetaminophen overdose. But no antipyretics were given for fever in this patient.

Option B: Glucocorticoid therapy is the mainstay of management in autoimmune hepatitis. Considering the age and symtoms  of the patient with normal serum IgG levels, autoimmune hepatitis is unlikely.

Option C: Antivirals are not needed in Hepatitis A, since most patients recover spontaneously, only supportive treatment is required.

questions.text: 185. Which of the following drugs is effective in the delayed phase of post-chemotherapy nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution:
Aprepitant is the drug preferred for delayed-onset vomiting after cancer chemotherapy.

Nausea and vomiting associated with chemotherapy occur in two phases:

* The acute phase is seen within 24 hours and occurs in almost all patients receiving chemotherapy. In response to chemotherapeutic agents, the enterochromaffin cells in the small intestine secrete serotonin, which acts on the 5HT3 receptors and causes vomiting. This phase is treated by 5HT3 antagonists such as ondansetron, granisetron, and palonosetron.

* The delayed phase is seen on days 2-5 and occurs only in some patients. It occurs in response to stimulation of NK-1 receptors by substance P. 5HT3 antagonists are not effective against the delayed phase, and NK-1 receptor antagonists are used in these patients. 

NK-1 receptor antagonists include aprepitant and its parenteral formulation, fosaprepitant, rolapitant, and netupitant. These drugs are usually administered in combination with 5HT3 antagonists and dexamethasone for highly emetogenic chemotherapy. A fixed-dose combination of netupitant and palonosetron has been approved to cover both the acute and delayed phases of post-chemotherapy nausea and vomiting.

Other options:

Option A: Granisetron is a 5HT3 receptor antagonist, and is a very effective drug for the treatment of chemotherapy-induced postoperative nausea and vomiting. Granisetron is metabolised predominantly by the liver by the CYP3A family.

Option C: Domperidone predominantly antagonises the D2 receptor without major involvement of other receptors. It has prokinetic activity and is used to treat nausea and vomiting.

Option D: Metoclopramide involves 5HT4 receptor agonism, vagal and central 5HT3 antagonism, and possible sensitisation of muscarinic receptors on smooth muscle, in addition to dopamine receptor antagonism. It is used to treat nausea and vomiting that often accompany gastrointestinal dysmotility syndromes, such as gastroparesis.

questions.text: 186. An ophthalmologist observed the banking of veins distal to arteriovenous crossings along with flame-shaped haemorrhages in the retina of a patient with hypertension. What is the grading based on the Keith-Wagner Barker classification and what is the observed sign known as?
questions.solution:
The grading based on the Keith-Wagner Barker classification is Grade III and the sign is known as Bonnet sign.

Hypertensive retinopathy is the fundus change that occurs in a patient with systemic hypertension. It is graded based on the Keith-Wagner Barker classification as follows:

* Grade I - Mild generalised retinal arteriolar narrowing

* Grade II - Marked generalised narrowing, focal attenuation of arterioles and deflection of veins at AV crossings (Salu's sign)

* Grade III - Grade 2 changes with the following:

*

* Copper-wiring of arterioles

* Cotton wool spots, retinal haemorrhages (dot, blot, flame) or exudates (chronic retinal oedema)

* Bonnet’s sign: Banking of veins distal to arteriovenous crossings

* Gunn’s sign: Tapering of veins on either side of the arteriovenous crossings 

* Grade IV - Severe grade 3 changes with optic disc swelling or papilledema (a marker of malignant hypertension) and silver-wiring of arterioles.

questions.text: 188. Which of the following is not a contraindication for performing the following procedure in a patient with pancreatic carcinoma?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Whipple procedure. It is not contraindicated in pancreatic carcinoma patients with peripancreatic lymph node involvement.

Contraindications for resection:

* Liver metastases of any size

* Celiac lymph node involvement

* Peritoneal implants

* Hepatic hilar lymph node involvement

Findings that are not considered contraindications for resection:

* Duodenum or distal stomach invasion

* Peripancreatic lymph node involvement

* Involvement of Lymph nodes along the porta hepatis that can be swept down with the specimen 

The Whipple procedure is a complex surgery done for carcinomas involving the head of the pancreas.

The following structures are removed during the Whipple procedure:

* Distal stomach

* Duodenum

* Head of the pancreas

* Gallbladder

* Common bile duct (CBD)

* Regional lymphatics

questions.text: 189. A patient with a history of myasthenia gravis presents with sudden worsening of her muscle weakness, particularly involving her respiratory muscles. Which of the following is the most appropriate inital treatment?
questions.solution:
Myasthenic crisis is a life-threatening exacerbation of muscle weakness, typically caused by diaphragmatic and intercostal weakness leading to ventilatory failure. The most appropriate treatment now is plasmapheresis.

Plasmapheresis is a procedure in which plasma is removed and replaced with fluids or plasma from a donor. Plasmapheresis is effective in removing circulating antibodies that block acetylcholine receptors in myasthenia gravis, leading to rapid improvement in symptoms. It is considered the most appropriate initial treatment for myasthenic crisis.

Myasthenic crisis management requires intensive care.

* Exclude "cholinergic crisis" by temporarily stopping anticholinesterase medication if deterioration is suspected. Identify and treat any underlying infections immediately.

* Ventilatory assistance for breathing support.

* Rapid Immunotherapy: Plasmapheresis or intravenous immunoglobulin.

* Corticosteroids for long-term immunosuppression. Thymectomy may be considered in some cases. Neither of these are administered on an emergency basis.

Option B: Edrophonium: This is a short-acting cholinesterase inhibitor that increases the amount of acetylcholine available at the neuromuscular junction. Edrophonium can be used to diagnose myasthenia gravis and to temporarily improve muscle strength. However, it is not effective in severe myasthenic crisis and may even worsen symptoms.

Option C: Corticosteroids can be helpful in the long-term management of myasthenia gravis but are not effective in the acute setting of myasthenic crisis.

Option D: Thymectomy can be beneficial in some patients with myasthenia gravis, but it is not an emergency treatment and is not indicated in myasthenic crisis.

questions.text: 190. Which of the following is false regarding the structure marked by the red arrow?

choices.text: Injury causes Loss of sensation of the posterior one third of the tongue
Arises from the posterior trunk of mandibular nerve
It is joined by the chorda tympani branch of facial nerve
It is joined by a branch of inferior alveolar nerve

questions.solution:
The marked structure is the lingual nerve. Injury to the lingual nerve results in loss of sensation to the anterior two thirds of the tongue.

Points of identification: The nerve runs downwards and forwards on the surface of the medial pterygoid muscle.

The lingual nerve arises from the posterior trunk of the mandibular nerve. It is joined by the chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve and a branch from the inferior alveolar nerve.

Loss of sensation of the posterior one third of the tongue is due to the injury to glossopharyngeal nerve.

Deviation of the tongue to the affected side is seen in injury to the hypoglossal nerve.

questions.text: 191. A 6-year-old child presented with a sore throat, fever, and malaise. Examination findings are given in the image below. She was also found to have a penicillin drug allergy. Which of the following antibiotics can be used for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the image showing a bull neck appearance and greyish-white membrane over the faucial pillar are suggestive of pharyngeal diphtheria. Erythromycin can be used in this patient as she has a penicillin allergy.

Diphtheria is caused by the bacteria Corynebacterium diphtheriae which spreads via droplets through the respiratory tract (most important), cutaneous lesions, and fomites.

Respiratory tract diphtheria is characterized by a thick, adherent pseudomembrane (grey or white) on one/both tonsils and adjacent pharynx. Underlying soft tissue edema and enlarged lymph nodes can cause a bull-neck appearance. 

Patients with laryngeal diphtheria are at risk for suffocation because of local soft-tissue edema and airway obstruction by the diphtheritic membrane.

Management includes antitoxin therapy as a single empirical dose of 20,000-100,000 units and antibiotics. Penicillin G/ Benzylpenicillin can also be used for diphtheria. However, in case of an allergy to the same, Erythromycin is used. Other antibiotics used are clindamycin, rifampin, and tetracycline.

All household contacts should be closely monitored for 7 days. Culture should be taken from both the throat and nose. After culture, all contacts should receive the following.

* Antibiotic prophylaxis (benzathine penicillin G or erythromycin), regardless of immunization status.

* If fewer than three doses of diphtheria toxoid have been given, or vaccination history is unknown, an immediate dose of diphtheria toxoid should be given and the primary series completed according to the current schedule.

* If more than 5 years have elapsed since the administration of the diphtheria toxoid-containing vaccine, a booster dose should be given.

* If the most recent dose was within 5 years, no booster is required.

At least two successive negative cultures obtained 24 hr apart after completion of therapy are needed to confirm the elimination of the organism. If positive culture is obtained, the erythromycin course is repeated.

questions.text: 192. A 35-year-old man is found dead in a lake under suspicious circumstances. During the autopsy, the forensic pathologist performs the Gettler test to determine whether drowning occurred before death. The chloride concentration is found to be significantly lower on the left side of the heart compared to the right. Which of the following findings would most likely be seen in this individual?

choices.text: Shrinkage of red blood cells due to a hypertonic environment

questions.solution:
In this case, the Gettler test revealed a significantly lower chloride concentration on the left side of the heart compared to the right. This pattern is characteristic of freshwater drowning, and hyponatremia with hyperkalemia is most likely to be seen in this individual.

In freshwater drowning, hypotonic water is absorbed from the alveoli into the pulmonary circulation. The rapid influx of water dilutes the plasma (hemodilution), especially in the pulmonary veins and the left side of the heart, leading to a drop in chloride concentration. 

Red blood cells in this hypotonic environment swell and burst (hemolysis), releasing intracellular contents such as potassium, resulting in hyperkalemia. These electrolyte imbalances, particularly hyperkalemia, are cardiotoxic and can cause fatal arrhythmias, which is a typical cause of death in freshwater drowning. The hypotonic environment draws fluid into the circulation, leading to hemodilution and hyponatremia.

The Gettler test is used in forensic pathology to help determine the type of drowning by comparing chloride levels in the blood from both sides of the heart. In freshwater drowning, chloride concentration is significantly lower on the left side of the heart (pulmonary vein and systemic circulation) due to hemodilution.

Saltwater, on the other hand, is hypertonic, and instead of being absorbed, it draws water out of the bloodstream into the alveoli, causing pulmonary edema and hemoconcentration (increased blood chloride, hematocrit, and sodium). RBCs in this environment shrink due to osmotic loss of water, leading to hypernatremia without hyperkalemia, since red cell lysis does not occur to the same extent. (Options A, C, and D) Feature | Freshwater Drowning | Saltwater Drowning Osmolarity | Hypotonic | Hypertonic Fluid movement | Into circulation | Into alveoli Plasma effect | Hemodilution | Hemoconcentration RBC effect | Swelling and hemolysis | Shrinkage (no significant hemolysis) Electrolyte imbalance | Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia | Hypernatremia, normal potassium Cause of death | Cardiac arrhythmia (due to hyperkalemia) | Pulmonary edema, hypoxia

questions.text:
193. Arrange in sequence the phases of damage control surgery.
* Re-exploration to perform a definitive repair of all injuries.
* Normalisation of biochemical and physiological parameters in the ICU.
* Rapid sequence induction of anesthesia and intubation followed by movement to the operating theatre.
* Immediate laparotomy with temporary wound closure.
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option C: 3,4,2,1

The correct sequence of phases of damage control surgery (DCS) are:

3. Rapid sequence induction of anesthesia and intubation followed by movement to the operating theatre.

4. Immediate laparotomy with temporary wound closure.

2. Normalisation of biochemical and physiological parameters in the ICU.

1. Re-exploration to perform a definitive repair of all injuries 

The aim of the DCS is to restore physiology over anatomy. It is applied to trauma patients with combined vascular and visceral injuries.

The phases are:

*

Phase 1 involves recognition of the severity of the injury. Here,rapid-sequence induction of anesthesia and intubation is done. This is followed by early rewarming and prompt movement of the patient to the operating theatre.

*

Phase 2 involves performing immediate laparotomy. Here, the focus is to control bleeding and contamination. Abdominal packing and temporary wound closure are done.

*

Phase 3 involves movement to the intensive care unit (ICU). The aim is to normalize the biochemical and physiological parameters.

*

Phase 4 involves re-exploration in the operating theatre. Here, definitive repair of all injuries is done. Multiple procedures on multiple occasions may be required.

Pearl PM2082: Damage Control Surgery

Five stages of damage control surgery:

1. Patient selection 2. Control of hemorrhage and control of contamination 3. Resuscitation continued in the intensive care unit 4. Deﬁnitive surgery 5. Abdominal closure

Phases of Damage Control Surgery:

Phase 1: Identification of patient for damage control surgery in emergency room Phase 2: Emergency laparotomy to stop bleeding and prevent contamination Phase 3: ICU care for resuscitation Phase 4: Re-laparotomy for definitive repair Indications for damage control surgery: Anatomical

* Inability to achieve haemostasis

* Complex abdominal injury, e.g. liver and pancreas

* Combined vascular, solid and hollow organ injury, e.g. aortic or caval injury

* Inaccessible major venous injury, e.g. retrohepatic vena cava

* Demand for non-operative control of other injuries, e.g. fractured pelvis

* Anticipated need for a time-consuming procedure

Physiological (decline of physiological reserve)

* Temperature <34ºC

* pH <7.2

* Serum lactate >5 mmol/L (normal is <2.5 mmol/L)

* Prothrombin time (PT) >16 s

* Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) >60 s

* Blood transfusion approaching 15 units

* Blood pressure <70 mmHg

Environmental

* Operating time >60 min

* Inability to approximate the abdominal incision

* Desire to reassess the intra-abdominal contents (directed relook)

questions.text: 194. A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of painful and swollen right breast for the past 4 weeks. On examination, a few matted axillary nodes and warmth of the right breast are noted. What is the treatment of choice?

choices.text: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy + Modified radical mastectomy + Radiotherapy

questions.solution:
The clinical photo shows erythema, edema, and dimpling (peau d'orange appearance) on the right breast, which together with the history and examination findings suggest a diagnosis of inflammatory breast carcinoma. It is treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy, followed by modified radical mastectomy and radiotherapy.

Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage T4d) is the most aggressive subtype and is associated with the worst prognosis. It accounts for <3% of breast cancers. It is characterized by skin changes of brawny induration, erythema, and edema (peau d’orange). The term peau d’orange describes the orange-peel appearance of the skin resulting from edema and dimpling at sites of hair follicles.

Diagnostic criteria for inflammatory breast cancer: 

* Sudden onset of inflammatory signs, such as warmth, redness, swelling, and/or peau d’orange, which may occur with or without a palpable mass

* Histopathological confirmation of invasive carcinoma

* Symptoms present for ≤6 months

* Erythema involving at least 1/3 of the breast

A cut-off of 6 months for the duration of history differentiates between inflammatory breast carcinoma (≤6 months) and locally advanced breast cancer with secondary erythema (>6 months).

The pathologic hallmark of inflammatory breast carcinoma is the presence of tumor cells within dermal lymphatics in skin biopsy specimens, but it is not a prerequisite for diagnosis.

Mammography may show normal findings or skin thickening. A PET-CT scan should be considered at the time of diagnosis to rule out concurrent metastatic disease.

Axillary nodal metastases are common, and there is a significant risk for distant metastases.

Treatment for inflammatory breast carcinoma is combined-modality treatment, which includes the following: neoadjuvant chemo­therapy + modified radical mastectomy + radiation therapy + hormonal therapy (for ER-positive tumors)/ Trastuzumab (for HER-2-positive tumors).

questions.text: 195. A child presenting with cervical lymphadenitis is suspected to have a nontuberculous mycobacteria infection. A culture study revealed yellow-orange pigmented colonies in the dark on LJ medium. What is the likely etiological agent?
questions.solution:
A child presenting with cervical lymphadenitis/scrofula and yellow-orange pigmented colonies in the dark on LJ medium is suggestive of Mycobacterium scrofulaceum infection. 

Mycobacterium scrofulaceum is a scotochromogen and belongs to group II of Runyon's classification. These strains can form yellow or orange-colored pigmented colonies in light and dark. It is known to cause scrofula (cervical adenitis) in children.

Other options -

Option A and C - Mycobacterium ulcerans, Mycobacterium avium complex are non-photochromogens that do not form pigment even on exposure to light. Mycobacterium ulcerans causes Buruli ulcers, painless ulcers in tropical areas, whereas Mycobacterium avium complex causes opportunistic infections, especially in HIV-infected people with low CD4 T cell count (<50/μL) as lymphadenitis, respiratory infection, and disseminated disease.

Option D - Mycobacterium marinum causes swimming pool granuloma or fish tank granuloma and is classified as a photochromogen, producing yellow-orange pigmented colonies only in light.

questions.text: 196. An elderly man is prescribed sucralfate for chronic gastritis. He is also on Digoxin for atrial fibrillation and Ciprofloxacin for UTI. He reports taking all these medications together after meals so that he does not forget. What is the most likely outcome of this practice?

choices.text: Increased risk of Ciprofloxacin toxicity due to delayed gastric emptying
Reduced efficacy of Digoxin and Ciprofloxacin due to sucralfate interaction
Increased absorption of Digoxin due to enhanced gastric pH
No significant drug-drug interactions are expected with sucralfate

questions.solution:
Reduced efficacy of Digoxin and Ciprofloxacin due to sucralfate interaction is the most likely outcome of this practice.

Sucralfate forms a viscous, sticky layer in the stomach that may inhibit the absorption of certain drugs, including digoxin, ciprofloxacin, phenytoin, and others. To prevent this, sucralfate should be administered at least 2 hours after other medications.

Sucralfate is associated with significant drug interactions with drugs such as (option D):

* Digoxin

* Levothyroxine

* Furosemide

* Quinolones

* Ciprofloxacin

* Warfarin and others by reducing their absorption

Antacids, if administered within 30 minutes of sucralfate, decrease the binding ability of sucralfate to gastric ulcers. It is advised to take sucralfate on an empty stomach or 1-2 hours after a meal so that the food does not interfere with the mechanical action of sucralfate.

Other options:

Option A: Sucralfate does not delay gastric emptying to a clinically significant degree that would cause ciprofloxacin toxicity. Instead, it interferes with the absorption of ciprofloxacin. 

Option C. Sucralfate does not enhance gastric ph; it acts locally by forming a protective barrier in an acidic environment.

questions.text: 197. A 34-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. He is in severe respiratory distress. Endotracheal intubation is unsuccessful due to massive facial trauma and oropharyngeal bleeding. An emergency cricothyrotomy is performed to establish an airway. Which of the following structures is incised in this procedure?
questions.solution:
An emergency airway is established by making an incision through the cricothyroid membrane, which is labeled as structure 2 in the diagram.

The cricothyroid membrane lies between the thyroid cartilage and the cricoid cartilage and is relatively superficial, making it an ideal site for quick access to the airway when endotracheal intubation is not possible.

This procedure is especially indicated in trauma patients with facial injuries, severe oropharyngeal bleeding, or other anatomical distortions that prevent oral or nasal intubation. The cricothyroid membrane provides a direct route into the subglottic airway, bypassing upper airway obstructions and allowing rapid oxygenation.

questions.text:
198. Match the following antiretroviral drugs with their important adverse effects.

Antiretroviral drug | Adverse effect * Didanosine * Abacavir * Indinavir * Enfuvirtide | * Hypersensitivity syndrome * Nephrolithiasis * Peripheral neuropathy * Injection-site reactions
questions.solution:
Option B is correctly matched. Antiretroviral drug | Adverse effect 1. Didanosine | c. Peripheral neuropathy 2. Abacavir | a. Hypersensitivity syndrome 3. Indinavir | b. Nephrolithiasis 4. Enfuvirtide | d. Injection-site reactions

Didanosine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) used in the treatment of HIV-1, HIV-2, and HTLV-1. Peripheral neuropathy characterized by pain, numbness, and tingling in glove and stock pattern, and pancreatitis are the most adverse effects of this drug. Stavudine, another NRTI, also causes similar adverse effects. 

Abacavir is also an NRTI approved for the treatment of HIV-1 infection. The most serious adverse effect of abacavir is a hypersensitivity syndrome characterized by fever, maculopapular rash, abdominal pain, gastrointestinal upset, malaise, and fatigue.

Indinavir is a protease inhibitor that has a unique adverse effect of nephrolithiasis and crystalluria. It is also associated with asymptomatic unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, hyperglycemia, and insulin resistance.

Enfuvirtide is an entry (fusion) inhibitor that binds to the transmembrane gp41 of HIV-1 and blocks its entry into the host cells. It is the only approved parenteral antiretroviral drug and therefore, injection-site reactions like pain, erythema, induration, and nodules/cysts development are most frequently seen.

Pearl PM1516: Classification of antiretroviral drugs

questions.text: 199. A patient suspected of having ischemic colitis following a major abdominal surgery underwent CECT abdomen, which showed poor perfusion at Sudeck’s point. This indicates ischemia of:
questions.solution:
Poor perfusion of Sudeck's point indicates ischemia of the rectosigmoid junction.

The given vignette describes a case of suspected ischemic colitis after abdominal surgery, for which the patient is undergoing a contrast-enhanced CT scan. The scan identifies poor perfusion at Sudeck's point. Sudeck's point is an important watershed area in the rectosigmoid junction where the sigmoidal and superior rectal arteries anastomose.

A watershed area is a region at the edge of an area supplied by end arteries from two main arteries. These areas are dependent on collateral circulation and are prone to ischemia due to the poor blood supply of the area. There are two important watershed points in the colon, Griffith point and Sudeck point. 

Griffith's point is the term used for the splenic flexure, where a marginal artery may be absent, at the junction of the superior and inferior mesenteric circulations. Anastomoses are avoided in this area as they have a higher risk of undergoing ischemia and failing to take up well. The left colon, including the splenic flexure, is the most common site for colonic ischemia.

Sudeck's point is the term used to describe the rectosigmoid junction which recieves a precarious blood supply from superior rectal and sigmoidal arteries, both branches of inferior mesenteric artery and prone to atherosclerotic changes. Ischemic injury is also common in the right colon as it is supplied by the terminal branch of the SMA, the ileocolic artery.



Ischemic colitis is a condition where low blood flow to the colon results in ischemia and injury. Predisposing factors include aortic surgeries, diabetes, hypertension, peripheral vascular disease, abdominal surgeries involving IMA ligation,anti-TNF alpha inhibitors, and cocaine. 

The presentation includes sudden abdominal pain, hematochezia, vomiting, abdominal distension, and tenderness. On X-ray, a classical thumbprinting sign is observed, which indicates submucosal oedema.

CT scan is a better investigation, and signs like pneumatosis intestinalis, portal venous gas, and the absence of large bowel enhancement suggest the need for immediate surgery.

The best/gold standard investigation is a flexible endoscopy, which shows edematous, friable mucosa, erythema, petechial haemorrhages, and mucosal ulcers with a segmental distribution that abruptly transitions from abnormal to normal mucosa.

Treatment in uncomplicated cases is generally conservative management with bowel rest, plenty of IV fluids, NG tube decompression, and broad-spectrum antibiotics. Complications like pneumatosis, bowel infarctions, and perforations necessitate resection of the necrosed segment by laparotomy. questions.text: 200. A 40-year male patient came to the hospital with complaints of dysphagia and chest pain for 1 month. ECG was normal. A barium study was done, which is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the barium study showing the corkscrew appearance of the esophagus is suggestive of diffuse esophageal spasm. 

Diffuse esophageal spasm (DES) is a hypermotility disorder of the oesophageal body. It is caused by spontaneous, abnormal contractions seen more in the distal two-thirds of the esophageal body. It is more common in women. 

It is characterized by incoordinate movements of the esophagus due to marked hypertrophy of the circular muscles which in turn leads to symptoms like dysphagia and chest pain. These symptoms may be related to eating or exertion and may mimic those of angina. Patients will complain of a squeezing pressure in the chest that may radiate to the jaw, arms, and upper back. The symptoms are often pronounced during times of heightened emotional stress. Regurgitation of esophageal contents and saliva is common.

Investigations:

* Manometry is the gold-standard diagnostic test.

* The classic manometry findings in DES are simultaneous multipeaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg) or long duration (>2.5 seconds).

* On high-resolution manometry, a DCI (distal contractile integral) >450 mmHg is suggestive of DES. There is intermittent normal peristalsis.

* A corkscrew appearance in the barium swallow. 

Treatment - Temporary symptomatic relief can be provided by calcium channel blockers, vasodilators, and endoscopic dilation. However, in some cases, surgical repair is required to treat dysphagia.

Pearl PM2445: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance



Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.



Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.



Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.



Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.



Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.



Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.





Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect. 



Pearl PM1575: Manometric classification of esophageal motility disorders

Types | Definition Disorders of EGJ obstruction Type I achalasia (classic) | Abnormal IRP 100% failed peristalsis Type II (with panesophageal pressurization) | Abnormal IRP 100% failed peristalsis Panesophageal pressurization Type III (spastic) | Abnormal IRP 100% failed peristalsis Spastic contractions Panesophageal pressurization or normal presurization DCI > 450mmHg Disorders of peristalsis DES (Diffuse esophageal spasm) | Normal IRPN Non-peristaltic (spastic) contractions or premature contractions. DCI>450mmHg Nutcracker’s esophagus | Normal IRP Increased duration of peristalsis Normal peristalsis DCI>8000mmHg

DCI (distal contractile integral) is an index of contractile vigor and is calculated as the product of amplitude, duration, and span of the distal esophageal contraction, (mmHg·s·cm).

IRP (integrated relaxation pressure) corresponds to the mean pressure of greatest post deglutitive relaxation in a 10 seconds gap, triggered at the beginning of a swallow, (mmHg).
